item.title: 1. Introduction
item.description:
In many contexts, the term 'couple' has replaced 'marriage' because of its emphasis on the bond between family members/individuals.
This shift in language is important - taking a non-judgmental approach.
There is a social value implied by the more traditional terms (which privileges marriage).


Use the most inclusive term possible (e.g., family)
With respect to all types of relationships, use the term 'couple' as it broadly encompasses those within a committed relationship (regardless of marital status).
With respect to persons of various gender identities and sexual orientations, use the term 'partner' rather than gendered language (whenever possible).
While the terms such as spouse, wife, husband, boyfriend, girlfriend may be preferred by clients - intentionally using the term 'partner' may be more inclusive.
With respect to those we serve, we will refer to them as clients as opposed to patients (whenever possible).


Psychiatrists are physicians whoo specializes in the diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of mental health and emotional problems. (M.D. needed)
Psychologist study the human mind and behavior. (Masters needed)
Social Workers help people function the best way they can in their environment, deal with their relationships, and solve problems. (Bachelors degree needed, unless clinical social work which needs a masters level degree)
Counselors assist people with personal, family, educational, mental health, and career decisions and problems. (Masters needed)
All:
Diagnose
Individual/relational intervention
Psychiatry
Diagnose
Prescribe
Psychology
Assessment
Intra
Marriage and family Therapy
Family intervention
Inter
Social Work
Case management


A family's patterns of behaviors influences the individual and therefore may need to be a part of the treatment plan.
In CFT, the unit of treatment isn't just the person - even if only one person is 'the client'; it is the set of relationships in which the person is embedded.
Brief
Solution-focused
Specific with attained therapeutic goals
Designed with attainable therapeutic goals
Designed with the 'end in mind'
MFTs treat a wide range of serious clinical problems including:
Depression
Relationship issues
Anxiety
Biopsychosocial-rooted problems
Research has shown that CFT is as effective or more effective than standard individual treatments for many mental health problems including:
Schizophrenia
Affective Mood Disorder
Substance (Ab)use
Child Conduct Disorder
Anorexia
Autism
Chronic Illness
Couple/Partner Distress


Psychiatry raised concern about scope of practice
Wanted to keep MFTs from diagnosis
Psychology sought amendments to the scope to place restrictions on psychological testing, and some oppose licensure in general.
Social Work concerned with title restriction
Wanted to call its members MFTs
Counselors (ACA) historically most active opponents
Opposed MFT licensure all together
Labeled the discipline as a subspecialty of counseling


Professionals from many different disciplines may at times utilize family-based interventions, or work from theories or models that are core to the CFT discipline.
Does that mean they are CFTs?


Profession vs. Practice
AAMFT's response 'It's not our intent to define the standards or the scope of practice of any other discipline - social work or psychology, for example, by saying what services they can perform or what training is need to perform those series.
"We assume those professions will be diligent in ensuring that their practitioners will only deliver services for which they have had training, and are competent to perform, and that the regulatory boards for those professions will police those who go beyond their competence."


Classic Schools
Bowen
Strategic Family Therapy
Jay Haley
Depathologize problems by viewing them as normative life-cycle complications.
Consider possible adaptive functions for the family.
Acknowledge the helpful, alberit misguided, intentions of individuals within a family to help one another.
In such reformulations, new solutions can more readily become apparent.
Structural Family Therapy
Salvador Minuchin
No family style is inherently normal or abnormal.
Whether organizational patterns are functional or dysfunctional depends largely on their fit with the family's developmental and social demands.
The strength of the system requires clear yet flexible boundaries and subsystems for the ability to shift organizational patterns to accommodate needed change.
Experiential Family Therapy
Virginia Satir
Carl Whitaker
Psychoanalytic Family Therapy
Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy (CBT)
Developments
Contextual Therapy
Solution-Focused Therapy
Focus on solutions (i.e., what works), future-oriented.
Focusing on exceptions (i.e., those times when the problem was not present).
Direct toward building solutions rather than increasing insight into punitive maladaptive psychological mechanisms.
Narrative Therapy
Michael White
David Epston
Families have good intentions and neither want nor need problems.
Families can develop empowering stories when separated form their problems and constraining cultural beliefs.
Redirect focus from causal assumptions of dysfunction to appreciate the toxic effects of many dominant discourses in the social world.
Others
Internal Family Systems (IFS) Therapy
Evidenced-based treatments
Couples
Emotionally Focused Therapy (EFT)
Gottman Therapy
Relationship Education there
Marital Preparation
Multi-group Couples Therapy


Does family therapy work?
Therapeutic processes (e.g., how it works)
Therapeutic outcomes (e.g., what results)
How large are the effects of family therapy in terms of their impact on families?
Are these effects sometimes negative?
What are the efficacy and effectiveness of different models of family therapy?
What therapist and family factors predict responsiveness to treatment?
Is family therapy helping in treatment individual problems?


What interactional patterns or characteristics of the family?
How healthy and satisfied is the family?
How did the relational patterns develop? How are they maintained? Risk factors for family functioning?
How do cultural and contextual factors (e.g., age, gender, identity, class, race, etc.) play into the family's functioning?
How has the family adapted to transitions, change, and crises?


Frequency, setting, and duration of symptoms?
Who besides the family is included in the problem?
Are psychotropic medications being used?
Are individual sessions held? And under what conditions?
Co-therapists?
Is therapy time limited? How long does it last? How often are sessions?


What is the therapist's role? Consultant? Teacher? Healer?
What is the role of the therapist-couple alliance? How is a working alliance fostered?
To what degree does the therapist direct sessions? How does the therapist direct sessions? How does the therapist handle escalations?
Do clients talk to one another or the therapist?
Do clients talk to one another or the therapist?
Does the therapist use self-disclosure? What are the limits?
Does the therapist's role change during the course of therapy?


What are the treatment goals?
How are the goals determined or prioritized?
Who determines the goals of therapy?
How are 'mixed agendas' handled?


How structured are therapy sessions? Pacing or rhythm?
What techniques are used to join with the family?
Is psychoeducation included?
Is homework included?
If secrets are revealed individually, how are secrets handled?
What are the common errors that a therapist can make?
How is termination determines and handled?


Why is family therapy important?
Why might clients choose family therapy over other approaches (i.e., individual, couple, group therapy)?
When might family therapy be preferred to other treatment modalities?
Under what circumstances or presenting problems might family therapy be most appropriate?


What is your assessment of the problem?
What is the presenting problem? Who is defining it? How is it defined?
Who is the identified client?
How does each member of the family view the problem? Do they share the defition?
What solutions have been attempted?
What are the family's beliefs, values, and cultural strengths for dealing with the problem?



Reaction to psychoanalytic traditions
Research on schizophrenia
Acknowledge of family and contextual factors in mental illness
Adoption of systems theories


1920s
Group Therapy Movement
1940-1950
The Child Guidance Movement (1940s-1950s)
1950s
Communication and role theories
1970s
Brief therapy theories


Therapists first encountered families as adversaries.
Therapists begin to notice that often when a client got better, someone else in the family got worse, almost as though the family needed a symptomatic member.
Clients improved in the hospital only to get worse when they went home.


Parents sometimes use their children as a buffer to protect themselves from intimacy/
I.e., You're scratching your eyes for your mother so she'll have something to worry about. You're a good boy. Good children sacrifice themselves for their parents.
I.e., Minuchin: As a father of a child in danger, what you're doing isn't enough. Father: What should I do? Minuchin: I don't know. Ask your son.


Groups dynamics are applicable to family therapy because group life is a complex blend of individual personalities and properties of the group.
The process/context distinction in group dynamics had a major impact on family therapy.
Attend to how family members talk as much as to what they say.
Family members have a long history and a future together.
Continuity, commitment, and shared distortions all make family therapy different from group therapy.


Concluded that the real problem wasn't a child's symptoms, but rather the tensions in the family that were the source of those symptoms.
Tendency to blame the parents, especially mothers (this was an evolutionary misdirection that haunts the field).
We need to understand the family in order to diagnose problems.


Many do not distinguish between couple and family therapy.
Couples therapy is just family therapy applied to a particular subsystem.
However, there is a case to be made that couples therapy is a distinct enterprise (see Gurman texts)


For many years, therapists resisted the idea of seeing clients' families in order to safeguard the privacy of the therapeutic relationship.
Converging developments in the 1950s led to a new view that the family was an organic whole.
What they observed was that the behavior of schizophrenia fit with their families; what they concluded was that the family was the cause of schizophrenia.


Champions of family therapy challenged the assumption that schizophrenia was a biological disease. Psychological healers everywhere cheered. Unfortunately, we were wrong.
The observation that schizophrenic behavior seems to fit in some families doesn't mean that families caused schizophrenia.
Families of schizophrenic members suffered for years from the assumption that they were to blame for their child's psychoses.


Modern Model Events and Timeline

1950s:

To understand this better, consider the example of a mobile.
When you move any one piece of a mobile, all the other pieces move too. They do not exist in isolation from one another, and movement in any one part of the system will affect all the rest of the parts of the system.


The study of feedback mechanisms in self-regulating systems.
Feedback Loop:
The process by which a system gets the information necessary to maintain a steady course.
If you see behavior persist over time, there is likely something maintaining that behavior.
Feedback loops can be negative or positive.
Negative Feedback:
Indicates that a system is straying off the mark and that corrections are needed to get back on track.
Positive Feedback
Reinforces the direction a system is taking.


What shows up as one individual's behavior may be a product of the relationship.
Family therapists use concepts to describe how people in a relationship contribute to what goes on between them (e.g., pursuer/distancer; overfunctioning/underfunctioning)
At the core, the theory is about:
Structure
Functioning
The whole is greater than the sum of its parts.
Mapping sequences of interaction (which reveal how a system works)
Homeostasis:
The self-regulation that keeps the system stable
Families tend to resist change, which explains why so many clients remain stuck despite heroic efforts to improve.


A system is, 'Any entity maintained by the mutual interaction of its parts.'
A system can be composed of smaller subsystems.
Every system is a subsystem of larger systems.
Open vs. Closed systems
Unlike machines, families change when necessary to adapt to new circumstances.


Social Constructionism:
Seeing the world through a pair of glasses.
Reframing:
Relabeling behavior to shift how family members respond to it.
The goal of therapy shifted from interrupting problematic patterns of interaction to helping clients find new perspective on their lives.
When they said reality was constructed, they meant socially constructed.


Interpretations are shaped by our context.
Interpretation of our experience mediates behavior.
Social constructionists place more emphasis on the intersubjective influence of language and culture.
Therapy becomes a process of deconstruction, freeing clients from the tyranny of entrenched beliefs.


Inherent in most forms of therapy is the idea that before you can solve a problem, you must figure out what is wrong.
But solution-focused turns this assumption on its head.
The best way to solve problems is to discover what people do when they are not having the problem.
Exceptions to a complaint.


Therapists create a shift in their clients' experience by helping them reexamine how they look at things.
Externalization:
Redefining problems not as properties of the individuals who suffer them, but as alien oppressors.


The focus of therapy has expanded toward the wider context.
This process started when therapists looked beyond individuals to their families.
Suddenly unexplained behavior made sense.
Early on, family therapists focused on behavioral interactions surrounding problems.
Next, they recognize that those interactions were manifestations of a family's underlying structure.
Structure became the target of change.
Later, family structure was seen as the product of multigenerational processes that were governed by belief systems.
Then, therapists aimed their interventions at those underlying beliefs.
More recently, it dawned on therapists that those belief systems do not arise in a vacuum
Behavior is shaped by transactions we don't always see.
Systems concepts help make complex interactions predictable.


Family Structure:
Defines the organization within which interactions take place.
Interactions shape structure, but once established structure shapes interactions.
Subsystems
Boundaries
Family Life Cycle
Context:
People are products of their context.
Behavior is powerfully influenced by interactions with other family members.
Circular Causality:
Problems are sustained by an ongoing series of actions and reactions.
Triangles
Process/Content
Focus on the process of communication (how people talk), rather than the context (what they talk about)



The goal is to get an overview of the presenting problem and arrange to meet.
Listen to the description of the problem and identify all members of the family, household, and others who might be involved.
Establish connection and engagement.
Ask how the problem is affecting other members of the family.
You'd like to hear from everyone, at least initially, in order to get as much information as possible.
Reminder calls help increase likelihood of attendance.


Build alliance with the family.
Develop hypothesis about what is maintaining the presenting problem.
Establish rapport.
Gather information.
Introduce yourself.
Orient the family to the therapy room (physical or virtual) and the format of sessions.
Invite family members to speak one at a time.
Give everyone a chance to be heard.
Establish a bond of understanding with each member of the family.
Process:
How did you feel about coming in?
What were your reactions to coming in?
Take a family history.
Conduct the genogram to diagram the family network.
Listen for family life cycle transitions.
Search for strengths and resilience.
Remain curious and respectful.
Explore the process of family interaction by asking questions about how family members relate to one another and inviting them to discuss their problems with one another in session.
What is keeping the family stuck?
Share recommendations for treatment.


What is maintaining the problem?
Maintain therapeutic alliance.
Listen to and acknowledge family members' points of view.
Through empathic understanding, family members feel respected and become open to being challenged.
When one person is presented as the problem, challenge linearity by asking how others are involved or affected? What role do others play in creating or maintaining the problem? How have they responded to it?
Challenge unhelpful interactions by pointing out patterns that seem to be keeping the family stuck.
The more you do X, the more they do Y - and the more you do Y, the more they do X.
Listen to people's feelings.
Listening is a silent activity, rare in our time, even among therapists.
Family members are not likely to reconsider their assumptions until they've been heard and understood.


Help family members deal with one another more effectively in session.
Take a less active role and encourage family members to interact more with one another.
Step back and observe.
When family members address their conflicts directly, they tend to become reactive; anxiety is the enemy of listening - help them listen and manage anxiety.
Stay calm:
You are not responsible for solving the family's problems.
Just look for the constraints that are keeping them stuck.
Be curious.
Display empathy and respect.


Review the therapeutic relationship.
Say goodbye.
Reinforce progress.
Review what the family has accomplished.
Anticipate and plan for upcoming challenges.
How will you know when things are heading backwards? And what will you do?
How will you know if it is time to come back to therapy?
Check-in with the family following treatment, if possible.


The presenting problem
Understanding the referral route
Identifying the systemic context
Stage of family life cycle
Family structure
Communication
Substance use/abuse
Domestic violence and sexual abuse
Affairs/infidelity
Cultural context (race, ethnicity, culture, gender identity, sexual orientation, class, disability, etc.)


Explore the presenting problem.
Explore attempts to deal with the problem.
What have they tried?
What has been helpful?
What hasn't been helpful?
Has anyone who is not present been trying to help or hinder?


Who referred the clients and why?
What are their expectations?
What expectations have they communicated to the family?
Is participation voluntary or mandated?
Who recognized the need for treatment?
What other agencies are or will be involved with the case?


Obtain a clear understanding of the interpersonal context of the problem.
Who is in the family?
Are there other important figures in the life of the problem who aren't present?
Family of origin, immediate family, extended family, family of choice, etc.
Are there other agencies involved? What is their input? Does the family see them as helpful?
Remember that family therapy is an approach to people in context.


Family problems become entrenched because they are embedded in powerful but unseen structure.
What is the family's structure?
What are the subsystems?
What is the nature of Boundaries between the subsystems?
What Triangles are present?


Assess for substance use, IPV, and affairs.
Consider assessment tools if needed.
Be aware of mandated reporting.


General Practitioner
What is your scope of practice?
Specialist
Do you specialize in particular populations? Or problems?
Most family therapists assume their approach can be applied to any problem. Of course their may be exceptions.



The whole is greater than the sum of its parts.
Systems can be viewed in terms of hierarchy, organization, and subsystems.
Systems strive toward self-preservation and therefore its members work in service of the system, as well as themselves.


All behavior makes sense in context.
No one family member is responsible for the family's distress.
Family therapists work to see the big picture.
Even when a client presents with an individual issue (e.g., depression, anxiety), family therapists view it within the larger relational context.


Share the following assumptions:
A person's lived reality is relationally constructed.
Personal identity and individual symptomology are related to the social systems in which they are embedded.
Changing one's language and description of the problem alters how it is experienced.
Truth can be determined only within relational contexts.


Systems theory
Systems metaphor
A family is a system, a group of individuals who coordinate meaning and their understanding of the world.
Social constructionist
Textual metaphor
People narrate their lives to create meaning using the social discourses available to them.


Skeptical of objective reality.
Reality is constructed.
Reality is constructed through language.
Reality is negotiated through relationships.
Shared meanings coordinate social action.


Founded upon the logical-positivist assumptions of an external, knowable truth.
Therapist assumes expert role.
Therapist is an expert who assumes the primary responsibility for identifying problems and goals, often assumes the role of a teacher or mentor.
Theory and research are the primary sources of information for identifying problems and diagnosis.
Therapist uses theory and research to select treatment approaches.


Humans are essentially good.
All people naturally tend toward growth and strive for self-actualization.
Focus on treatment is the subjective, internal world of clients.
Therapeutic interventions target emotions with the goal of promoting catharsis (release of repressed emotions).
A supportive, nurturing environment promoted therapeutic change.
Examples such as Carl Whitaker and Virginia Satir


One cannot communicate; all behavior is a form of communication.
An individual's behavior and symptoms always make sense in context.
All behaviors and symptoms serve a purpose within the system, allowing the system to maintain Homeostasis.
No one individual controls behavior in a system and therefore no one individual can be blamed for problems in the family.
Problematic behavior emerges from the interactions between members of the system.
Therapeutic change involves altering the interaction patterns within the system.


Objective truth can never be fully known because it must always pass through subjective and intersubjective filters.
The human mind does not have access to an outside reality independent of human interpretation.
Knowledge and truth are culturally, historically, and relationally bound.
Personal reality and truth are shaped by language and relationships.
Language affects how identity is shaped and experienced.
The identification of the problem is a social process that occurs through language.
Therapy is a process of co-constructing new realities.


As therapists become more aware of theories, they learn to skillfully integrate ideas from other approaches in a way that is philosophically congruent with their own approach.
However, therapists who are 'eclectic' or 'integrative' in a way that is not grounded in a single philosophical set of assumptions will confuse their clients.
Clients will be confused if each week the client is required to relate differently to the therapist and to assume a different level of participation (i.e., sending contradictory messages).
If the therapist is able to keep the philosophical assumptions consistent throughout therapy, then the therapist can adapt concepts and techniques from other approaches without sending conflicting messages.


Standard I: Responsibility to Clients
Non-discrimination, informed consent, multiple relationships, reporting, abuse, referrals, non-abandonment, consent to record.
Standard II: Confidentiality
Limits to confidentiality, releases, access to records.
Standard III: Professional Competence and Integrity
Competency, conflicts of interest, records maintenance, harassment, exploitation, gifts, scope of practice, misconduct.
Standard IV: Responsibility to Students and Supervisees
Exploitation, confidentiality
Standard V: Research and Publication
Protection of participants, informed consent, right to withdraw, confidentiality, publication, authorship, plagiarism.
Standard VI: Technology-Assisted Professional Services
Teletherapy, consent, confidentiality, location of services and practice, training
Standard VII: Professional Evaluations
Forensics, testimony, competence, informed consent, avoiding conflicts, child custody, professional opinions
Standard VIII: Financial Arrangements
Disclosure of financial policies, recovery procedures, bartering
Standard IX: Advertising
Professional representation, affiliations, educational credentials, qualifications


National
AAMFT Code of Ethics Research Citations/A/@AAMFTCodeofEthics2015
Local
State regulatory board, laws and codes
When in doubt, consult!


Reviews of psychotherapy outcome research document the empirical evidence supporting the effectiveness of psychotherapy.
Wide range of presenting problems.
Diverse therapeutic approaches
Therapeutic is effective. Treated families fare better than untreated.
We need to evaluate the evidence t - What is the typee of evidence? - Targeting what outcomess? - For whom?
Technical/model factors
“Influential Figures in CFT History.pdf” could not be found.
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Family Theory I (8874)/Lecture/1. Introduction.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 2. Strategic Family Therapy
item.description:
Strategic grew out of Gregory Bateson's project on Schizophrenia at the Mental Research Institute (MRI).
The initial emphasis was on observation and research on families, but due to the influence of Milton Erikson's work, intervention strategies were also formulated.


Believed in using the resources of his clients and designing a 'strategy for each specific problem'
He did not care about perspective (insight) as long as their actions produced beneficial results.
Conducted therapy by paying extreme attention to details of the symptoms his clients presented.
In therapy:
Accepted and emphasized positive
Used indirect and ambiguously worded directives
Directed routine behaviors so that the resistance is shown through change and not through normal continuous actions.


The MRI Pioneers:
Don Jackson
Gregory Bateson (As a consultant)
Virginia Satir
John Weakland
Jay Haley
Paul Watzlawick
Richard Fisch
Jules Riskin


Strategic Therapy is any type of therapy where the therapist initiates what happens during therapy and designs a particular approach for each problem.
Strategic therapy isn't a particular approach or theory, but a name for the types of therapy where the therapist takes responsibility for directly influencing people.


Families often perpetuate problems by their own actions.
Directives tailored to the needs of a particular family can sometimes bring about sudden and decisive change.
The exchange of multilayered messages between family members define their relationships.
Interrupting vicious cycles that occur when attempts to solve problems only make them worse.
People are always communicating.
All behavior is communicative.
One cannot not communicate.
All messages have report and command functions
Report = Content = information = (What is said)
Command = Process = underlying relationship = How it is said
If no one registers a complaint, there is no problem.
Patterns (e.g., quiet detachment, volatile engagement) may be dysfunctional for some families and adaptive for others.
The approach is non-normative and complaint-based.


Focuses on identifying and interrupting 'ironic processes' which occur when repeated attempts to solve a problem keep the problem going or make it worse.
The aim of therapy is simply to resolve the presenting complaint as quickly and efficiently as possible, so clients can get on with life
BSCT makes no attempt to specify what constitutes a functional or dysfunctional family relationship.
The therapist attends to what clients do, as well as how, they view the problem, themselves, and each other.
Often see family members individually in the context of family therapy, even when the focus of the intervention is a relational complaint.
The model is called 'Strategic' because the therapist intervenes to interrupt ironic processes deliberately, on the basis of a case-specific plan that sometimes includes counter-intuitive suggestions
Go slow
Engage in behavior they want to eliminate
What matters is the extent to which interaction patterns based on attempted solutions keep a complaint going or make it worse.
The problems clients bring to therapy persist only if they are maintained by ongoing current behavior of the family.
If problem-maintaining behavior is appropriately changed or eliminated, the problem will be resolved or vanish, regardless of its nature, origin, or duration.
How a problem persists is much more relevant to therapy than how the problem originated.
The persistence of the problem depends mainly on social interaction.
The behavior of one member of the family is stimulated and shaped by the response of the others.
How a family goes about trying to solve a problem usually plays a crucial role in perpetuating it.
Well-intentioned yet ironic solutions break the vicious cycle (Positive Feedback loops) that maintain an impasse.


Families are stuck in a spiraling Positive Feedback loop.
They make common-sense but ineffective attempts to change responses.
For example:
When a younger sibling arrives, the older sibling, feeling unloved, starts screaming for attention. The parent punishes him which reinforces his feelings of being unloved, and he continues to throw tantrums.


Family Rules:
The rules or regularities of family interaction that operate to preserve family stability.
Homeostasis:
The conservative aspect of family systems (similar to Cybernetics concept of Negative Feedback)
Circular Causality
Feedback Loops
First-Order Change
Second-Order Change
Hierarchical Structure
Prescribing Ordeals


Rules are typically unspoken, and govern most behavior
When tules promote rigid attempted solutions, it isn't just the behavior but the rule needs to change.
When a specific behavior within a system changes (First-Order Change)
When the rules of the system change (Second-Order Change)
Rules are changed through reframes.


Centerpiece of the model
Families encounter many difficulties over the course of their lives, whether a difficulty becomes a problem depends on how fmaily members respond to it.
Families often make misguided attempts to solve their difficulties and, on finding that the problem persists, apply more of the same attempted solutions. This produces an escalation of the problem, which provokes more of the same, in a vicious cycle.
What often needs to happen? Reverse the solution!


Paradoxical Injunction:
A technique used in Strategic Family Therapy whereby the therapist directs family members to continue their symptomatic behavior. If they conform, they admit control and expose secondary gain; if they rebel, they give up their symptoms. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Not to point out that an individual is fighting going under, but instead tell the individual to keep their eyes open until they become unbearably heavy.
Reframing:
Changing the interpretation.


Identify Feedback Loop s that maintain problems.
Determine the rules that support those interactions.
Find a way to change the rules in order to interrupt problem-maintaining behavior.


Do not regard any particular way of functioning, relating, or living as a problem if the client is not expressing content with it.
How problems develop:
Cybernetic:
Difficulties turn into chronic problems by misguided solutions, forming Positive Feedback escalations.
Structural:
Problems are the result of incongruous hierarchies.
Functional:
Problems result when people try to protect or control one another covertly, so that their symptoms serve a function for the system.


Once the presenting problem is resolved, therapy is concluded.
If a family didn't ask for help with other issues, they aren't targeted.
The job is simply to get the family moving again.
Help families define clear and reasonable goals so that everyone knows when treatment has been successful.
In pushing family members to set concrete goals, they are forced to clarify vague dissatisfactions.
The primary goal is behavior change.


Alter specific patterns of communication that maintain problems.
Mental Research Institute (MRI):
The way to resolve problems is to reverse the misguided solutions that have been maintaining them.
Jay Haley:
Changes in behavior alter perceptions (rather than the other way around)
Milan:
Get families to see things differently (through reframing or positive connotation), rather than in getting family members to behave differently.


Define a resolvable complaint.
Obtain a very specific behavioral picture of the complaint.
Who sees it as a problem?
Why is it a problem now?
"What is the problem that brings you here today?" is too vague.
Inquire about exactly what these complaints mean.
Identify attempted solutions that maintain the complaint.
Once the problem had been defined, the therapist tries to determine who has tried to solve it and how.
The solution is part of the problem.
Prescribe some alternative behavior!
The key is to stop the performance of the problem-maintaining solution.
MRI Approach:
Introduction to the treatment setup
Inquiry and definition of the problem
Estimation of the behavior maintaining the problem
Setting goals for treatment
Selecting and making behavioral interventions
Termination
Attempted solutions:
The solution is deny that a problem exists; action is necessary but not taken. For instance, parents do nothing necessary despite the growing evidence that their teenage son is using drugs.
The solution is an effort to solve something that isn't really a problem; action is taken when it shouldn't be. For example, parents punish a child for masturbating.
The solution is an effort to solve a problem within a framework that makes a solution impossible; action is taken but at the wrong level. For instance, a husband buys gifts for his wife when what she wants is affection.
Solutions that perpetuate problems fall into three categories:
When clients deny that a problem exists (example: anorexia) ACT
When clients try to solve something that really isn't a problem (example: punishing a child for masturbating) STOP ACTING
When clients try to solve a problem within a framework that make a solution impossible (example: husband buys gifts for his wife, rather than giving her the affection she desires) DIFFERENT ACTIONS
Understand the clients' unique language for describing the problem.


To interrupt problem-maintaining sequences, therapists may try to do something that runs counter to common sense.
Paradoxical interventions:
The therapist directs the family members to continue their symptomatic behavior. If they conform, they admit control and expose secondary gain. If they rebel, they give up their symptom(s).
Most common symptom prescriptions where the family is told to continue or embellish the behavior they complain about.
Hope is that the family will comply and then be forced to reverse their attempted solution.
May also hope the client rebels against the therapist's advice.
Restraining technique:
Warning clients against changing to fast and relapse; reinforced the therapist's one-down position.


The family is told to continue or embellish the behavior they complain about.
Sometimes the therapist prescribes the symptom while secretly hoping the clients will rebel against the directive.
As soon as a family member is overwhelmed, they are instructed to make a list of all the things that they might do to sabotage their life. Doing so can take the rebellion out of self-destructive behavior, thus making it less appealing and less impulsive.


Asking a couple to deliberately have an argument during the week in order to help the therapist understand how they get involved in such no-win encounters and how they are able to get each other to act unreasonably.
Discouraging families from trying to change too fast, warning them to go slow and worrying out loud about the possibility of relapse when improvements do occur.
Perhaps you should continue to wake Ricky up for school, after all, you don't want to push him to be too responsible too soon.
The main thing is to discover what families are doing to perpetuate the problem and then get them to do something different.


Co-founded the Family Therapy Institute of Washington D.C. (1974)
Hayley learned from:
Milton Erikson
Gregory Bateson
Salvador Minuchin
He adopted and modified Milton Erikson 's individual emphasis to work with families.
Concerned with the function a symptom served.
Examined rules and structure of a family (influenced by Salvador Minuchin).
Hayley was particularly concerned with power struggles, and often prescribed the symptom such that the cost of keeping it up outweighed the gains.
Madanes was concerned with incongruence hierarchies, where a child uses symptoms to change the behavior of the parent.


Family Life:
Over and covert rules families use to govern themselves
Family Homeostasis:
Tendency of the family to remain in its same pattern of functioning unless challenged to do otherwise.
Quid Pro Quo:
The responsiveness of family members to treating others in the way they are treated.
Redundancy Principle:
Fact that a family interacts within a limited range of repetitive behavioral sequences.
Punctuation:
Idea that people in a transaction believe what they say is caused by what others say.
Symmetrical Relationship s:
Relationships within a family are both among equals (symmetrical) and unequals (complementary).
Circular Causality:
Idea that one event does not 'cause' another but that events are interconnected and there are multiple factors behind a behavior.


To resolve, remove, or ameliorate the problem the family agreed to work on.
Behavioral, concerned with the immediate problem, and anti-insight.
Structural re-organization of the family, like the structural therapies, but with sub-goals to deal with the presenting problem.
Process, not content-focused.
Emphasize short term treatment (10 sessions)


Define a problem clearly
Investigating all solutions that have previously been tried
Defining a clear and concrete change to be achieved
Formulating and implementing a strategy for change


Therapists must be innovative
Therapy must be customizable to families (technique driven)
If families are going to change, alterations in ways their members act must precede new perceptions or feelings
Focus on interpersonal payoff of psychiatric symptoms


Social Stage:
Introduction and setup
Help everyone relax, greet each family member, make sure everyone is comfortable.
Problem Stage:
Definition of the problem in clear behavioral terms
Ask each individual for their perspective, speak to the less involved parent/partner first to get their involvement, listen carefully to the way each family member describes the problem, make sure no one interrupts until each has a turn, make observations.
Emphasize the use of directives.
If therapy is to end well, it must begin proper.
Interaction Stage:
Estimation of the behaviors maintaining the problem
Encourage family members to discuss their points of view among themselves, observe rather than just hearing about the interchanges that surround the problem, look for coalitions between family members against others, how functional is the hierarchy and do family members work together as a team or undercut one another?
Goal Setting Stage
Providing directives
Give the family a task, directives


Offering a different perspective/framework to understand problem behavior.
"The use of language to give a new meaning to a situation."
For instance, a child's misbehavior can be reframed as his way of asking for attention, not an indication of disrespect.
Reframes can be offered by asking circular questions:
"Who makes you depressed?"
"What does dad do when you and mom are fighting?"
Changing the frame of reference for understanding behavior leads to change in the rules governing interactions which in turn leads to sustainable change.


Where a symptom is often seen as a metaphor for an underlying problem.
Example:
A school problem in a child may mirror a work problem in a parent.
Mandanes talked about how one relationship may metaphorically replicate another and power struggles in couples (money, education, control of children, etc.)


Negotiation (pg. 90)
Quid Pro Quo (pg. 91)
Pretend techniques (pg. 91)
Ordeals (pg. 91)


Hayley believed that telling people what they're doing wrong only mobilizes resistance.
Changes in behavior alter perceptions.
Milan group was interested in getting families to see things differently through (reframe) positive connotation.
Which then gets family members to behave differently.
Shift from behavior to cognition set stage for constructivist/narrative movements.


Families should have clear generational boundaries.
Therapists should be 'neutral' and not have expectations for families.
Therapy helps the family by simply examining the family, asking questions to help them examine their own family structure, and exposing games after which they can redesign their family into a better structure on their own.
Mara Selvini Palazzoli
Gianfranco Cecchin


Presession:
Generate initial hypothesis of presenting problem.
Session:
Validate, modify, and change the hypothesis.
Intersession:
Team discussion of hypothesis and arrival at an intervention.
Intervention:
Delivery of the intervention to the family.
Postsession:
Team discussion to analyze the family's reactions and to plan for next session.
Highly scripted. Families treated by co-therapists and observed by other members of the team.


Positive Connotations
Must include the entire family system and confirm the behavior of all family members as maintaining the stability and cohesion of the group.
Rituals:
Engage families in a series of actions that ran counter to or exaggerated rigid family rules.


Define the complaint in specific behavioral terms.
Set minimum goals for change.
Investigate solutions to the complaints.
Concentrate on the 'less of the same.'
Understand clients' preferred views.
Use these views to suggest 'less of the same'
Nurture and solidify initial change.


Frequency of sessions intended to maximize the likelihood that change will be durable.
Typically patter of brief (e.g., weekly, tapering off)
Therapy ends when the treatment goals have been attained (and change seems reasonably stably?)
Co-therapists work as a team (e.g., observing behind the mirror, leaving the room to consult)
Late in session, the therapist may leave so the team can help the therapist plan a homework assignment or framing intervention.


The essential role of the therapist is to persuade the family to 'do less of the same' solution that keeps the complaint going.
Treatment is likely to go awry if the therapist is not in control of it.
Good strategic therapists rarely exert control directly in the sense of offering authoritative prescriptions or assuming the role of an expert.
Taking a 'one down position' and a stance of empathetic curiosity.
I'm a little slow on the uptake here, so could you help me understand again what it is you do when he raises his voice that way?
I don't know if doing this when he walks through the door will make much of a difference, but if you could try it once or twice this week, at least we'll have an idea what we're up against.
Emapthetic restraint (e.g., go slow) is used to neutralize apprehension and resistance to change.
When clients fail to follow a suggestion, a common response is for the therapist to take the blame (e.g., I think I suggested that prematurely) and seek alternative routes to the same strategic objective.
While the model does not emphasize the importance of the therapeutic relationship, this does not mean that strategic therapists come across as cold, manipulative, or uncaring. On the contrary, many receive high ratings on rapport and alliance.


Define a resolvable complaint.
Identify solution patterns (problem-solution loops) that maintain the complaint.
Understand clients' unique language and preferred views of the problem, themselves and each other.

The first two goals provide a template for where to intervene and the third goal is relevant to how to intervene.


Gather a specific behavioral picture of the complaint
Who is doing what?
If I had a video of this, what would I see?
Assess who sees the complaint as a problem and why it is a problem now?
Determine a minimum change goal
What would you be doing, or the two/three/four of you be doing differently that will let you know this problem is taking a turn for the better.
Inquire into behaviors that are closely related to the problem:
What has the family is done to handle, prevent, or resolve the complaint?
What happens after these attempted solutions?
Develop a picture of what 'less of the same' will look like:
What behavior, by whom, in what situation, will suffice to reverse the problem-maintaining solution?


The key element to stopping the performance of the attempted solution, so as not to perpetuate 'more of the same' problem-maintaining solution.
The final assessment goal is grasping the clients' unique views. This is crucial to the later task of framing suggestions:
How do they see themselves and want to be seen by others?
What do they hold near and dear?
When are they at their best, and what do others notice about those times?
What is their best guess about why a particular problem is happening - and why they handle it the way they do?
Whose idea was it to come? Why now?
Who is most optimistic that therapy will help?


How will you know the situation is improving?
What kinds of change will you settle for?
What will need to happen (or not to happen) to let you know that, even if you are not out of the woods entirely, you're at least on the right path?
What will each of you settle for?


Therapeutic restraint:
Telling clients to 'go slow'
Cautioning them about the dangers of improvement
Giving insturctions about how to make the problem worse
Go slow is used to prepare clients for change, to convey acceptance of reluctance to change, and to solidify change once it begins to occur.
Asking the family to collaborate in performing the problem patterns (e.g., an argument) deliberately.
Identify problem-solution feedback loops:
Demand-Refuse
Discuss-Acoid
Criticize-Defend
Accuse-Deny
Encourage the family to do less of the same:
When members felt the need to talk about their relationship, they would first go bowling.
Reframing:
For a small set of family complaints, the goal is to help families reevaluate their problem as 'no problem,' or as a problem they can live with.
Acknowledging (Reinforcing):
When a small change occurs, the therapist acknowledges and emphasizes the clients' part in making it happen, but avoids encouraging further change directly.
Predicting or Prescribing:
Exploring the dangers of movement.
Therapeutic restraint / going slow
Prescribing the symptom / performing the problem / predicting
Jamming / experiment
Reframing
Less of the same
Acknowledge / reinforce


Critics sometimes regard strategic therapy as 'manipulative' because the therapist does not usually make the rationale for particular interventions explicit to clients.
The therapist may say things that they do not truly believe to achieve an effective framing.
Proponents counter that responsible therapy is inherently manipulative and that therapeutic candor can be disrespectful. Good therapy shows profound respect for clients' subjective experiences.
Critics suggest strategic therapists may ignore problems such as intimate-partner violence or substance abuse, if clients do not perceive or present them as overt complaints in session.
The model does not attempt at helping families with personal growth or solving underlying emotional issues.


The central curative factor is interruption of 'ironic processes' which depends on:
Accurate identification of the particular solution efforts that maintain or exacerbate the problem.
Specifying what less of those same solution behaviors might look like.
Designing one intervention that will persuade at least one of the people involved to do less or the opposite of what they have been doing.


Applicable to any family that presents with a clear complaint.
Particularly relevant for families that seem resistance to change.
Most qualitative research (case reports) and follow-up quantitative data.


Historically, most of the research on the effectiveness of Strategic Therapy wasn't very rigorous.
Mostly case report format.
Anecdotal support for its efficacy, although people tend not to write about their failed cases.
Case reports with Anorexia Nervosa, Schizophrenia, and delinquency (pg. 96)
Brief Strategic Family Therapy for adolescent substance abuse and behavior problems
Treatment engagement, family functioning


Focuses on the process of communication rather than its content.
Clever, prescriptive, expedient
Critiqued as manipulative


Therapist is responsible for the outcome of therapy.
Families are stuck in well-intentioned but ineffective attempts to solve problems.
Paradoxical Injunction:
To shake the status quo of the system
Circular questioning and team supervision from the Milan group.
Team approaches to therapy


As a treatment for families, strategic differs from most other approaches in that the therapist is willing, and sometimes prefers, to see family members (particularly partners) individually.
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Family Theory I (8874)/Lecture/2. Strategic Family Therapy.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 3. Structural Family Therapy
item.description:
Salvador Minuchin (1921-2017)
Physician in the Israeli army
Trained in psychoanalysis in the US
Studied interpersonal psychiatry with Harry Stack Sullivan
Worked with delinquent boys at the Wiltwyck School - where foundation for family therapy was laid.
Director of the Philadelphia Child Guidance clinic
Why did Minuchin go into family therapy?
He sees families in terms of particular shapes, particular stages
He sees himself as an instrument, a challenger of patterns


Family is depicted as a system that is comprised of Subsystems
A family is functional to the degree that it nurtures its members to negotiate well the demands of the outside world.
Boundaries set limits distinguishing subsystems from one another in varying permeability (from diffuse to rigid).
Subsystems separated by a diffuse boundary are enmeshed, whereas subsystems separated by a rigid boundary are disengaged.


Family
Structure
Structure is expressed through transactional patterns such as:
Hierarchy
Power
Alliances
Subsystem (couple, parent, sibling)
Boundaries
Coalition
Patterns
Triangles
Loyalties


The family could have developed a structure different from the dysfunctional one now being displayed.
The family processes adaptive resources in its relational repertoire that currently lie dormant.
Therapy attempts to activate what is already there, but latent.


Offers a framework that brings order and meaning to family transactions.
The consistent patterns of family behavior reveal family structure.
The emotional boundaries and coalitions that make up a family's structure are abstractions.
The concept of family structure enables therapists to intervene in a systematic and organized way.
Families seek help for a specific problem.
Family therapists look beyond the specifics of those problems to the family's attempts to solve them.
Exploring dynamics of interaction.
Recognizing the overall organization of the family regulates those interactions.
The model attends to subsystems and boundaries that regular contact between members.
The model emphasizes enactments wherein family members are encouraged to deal directly with one another in session, permitting the therapist to observe and modify their interactions.
Structural family therapy provides therapists with a blueprint for how to view patterns of family dynamics.
The three major concepts of structural family therapy are Structure, Boundaries, and Subsystems.
Subsystem (Couple; Parent; Sibling)


Problems are symptomatic of the family's inability to be flexible and accommodating of changing needs.
All family behavior, even destructive behavior, has the goal of balancing the system to ensure its survival.
Family problems do not result from stresses in the system but from the effects of reactions and responses to the stresses.


Structure is:
The way a family is organized into subsystems whose interactions are regulated by interpersonal boundaries.
The organized pattern in which families interact
Patterns are formed based on rules that are implicit or explicit.
Over time, as patterns develop, roles for family members are established.
Patterns are isomorphic (i.e., interaction patterns are repeated in different relationships in a system).
The focus of treatment is on changing the family structure rather than changing individual family members.
The process of family interaction is like the patterns of conversation at the dinner table. The structure of the family is where family members sit in relation to one another.
As family transactions are repeated, they foster expectations that establish enduring patterns.
Family structure is reinforced by the expectations that establish rules in a family.


Families are differentiated into subsystems based on generation, gender, or function.
Adults are the 'organizational leaders' of the family system so whatever is present in the adult subsystem relationship will be felt throughout the whole system.
Children are common 'symptom bearers'
Organization is most healthy when there are 3 clearly defined systems:
Marital/Couple
Parental
Child/Sibling


Each subsystem is demarcated by interpersonal boundaries.
Boundaries range from rigid to diffuse.
Defined as rules for managing physical and psychological distance between family members and for defining regulation of closeness, hierarchy, and family roles.


Rigid boundaries are restrictive and permit little contact with outside subsystems, resulting in disengagement.
Disengaged systems are independent, but isolated.
On the plus side, this fosters autonomy.
But limits affection and support.


Diffuse boundaries result in enmeshment.
Enmeshed systems offer closeness, but at the expense of independence.
Too much closeness can cripple initiative.


Determines who (or which subsystem) has power in the system.
Any structure in a family is not static, it is developed over time.
Hierarchies can be rigid and unfair or weak and ineffective.
Be aware of cross-generational coalitions.


Accommodation requires the family system to be flexible and alert to changing needs of individuals in the family.
Boundary making refers to the demarcation of subsystems as they are formed.


In accommodating to each other, a couple must establish a boundary between them, as well as a boundary separating them from the outside.
The addition of children transform the structure of a family into a parental subsystem and child subsystem.
Even in healthy families, children often bring stress and conflict. Children require different styles of parenting at different ages.
Minuchin warned therapists not to mistake growing pains for pathology.
What distinguishes healthy families isn't the absence of problems, but a functional structure for dealing with them.

"The problem behavior is a symptom of the dysfunctional structure of the family system."

Disengaged or enmeshed subsystems
Hierarchies are weak and ineffective; or rigid & arbitrary
Conflict avoidance
Detouring which results in a scapegoat
Cross-generational coalition (where hierarchy may be inverted)

Modifications in structure are required when a family or one of its members encounters external pressure (a parent is laid off) or a developmental transition occurs (e.g., parents retire).
Healthy families accommodate to their changed circumstances, dysfunctional families increase the rigidity of structures that no longer work (e.g., strict parenting tightening up further when a child acts out and needs nurturance).
Families are susceptible to develop a dysfunctional structure during periods of:
Normative life cycle transition
The arrival of a first child
An adult child leaving home
An acute stressor
Natural Disaster
Unemployment


Single Adult
Coupling
Having Children
Families with Young Children
Families with School-Age Children
Families with Adolescents
Divorce
Blended Families
Launching Children
Later Life


Early on the model shifted from why family members interact the way they do, and the past, to how they learned to act that way.
Now, the model considers not only how family members interact, but also how and why they learned to do so.
All behavior makes sense in context.
The mechanism of change is the production of new relational experiences for families.
Families change each other by behaving differently toward each other.
Enactment refers to those moments in therapy when family members interact directly with each other.
Enactment is not necessarily a technique. It typically occurs naturally in session. It is the 'here-and-now' of the therapy session.


Alter the organization of a family so that its members can solve their own problems.
The goal is structural change; problem-solving is a by-product.
Problems are embedded in dysfunctional structures.
Activate adaptive patterns that are already in families repertoires.
Create effective hierarchy:
Parents should be in charge, not relate to their children as equals.
Differentiate individuals and subsystems by strengthening the boundaries around them.
Increase contact by making boundaries more permeable.


The therapist produces change by joining the family, probing for areas of flexibility, and then activating formant structural alternatives.
Joining conveys acceptance of family members and respect for their ways of doing things.
Only after joining can the therapist attempt restructuring.
Understand the family's view of their problems by tracking their perspectives (words they use to explain problems and the behavior with which they demonstrate them).
Enactment s reveal structural patterns and later change them.
Take-Away:
Observe and modify the structure of family transactions in the immediate context of the session.


The therapist manages the nuts-and-bolts details of how the therapy process is structured including:
Who should attend
How often
Referrals for psychiatric evaluation
Therapy aims to change how family members experience each other.
Family members are expected to be present together for sessions.
Relational experiences can 'wash out' between sessions, therefore, therapy usually starts out weekly.


Join the family accommodate to its members' style (building alliance)
Map the family structure, boundaries, and hierarchy (evaluating and assessing structure)
Intervene to transform the structure to diminish symptoms (addressing the problems identified in the assessment)


Observe and assess how family members respond to their dilemmas.
Because problems are a function of the entire family structure, it's important to include the whole group for assessment.
Some problems may be treated individually.
Problems can persist in individuals, in the social context, or the feedback between them.
Individual problems need to be identified and appropriate.
Structural therapists prefer to begin therapy with the entire family, but they do not insist on it.
Once the family has been assessed, the therapist often meets with specific subsystems and individuals to achieve structured goals.


Role of the symptoms in the family
Subsystems
Cross-Generational Coalition
Boundaries
Hierarchy
Complementarity
Family Life Cycle
Strengths


Ask questions about the presenting problem until family members begin to see that the problem goes beyond the symptom bearer to include the entire family.
Assist family members in seeing how their interactions may be perpetuating the presenting problem.
Briefly explore the past, focusing on how the adults in the family came to develop the perspectives that influence their interactions.
Explore options that family members might take to interact in more productive ways to create a shift in the family structure and help resolve the presenting problem.



Greet the family
Ask for each person's view of the problem
Listen carefully
Acknowledge what you hear
Model empathy that family members are temporarily not able to provide
Acknowledgement (feeling heard and understood) releases family members from resentment
Joining opens the way for family members to begin listening to one another and establishes a bond with the therapist that enables them to accept the challenges to come.
Intervention Language:
Joined with the Family
Engaged in Reflective Listening
Built Rapport
Acknowledged
Reflected
Summarized
Validated
Elicited
Emphasized
Challenged
Reinforced
Maintain an outsider perspective to remain objective, while becoming familiar with family's experiential reality.
Unless therapist is allowed to become part of the new system, no change will take place.
Respect the family, and its individual members, despite presenting problem (i.e., abuse)
The therapist joins the system in the sense that they accommodate to its style; how people talk, what words they use, how they walk, and so forth.
Make contact with each member of the family
Greeting, shaking hands (pre-COVID)
Using names
Noticing something unique about each of the members
Find something similar about each person and then allow the family members to recognize the similarity


Skills involved in joining:
Accommodating:
Matching the family's style of language with gestures or subject matter (being 'familiar' to the family)
Being interested in the family's interests (i.e., baseball).
Validating:
Validate the worth of each family member.
Searching for Competencies:
Therapist enhances self-esteem by discovering and validating competencies.


During joining, assess the Family Structure:
Hierarchy
Who has the most power?
The position members take in relation to each other (emotional closeness between members).
Boundaries between Subsystem


Assume authority for the structure of therapy.
Maintain control so things do not go awry.
Lead by following.
Be able to interrupt.
Make demands, rather than polite, requests.
Inviting the family to schedule the next session.
Validating ambivalence about coming again.


Need to expand family's view of problem to include all family members.
Therapist is less concerned with the content of the message than with how it is transmitted, to whom, and with what effect.
Process messages usually describe the power structure of the family, Hierarchy, Boundaries, emotional tone, and Family Rules.
Attending to process = accommodation when the therapist responds to the underlying affect in the manner in which the statement is made.
Process comments are better when kept general.


The therapist notices a problematic sequence (a hunch).
The therapist initiates an enactment (talk this over with your partner).
The therapist guides the family to modify the enactment (offering encouragement as needed).

Enmeshment
Watch for interruptions, speaking for one another, doing things for one another that they can do for themselves, arguing.
Disengagement
Watch for passivity, absence of emotion, absence of conflict, ignoring, lack of concern for other's interests.
When the enactment breaks down:
Comment on what went wrong.
Push them to keep going.


Assess interactions in session.
Families tend to quickly induct therapists in their culture.
Take into account both the problem the family presents and the structural dynamics it displays.


Once families begin to interact, problematic transactions emerge.
Recognizing structure requires focusing on process, not content.
Achieve intensity by selective regulation of affect, repetition, and duration. Tone, volume, pacing, and choice of words can be used to raise the affective intensity of interventions.
Pay attention to Coalitions
Temper tantrums are maintained by parents who give in. They try not to give in; they just don't try long enough.
Empathy:
Use empathy to go beneath defensiveness.
Interrupt squabbling and using empathy talk with each family member at a time about what they're feeling.
Shaping Competence:
A particular method of modifying interaction, reinforcing positives, reinforcing use of functional alternatives already in the family's repertoire.


Invite family members to speak for themselves.
Block interruptions.
Assist dyads in finishing conversations without intrusion.
Although structural family therapy begins with the whole family, subsequent sessions may be held with individuals or subgroups to strengthen boundaries.
Asking family members to change seats.
Asking family members to move seats further apart or closer together or turn toward one another.
Having separate sessions with individuals or subsystems to strengthen boundaries.
Asking one or more members to remain silent during an interaction.
Asking questions that highlight a problem boundary area (e.g., do you always answer for your son when he is asked a question?)
Blocking interruptions or encouraging pauses to enable less dominant persons to speak.


The goal in unbalancing is to change the relationship within the subsystem.
The therapist joins and supports one individual or subsystem.
While taking sides seems like a violation of neutrality, this is done to unbalance and realign the system (note that fairness is achieved because the therapist sides with family members in turn).
Tools/Techniques:
Reframing
Complementarity
Intensity
Enactment


The therapist sometimes challenges the way clients see things.
Act as a teacher, offering information and advice, often about structural matters.
Stroke and a Kick:
To mother, "You are very helpful." (Stroke)
To daughter, "Mommy sometimes takes away your voice. Can you speak for yourself?" (Kick)


After the family's view of the problem has been enlarged by process comments and family is familiar with therapeutic process.
Therapist can present the family with a different perspective of the problem that allows them to activate new behaviors (in a new situation)
To formulate a reframe the therapist brings together the verbal and nonverbal messages.
Should take into account every member.
Should like the family problem with the rules of the structure.
Should not be explained to the family.
As family members describe their problems, therapists reflect on their understanding systemic reframing, which takes into account all behavior as reciprocal.
Use family's language.
Use family's content.
Include everyone.
Ensure the reframe has a nonjudgemental, non-blaming focus, and better still, has positive connotations.
Be prepared to restate the reframe in several different ways.
Avoid intrapsychic interpretations and why-because aspects in forming the reframe.
Realize that there is no perfect reframe.


Structural mapping is used as an assessment tool for understanding interaction patterns.


Blocking:
Stopping usual transactions.
Exaggerating:
Encouraging or sustaining interactions.
Silence:
When a response is expected, doing the unusual by not giving one - thus demanding the family to act.
All unbalancing, if successful, will heighten tension and intensity to fuel family to move toward change.
Actively shift the focus of the family from solving the presenting problem to changing the family structure. The therapist must unbalance the family's old patterns.


The model directs therapists to look beyond the content of problems and even beyond the dynamics of interaction to the underlying family organization that supports and contains those interactions.
The most important tenet in that every family has a structure, and this structure is revealed only when the family is in action.


Strongest empirical support comes from a series of studies on children with psychosomatic symptoms and young adults addicted to drugs.
Early structural family therapy studies demonstrated effectiveness in treating disruptive behavior and adolescent substance use.
More recent, studies have shown that structural family therapy can be effective when addressing problem behavior spanning the externalizing spectrum (e.g., disruptive behavior, adolescent substance use, conduct disorder, ADHD)


Treatment is concerned only with the relief of the family's suffering.
Interventions are limited to relief of suffering, thus treatment may be brief (<6 sessions)


Therapist must be more flexible than the family.
Focused on change not insight (how not why of dysfunction).
Therapist should be in charge of all communications and coordination with collaborators.


The self of the therapist is one of the primary tools for facilitating change.
Therapists must use themselves to relate to the family, varying from being highly involved to professionally detached (depending on the family's needs).
Salvador Minuchin encouraged new therapists to reflect on aspects of their personal and relational lives that shape their therapeutic process and client behavior in session.


Describe 'who you are' as a therapist.
How will 'who you are' as a therapist impact therapy with families?
What are your personal strengths? What are your growth areas?


Strongest empirical support comes from a series of studies on children with psychosomatic symptoms and young adults addicted to drugs.
Early structural family therapy studies demonstrated effectiveness in treating disruptive behavior and adolescent substance use.
More recently, studies have shown that structural family therapy can be effective when addressing problem behavior spanning the externalizing spectrum (e.g., disruptive behavior, adolescent substance use, conduct disorder, ADHD).


Similar to all family therapy approaches, structural family therapy is not effective in all cases.
No research identifies readily observable characteristics shared by failed cases of structural family therapy.
Developed to work with poor urban families, at all socioeconomic levels, ethnic groups, sexual orientations, and across countries.
Indirect empirical support, as research on efficacy has focused on applicability to family treatment.
Studies that directly test structural family therapy's efficacy in the treatment of various presenting problems and targeted populations are needed.


Efficacy 'refers to treatment effects observed in randomized controlled trials.'
Effectiveness 'refers to treatment effects in routine practice.'
Currently, the evidence does not show that any of the demonstrably efficacious approaches to family therapy are more effective than other approaches, largely because there is a dearth of evidence on the efficacy of many widely used family therapy approaches.


Family therapy research has had little impact on the day-to-day practice of family therapists.
The disconnection between research and practice is alarming.
This may be attributed to, 'An overemphasis by researchers.. On treatment packages and therapeutic models/techniques.'
Insufficient attention has been paid to sources of influence on treatment outcomes (the skills of the the therapist themselves)
Effective family therapy requires a good 'fit' between the person of the therapist and their primary theoretical orientation.
Family therapy is shifting to research that addresses the process aspects of the therapeutic models.


It is important to remember there are multiple ways of knowing what works:
Randomized control trials
Case studies data
Observations of therapists and clients
Collecting qualitative or quantitative
Remember:
Research lags behind practice in family therapy.
Just because a model has been tested doesn't inherently mean it is superior.


Heteronormative
Pathologizing (seeing problems are embedded in dysfunctional family structures)
Family mapping implies pathology resides in family structure, but this is not true. Problems are viewed as a failure to adjust to changing circumstances.
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Family Theory I (8874)/Lecture/3. Structural Family Therapy.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 4. Cognitive-Behavioral Family Therapy
item.description:
Engaging and making comfortable
Joining
Creating alliance
Building rapport
Active listening
Open-ended questions
Identifying strengths and why now
Reinforcing positives
Mapping family system/ Genogram
Exploring family dynamics (assessment)
Reflecting
Summarizing
Reframing
Circular questioning
Acknowledge/reinforce


Thoughts and perceptions
Acting or behaving
Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) is a form of psychological treatment that has been demonstrated to be effective for a range of problems including depression, anxiety disorders, alcohol and drug use problems, marital problems, eating disorders, and severe mental illness.
Problems are based in unhelpful thinking and behavior.
Families can learn better ways of coping, which improves symptoms.


Behavior is maintained by its consequences.
Consequences that increase behavior are reinforcers.
Consequences that decrease behavior are punishers.


Behavior is regulated by its consequences.
Responses that are positively reinforced will increase.
Responses that are punished or ignored will be extinguished.
CBT/CBFT is a highly efficacious intervention to assist families in a variety of contexts (this model has empirical support)
CBT has focused on family's cognitive processing and behavioral interactions, while minimizing the influences of individual differences between family members.
CBT also addresses characteristics that each family member brings to their relationships, explaining why family members behave and interpret events in maladaptive ways.


Scarcity of positive outcomes available for each family member.
Deficits in communication and problem solving.
High frequency of negative or punishing exchanges reciprocated by partners, parents, family members.
Family members are more likely to track negative behavior selectively and to make negative attributions for such behavior.
They reciprocate negative behavior with negative behavior.
Primary distress results from unmet fundamental needs create secondary distress (withdrawal or verbally abuse among family members)


Behavior is maintained by its consequences.
Ratio of costs and benefits to behavior (something is maintianing it)
Good relationships are under positive reinforcement ocntrol


CBT recognizes the influence of both the family's behavioral interactions (processes) and the major themes (content) that serve as the basis for relationship discord.


Thoughts change to promote behavioral change (thoughts -> behavior)
Emotions and actions are mediated by cognitions (thoughts -> emotions)
Understand cognition (beliefs, attributions, expectancies) makes it possible to identify triggers to behavioral patterns.
Uncovering hidden/automatic assumptions that keep people stuck.


Overgeneralizations
Magnification and minimization
Personalization
Dichotomous thinking
Labeling and mislabeling
Also called black and white thinking, catastrophizing, defense mechanisms


Help families become more active observers and evaluators of their own automatic thoughts, long-standing assumptions, and of their relationship standards.


Individual family members vary in the extent to which they have a clear understanding of the factors affecting their relationships and clear goals for treatment and how their own contributions affect the achievement of their goals.
Therapist determines the appropriate sequence of addressing goals in therapy.
Extinguish undesired behavior and reinforce positive alternatives.
Ignoring the tantrum; rewarding the child for putting feelings into words
Redefine the family's goals of decreasing negative behavior into increasing positive responses.
Families have difficulty describing the behavior they want to see more of
The therapist helps by asking families to make a list of things the other person did that they liked throughout the week.
Reviewing the list in session the next week provides an opportunity to emphasize the importance of positive feedback.
This agenda of therapy is educational:
Teach communication, problem-solving, and negotiation


Behavior will change when the contingencies of reinforcement are altered.
Identify behavioral goals
Learn techniques to achieve these goals
Facilitate social reinforcement of change


Brief (about 20 weekly sessions)
Use of homework assignments
Phase out therapy gradually.
Once the family shows evidence of substituting positive interactions for negative ones and goals are achieved.
Booster sessions


Collaborate with families in designing homework to complete between sessions.
Homework is based on the learning principle that to replace existing ingrained dysfunctional interactional patterns with new ones, families rehearse the new patterns repeatedly, particularly under 'real life conditions.'


CBFT has been popular in two primary sub-systems:


All couples run into conflict.
Conflict resolution is a critical skill.
Healthy families are not problem free, but they can resolve conflicts when they arise.
They describe their own feelings and request changes in the behavior of others rather than criticizing or complaining.


Good relationships are not made in heaven, they are a product of learning effective coping behavior.
Families need problem solving skills
Therapy includes:
Clinical interview
Rating specific behaviors
Relationship satisfaction questionnaires


Couples are taught to express themselves in clear, behavioral descriptions, rather than in vague complaints.
Couples are taught new behavior exchange procedures, emphasizing positive reinforcement.
Couples are helped to improve their communication.
Couples are encouraged to establish clear and effective decision-making.
Couples are taught strategies to problem-solve future complaints to extend the benefits of therapy.
Ask each partner to list three things they would like the other to do more often.


Imagery
Role-play
Coaching (to switch places, to increase their empathy for one another's feelings)
Communication training
For example:
Engaging in an argument without attacking
'I' statements (Using 'I' Statements.pdf)
Speaker listener exercises (Practice Exercise (Speaker Listener Activity))
Problem-solving training
Homework assignments
Mindfulness and meditation
Sensate focus (p. 164)
In vivo desensitization (p. 164)


Parents ahve control over the rewards and punishment of children.
If parents change the contingencies of reinforcement, the child's behavior will change.
Skills are taught in sequence (shaping)
Help parents define the child's positive and problematic behaviors in specific observable actions.
Tracking target behaviors
Reinforcing desired behavior through contigent encouragement with incentive charts.
Disciplinary tehcniques include Time-Out and ignoring the problem behavior.


Observe/Assess the frequency of problem behavior, what precedes it, and what reinforcement follows (Behavior Chaining)
Shaping (reinforcing small steps toward change)
