item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Minding the Gap not Bridging the Gap: Family Therapy From a Psychoanalytic Perspective
item.description:
Bibliography: Brodie, F., & Wright, J. (2002). Minding the Gap not Bridging the Gap: Family Therapy From a Psychoanalytic Perspective. Journal of Family Therapy, 24(2), 205–221. https://doi.org/10.1111/1467-6427.00212
Type: Journal Article
Title: Minding the Gap not Bridging the Gap: Family Therapy From a Psychoanalytic Perspective,
Author: Brodie, Fiona; Wright, John;
Journal: Journal of Family Therapy,
Volume: 24,
Issue: 2
Pages: 205-221
Year: 2002
DOI: 10.1111/1467-6427.00212
ISSN: 0163-4445, 1467-6427

Following recent interest in this journal in building bridges between a psychoanalytic and systemic approach to family therapy (Vol. 19, 1997), the authors take up the debate. A clinical vignette from a recent article is used for discussion and, in order to describe further work from a psychoanalytic perspective, two case vignettes are presented. The comparisons are discussed with particular reference to the concepts of projective identification, transference/countertransference and internal object relations.


Keywords: Need to Read


“two different models to thinking about families and their interactions: (1) an inside-out model which takes account of the family’s internal phantasy world and how this impinges upon external relationships, and (2) an outside-in model which considers the manner in which family members relate to one another as well as to the external world and how this impinges upon individual family members’ thoughts, awareness and beliefs about each other” (Brodie and Wright, 2002, p. 2)
“Gregory Bateson’s (1972) observation that ‘mind is immanent’ in the larger system. In this sense mental processes are brought about by a total system, or series of interconnections between external relationships. In more recent years this has been developed further by the influence of feminism and postmodernist thinking, which question assumptions of power and authority in authorship inherent in the system” (Brodie and Wright, 2002, p. 2)
“Gergen’s idea of the ‘distributed self” (Brodie and Wright, 2002, p. 2)
“there is no true core self because self is a product of relationships, settings and contexts. This is important for systemic family therapists, since an individual’s sense of self is maintained by ongoing relationships with other members of the family which are non-linear.” (Brodie and Wright, 2002, p. 2)
“This conceptualization is enshrined in circularity in relationships and” (Brodie and Wright, 2002, p. 2)
“the interviewing technique known as ‘circular questioning” (Brodie and Wright, 2002, p. 3)
“Milan school emphasized an attitude of neutrality” (Brodie and Wright, 2002, p. 3)
“being necessary in order to really engage with and understand the system and that this might be considered as similar to Freud’s idea of evenly suspended attention” (Brodie and Wright, 2002, p. 3)
“a psychoanalytic approach emphasizes that whatever the pressures of the external circumstances, the way in which these are engaged with is also significantly influenced by how individual family members function internally (e.g. splitting or integrating).” (Brodie and Wright, 2002, p. 3)
“the family’s tendency to organize itself around the intolerance of pain and adversity, and on the other, to organize itself around the enjoyment and promotion of hope and well-being, whatever the external circumstances” (Brodie and Wright, 2002, p. 3)
“certain modes of thinking and learning can become dominant within families.” (Brodie and Wright, 2002, p. 3)
“These patterns are based on identificatory processes (introjective, projective, adhesive) operating within an internal (psychic) reality.
Consequently, the understanding of family life and emotional nurturance may be seen as broadly organized under three general learning types: (1) those which learn from experience, (2) those relying on more narcissistic mechanisms, and (3) those functioning at a parasitic level. As a consequence of these fundamental differences between kinds of learning, the growth of the personality is either facilitated or opposed, thereby blocking development.” (Brodie and Wright, 2002, p. 3)
“what we observe within the therapeutic encounter is that transference and countertransference are hereand-now processes which actively use the therapist as an object in which to put these unwanted states of mind. The repetition, in this sense, is the re-enactment, in the lived moment of the therapy, of the way the family has related to objects in the past” (Brodie and Wright, 2002, p. 4)
“patterns of relating are not repeated for the sake of it but because the family is unable or unwilling to relate emotionally in a more developmentally complex way.” (Brodie and Wright, 2002, p. 4)
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Family Theory II (HDFS 8875)/Lecture/4. Psychoanalytic Models of Family Therapy/@brodieMindingGapNot2002.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: @byng-hallRewritingFamilyScripts1995
item.description:
"We may feel secure enough to explore if we can predict that support will be readily available if and when it is needed, especially if new ventures run into trouble or if potentially dangerous situations arise. Difficulties that lead to consultations with a family therapist often arise out of conflict within the family's own relationships."
"The family script can provide routines for family life which can be followed almost automatically."
"Repetition becomes the background against which change is the foreground, that which is new becomes the focus of attention. In contrast, chaos obscures potentially significant change, unless the new behavior facilitates consistency, in which case that new patter becomes the foreground, thus becoming the new center of attention."
"Rewriting family scripts follows the sequence of a scripted pattern giving way to some improvisation followed by the establishment of a new pattern."
"Family scripts can be defined as the family's shared expectations of how family roles are to be performed within various contexts."
The term 'expectations' implies anticipation of what is to be said and done within family relationships, as well as family pressures to perform the roles as expected. If one member fails to perform in the prescribed way, another member of the family may be recruited to take up that role instead.
The plot is 'scripted' while the cast can change.
Family scripts are revealed when repeating patterns of family interaction are either observed or described.
Family Scenario:
An encounter of which it can be said that something significant happens within family relationships.
Basic elements of family scenario:
Context
Families engaging with each other around a particular task or situation
Plot
Family members 'motives' become clear as the scenario unfolds
Outcome
The consequences of the encounter are revealed
The expected scenarios for each particular family situation thread together to create an overall script for how all family relationships are expected to be conducted in general.
"Problem Scenarios":
Instead called 'Attempted Solution Scenarios'
This helps us to focus attention on how each person tries to solve the problem.
The behavior that is experienced now as problematic may have started out as an attempted solution to an earlier problem.
The co-constructed story may then become part of the family beliefs about what to expect of itself.


Improvising implies abandoning the set script and extemporizing instead. This may happen when the old script does not fit the current situation, or when those involved are in sear of something different.
The therapist can help to create a new co-constructed scenario by suggesting a goal which the family then achieves in their own way.
Suggest a scenario in which it becomes necessary for the family to improvise. (in two parent families, the parents should devise a strategy together)
Try to block each move that has not worked in the past.
Unraveling some of the origins of the scripted scenarios frees families to explore new pathways. Work on the present and the past can reinforce each other.


Replicated Scripts
Parents with their own individual scenarios from childhood that are repeated
Corrective Scripts
Choice of the opposite style of parenting
Improvised scripts
Corrective scripts repeated over time


The therapist's background also plays a part in shaping scenarios in therapy.


Positive Labeling
Can be given to replicative scrips by labeling them as being loyal to the family of origin.
Corrective scripts can be given a positive frame by pointing out to parents that they are struggling to provide a better experience for their children than their parents were able to provide for them.
Improvised scripts (unlike the historical replicative and corrective scripts) are written in response to current situations. They are improvised either out of necessity or driven by curiosity and a wish to explore new ways of relating.
A stimulus for improvisation is a degree of uncertainty about what to do next so that interaction must be played off the cuff.
Positive comments can be made about how much the family is exploring unknown territory.


Attachment behavior
The behavior of a person seeking proximity to his or her attachment figure in a potentially dangerous situation. (This is a mechanism that protects children - or adults - when vulnerable)
The child uses the parent as a safe base from which to explore, and parent and child stay in contact to ensure that they can get together in the presence of any potential danger.
In terms of script theory a potentially threatening situation evokes tightly scripted behavior in which parent and child predictably got together. Exploration allows for more improvisation.
The therapist can become a temporary attachment figure to the family. The therapist must be aware of the factors that threaten the family's relationship.
Any new behavior of uncertain origin emerging in a relationship (e.g., unexplained impatience) might be seen as either strange and treated as potentially dangerous, or novel and will arouse curiosity.
If it is perceived as strange, attempts may be made to avoid reprovoking the impatience, returning to old familiar ways instead.
If the impatience arouses curiosity, then it will probably lead to trying to discover what it is all about, and to improvise ways of dealing with it.
If it becomes clear that the impatience poses a problem and something has to be done about it, new solutions may be improvised out of the necessity to sort things out.
There are two main forms of improvisation in family relationships:
Improvisation that comes out of necessity (Something has to be done when old solutions are not working)
Improvisation out of curiosity when it feels safe to try something new, even if it is uncertain where it will lead.
A therapist who is trusted by the family can make the risks involved in improvisation feel less frightening, even when family relationships are insecure.
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Family Theory II (HDFS 8875)/Lecture/4. Psychoanalytic Models of Family Therapy/@byng-hallRewritingFamilyScripts1995.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 4. Psychoanalytic Models of Family Therapy
item.description:
Most psychoanalytic models are based on Freud's idea around the identity, ego and super ego, or the development of self. For Freud the drives were sexual (in terms of possession and control), for newer psychoanalytic ideas the drives are more around connection and validation of the self (good or bad).
Object Relations Theory in some ways provides a bridge between psychodynamic theory and systems theory. We relate to people in the present based on expectations formed by early experience.
Normal Development (?)
Early development is based on attachment theory/separation-individuation constructs.
Infant is born ready to be in a reciprocal relationship. This is activated by relating to a parent, by being loved and loving.
Stages of development based on object relations: internal object (mental image of self and other, and self in relation to other).


Objectless (primary narcissism/autistic) there is no other, only self.
The following stages focus on the development of self through relations with internal and external objects: first the actual interactions and then the unconscious residue of the interactions.
As humans, we exist in the context of relationships not as single units: There is no self without an object, there is no object without a self.
Infants develop in a context of concentric 'holding environments.' As infants internalize the guarding, protecting, soothing and nurture of this 'holding environment' they begin to form a self (even if the environment is inadequate).
These early experiences then form our 'unconscious' drives for connection or separation. 'Real' others are 'used' to satisfy those drives, and we find others to validate our sense of self (good or bad).


Health: achieving and preserving psychic wholeness through good object relations, integrating our 'unconscious' with our consciousness.
Self and its relationships with others rest on and are expressed by the degree to which relations between the self and object are gratifying (but some theorists would suggest that since we are so narcissistic in the beginning, the relationships with others are never gratifying enough. Is it possible to be healthy?)


Fairbairn suggest that as we internalize objects we are inevitably disappointed by them, in order to defend against this pain, we do the follow:
We split off those aspects that are too painful to be tolerated.
Repress these intolerable aspects.
This modifies the ego.
Pathology occurs when some aspects of the repressed self-object system are excessively repressed, leaving the central self depleted with an impoverished relationship to the 'ideal object.'
Other forms of pathology occur when the central self system is taken over by one of the usual repressed systems, such as those whose relations are characterized by continual patterns of distance and rage with the apparent disappearance of reality.
Fear-dictated flight from early object relations is also considered the deepest root of psychological problems.


Skynner (1981)
Diffuse boundaries
Unclear identities
Satisfaction from fantasy as opposed to reality
Difficulty coping with separation and loss
Attempts to preserve past states of relationships
Attempts to manipulate others into rigidly held views of them


The major goal of Object Relations Theory is to free family members of unconscious restrictions so that they will be able to interact with one another as whole, healthy persons on the basis of current realities rather than unconscious images.
The encounter between the therapist and client is the intervention. The relationship is the crucible for change and growth.
The therapeutic process is the same as 'normal development' during infancy. The therapist provides the holding environment, contains/introjects the clients' emotions, resolves them, understands them, somehow makes them acceptable, and then the client introjects the resolution of the emotions. Therapist projects back a 'corrective experience.'
Self of therapist is key:
Transference and counter-transference are the keystones of any psychoanalytic therapy, meaning the therapist must constantly be aware of who they are' for the client, and who the client is for them.
Change occurs through insight and working through.
Techniques:
Listening
Empathy
Interpretation and maintaining neutrality with respect to what or how things change


Big Picture (how families operate/develop):
He uses attachment theory as a base. Early attachment relationships create 'working models' of how relationships are supposed to be, they create 'scripts.' as people interact with each other to become a family, they create their own 'family script' based on these early 'working models.' families have attachment patterns that are full of meanings about abandonment, engulfment, intrusion, etc. (i.e., distance regulation)
These scripts provide routines for family life which can be followed automatically. They are shared expectations of how family roles are to be performed within various contexts.
These scripts may be carried out from generation to generation in one form or another. Some use replicative scripts (repeat what has happened in the past), while others use corrective scripts (trying not to repeat scripts from the family of origin). There is a constant tension between these two.
Healthy vs. Dysfunctional families
Healthy families have scripts that provide a set of roles with which each member can identify and which provides room for improvisation when facing new situations. These scripts promote interactional awareness:
Consequences of interaction
Self-awareness (why you are acting in a particular way)
Empathic awareness (why others are acting in particular ways)
Understanding the meaning of the interaction
Shared coherent perception of what is happening


Symptoms occur when there is difficulty updating scripts. They may occur because the script necessary remains someone or something too painful to relive. Intolerable information is blocked or edited both intraphysically and interpersonally (secrets)\
Symptoms may also occur when a family script is used to prevent what members may fear to be an even worse disaster. Even though the current script is painful, it is rigidly clung to (the solution has become to problem)


Major goal is improvisation (flexibility). In order to create an environment safe enough to explore options however, the therapist must provide a secure base from which to explore. Paradoxically, scripts, although repetitive, provide the background against which change can occur.
Attachment notions
Secure
Curious
Improvisation
Uncertainty
Insecure
Avoid strangeness
Stick with the familiar


Instead of conflict in the family arising out of one person's pathology which extends to influence another's behavior, family scripts are encoded in all family members' minds, but each family member plays a particular role. Therefore, each member of the family can be taught to see how their role contributes to the problem, rather than asking the 'sick one' to reown the bad object and working through these issues.


Reduce strategies that undermine problem-solving abilities (i.e., triangulating, scapegoating, etc.)
Reduce strategies that undermine security (threats about leaving, control, etc.)
Move toward collaboration rather than coercion and blame.
Re-edit scripts so the roles are fillable by the individuals in the family.
Move closer to an ideal script in which a wide scope of improvising is possible.
Develop a hopeful script.
Promote ownership of family's success, attributable to them not you as the therapist.


This is still important for the therapist to attend to. The therapist needs to contain the family's emotions in a way so as not to become another player in their script. Therapists own scripts can also be replayed, thus it is essential that the therapist understand their own family script. Byng-Hall outlines methods for staying out of the script and for containing emotional impact:
Staying out:
Use teams, get supervision, have a clear plan, use circular questioning
Containing:
Reflecting on the process, seeing emotions as valuable information, differentiating your script from the family's, share your emotional experience with the family.


Absolves people of responsibility for their behavior (it is my mother's fault)
Lack of empirical testing
Tautological thinking:
Make an interpretation, it is rejected, patient is resistant, you must be onto something.
Perspective is individualist or dyadic without revision.
Deterministic, linear thinking (it is my mother's fault)
Blaming the victim (you put yourself in this situation, because of what your mother did)
Mother blaming
Long process

item.title: 1. Philosophy of Change Framework
item.description:
Parts in interaction such that the whole is greater than the sum of its parts.
University Resources/Couple and Family Therapy/Keywords/Open System (i.e. human systems) exchange matter/energy with the environment (for Family Systems and our purposes this in information)
University Resources/Couple and Family Therapy/Keywords/Open System s have to have monitoring functions that allow them to pay attention to what is important in their environments (i.e. feedback)
If they have monitoring functions then there needs to be increasing complexity of rules about how to handle the feedback, and when to change in order to continue to grow and adapt to both internal and external sources of information (Rule about interaction, rules about changing the rule of interaction, and rules about change rules about changing the rules of interaction, etc.)
All interaction is fed into the system and becomes both input and output, with a constant flow of information to these monitoring functions, with decisions made to either assimilate or accommodate.
Systems are goal directed, and purposeful using both negative (deviation dampening) and positive (deviation amplifying) feedback.


System Complexity:
An increase in the autonomy of the component parts and an increase in the extent to which the system or its parts determines system behavior (parts of not simply reactive to input from the environment).
Requisite Variety:
A wide range and quantity of varied information, experience and input into the system that is somehow stored for future use.
Morphostasis:
As the system assesses information from internal and external interactions it may 'choose' to maintain itself in the same way, however because of the new information it has to change in some way to stay the same (assimilation).
University Resources/Couple and Family Therapy/Keywords/Morphogenesis:
As the system assesses information from internal and external interactions it may 'choose' to change in order to accommodate to the new information.
These processes are simultaneous and constant as the system adapts and also maintains its integrity.


When continuity and the need to accommodate to change become integrated in the system then the system is flexible and stable at the same time.
When that is happening we would say the system is 'effectively' functioning and capable of growth and change.


Behaviors and interaction patterns will not be repeated unless they serve the system in some way.
If a pattern of interaction is repeated it is serving the system in some way (symptoms serve a function).



How do families operate?
How do families develop?


Symptoms:
What is different about families that are 'healthy' and families that develop symptoms?
How do symptoms develop?
They would not be repeated if it was not supported by the system.


How can we intervene to change the way the family operates given the theory?
What is the focus of the intervention?
Is it having them act in a certain way? What is the focus?
We don't teach them about theory specifically, we are wanting to change behavior

(Rule about interaction, rules about changing the rule of interaction, and rules about change rules about changing the rules of interaction, etc)
All interaction is fed into the system and becomes both input and output, with a constant flow of information to these monitoring functions, with decisions made to either assimilate or accommodate.
Systems are goal-directed, and purposeful using both negative (deviation dampening) and positive (deviation amplifying) feedback.

item.title: 6. Contextual Family Therapy
item.description:
Ivan Boszormenyi-Nagy




Biological and historical context variables (i.e., sex at birth, national origin, race/ethnicity, etc.)
Also, events that you had no control over (parents divorce, illnesses)
Anything that would impact how families function.


Cognitions, affect, perceptions, experience, individual coping mechanisms.
Could include attachment styles here or other psychodynamic constructs


Patterns of interaction between family members.
Concepts of family systems theory (Boundaries, Family Rules, Triangles, Differentiation of Self, etc.) could be included here.


This is the cornerstone construct for Nagy's work.
Trust
Loyalty (split, invisible)
Entitlement (destructive)
All of these influence justice and fairness in relationships and are transmitted through generations.


Ontic: 'I-Thou' relationship, or dialogue


Revolving Slate, justice and fairness
All humans have worth and should be provided with 'due care.'
When we don't get the care we deserve we develop symptoms
We develop destructive entitlement which continues the cycle.


Multidirected partiality
Acknowledgement/accountability/crediting
Exoneration
Therapist use of self: you need to believe/live the theory and examine your own entitlements.


Family Transaction & Power
Relational Fairness/Ethical Dimension
Ontic
Facts
Psychology


Dimension II:
Strong emotional reactions (anger, shame)
Behaviors (control-seeking or chaotic/risky)
Nay point to a destructive entitlement. As humans, we are born with value and are entitled to do care. When we do not get that, we develop a destructive entitlement. We seek others to meet our needs. We treat our partner as an object rather than a person in a relationship.
Dimension III (Transactions):
Rigid or chaotic structures
Power struggles
High conflicts
Conflicts over 'nothing'


Violation of trust

Destructive entitlement

Parentification
Parent using the child to get the parents do care needs met.
Overgiving
Over functioning, one of the partners decides what is wrong and how to fix it. They decide what is wrong with the other person and how they need to fix it. Getting into someone else's lane.
Not making 'claims'
People not claiming self. People not holding themselves accountable.
Loyalty conflicts or its 'invisibility'



Restoring trust and balance of fairness in relationships
Opening relational resources
Opening a dialogue about fairness
Direct address
Presenting options
Enhancing an individual's capacity to consider the needs of others and acknowledgement of their acts
Enhancing an individual's capacity to stand up for his/her own needs and to do self-validation through acts
Earned merit and due consideration = balance


Not neutral
Multidirected Partiality
Not being neutral, being multidirectedly partial that you acknowledge each person's perspective and saying 'I get it. I understand why you may think that way.' You want the couples to learn how to validate someone else's perspective. Not agreeing with it, but just expanding the ability for a person to have compassion for others. Getting couples to ask for what
You have been with me long enough you should know. Opening up of relational issues.
People cannot be in a relationship and give nothing. Keep looking for their contribution. Want couples to validate each other and themselves.
As people acknowledge that other people make contributions (due consideration), we feel that we are getting the due consideration.
For couples therapy - considering
Transitional
Nonjudgmental
Facilitating - 'sowing seeds and opening doors' and giving moratorium
But - therapy still can be 'short-term'
Avoids becoming parentified
Therapists' own relational histories may resonate with those of their clients
'Self-of-the-therapist' issues may prevent clinicians from keeping a balanced stance towards members of the family
Therapist does not need to be liked by their clients. Why is it so important that your clients like you? Should your clients get better for you to be a good therapist?


Child maltreatment
Blended families
Adoption and foster care
Couple relationships
Anger issues
Depression
Self-esteem
Self-destrucitve behaviors and substance abuse


Multirectional Partiality
Acknowledgement
Crediting
Anticipatory Listening
Direct Address of Fairness Issues
Suggestions
Summary/Interpretations
Making Accountable
Exoneration


Beginning
Safety and trust
Middle
Dialogue and relational ethics
End
Integration/solidifying constructive entitlement


Establish safety and trust
Alliance building
Assess on 4 dimensions
Facts, individual psychology, family transactions, relational ethics
Acknowledge past - identify transgenerational revolving slates
Screen for risk factors and ethical/legal issues
Emphasize strengths rather than pathology


Relational Ethics and Dialogue
Behavioral changes
Mutual listening and validation skills
Develop effective dialogue skills
Make explicit relational ethics, i.e., power imbalances, broken trust
Make explicit issues involving family-of-origin
Destructive entitlement
Split loyalties
Deparentification
Exoneration


Integration:
Solidify constructive entitlement
Reinforce in calm environent
Balance give and take
Enhanced trust
Continue work with exoneration
Highlight new strengths and resources
plan for the future


De-escalation and soothing
Acknowledgement of the other:
Of reality, points of view
Deeds
Good starting point: "Do you see any truth in her/his words"
Acknowledgement of the self (instead of 'why')
Claiming considerations
Repairing past unfairness
Exploring family of origin model of fairness
Creating a couple's new fairness:
Repair and negotiation


How did your childhood experiences shape your model of what you owe and deserve and your beliefs about love and fairness?
Does love in your family permit you to question what's unfair? (p. 108)
How does your unfinished business play out in your expectations of yourself and your partner? (pg. 112)
What did your parents appreciate about you? (pg. 127)
What happened when you protested unfairness (pg. 133)


Parental accountability and responsibility
Restoration of fairness between generations of adults (parents and grandparents) benefits children
Assessing and addressing:
Loyalty issues
Fairness
Parentification
Checking and restoring age-appropriate balance of 'give and take'
It is desireable to restore relationships with parents even who abused their children because it is a way to self-freedom


Who was there for you? When you needed someone, who did you turn to?
Who did your parent (s) turn to during times of need?
Who did your parent (s) confide in most?
Whom were you able to rely on in times of need?
Whom were your parents able to rely on in times of need?
Whom could you trust in your family to see your best interests?
Whom could your parents trust in the family/their parents to seek their best interests?
Have you ever felt betrayed by any of your family members?
Have you heard from your parents or other family members that they felt betrayed or unsupported by the family?

item.title: 8. Experiential Family Therapy
item.description:
Myth of Fusion:
Human's must come to grips with 'aloneness.' Once we accept our aloneness then we have to make meaning for our lives.
"We believe people who love us should 'just know' what we need."
We have to accept we are a self. Once we accept our aloneness, we must make meaning of our lives.
Freedom and Responsibility
Humanistic Psychology:
Humans are good and move toward growth if unhindered.


Whitaker and others claim to be a-theoretical. However, Whitaker was a systems theorist and used ideas from humanistic psychology and psychoanalytic theory to guide his therapy.
Jay Haley thought he could change a family behind a mirror by telling a therapist what to do. Experiential therapists did not believe this is true. They want the family to be open to their emotional experience and thoughts they are having.
Anti-Technician:
Rather than a-theoretical, Whitaker and other experiential therapists are anti-technician. Manipulation does not encourage open experiencing.


Through feeling expression, families are able to balance separateness and connectedness.


Always 'becoming' or moving forward, toward growth.
Emotions/affect are validated and nurtured. Rules create balance: respect for affect and getting along.
Permeable boundaries which encourage expression of intimacy needs, differentiation, bonding, conflict expression/resolution, problem solving, and playfulness.


Symptoms develop when affect is blocked, impulses are denied and feelings are suppressed.
Boundaries and processes are rigid: holding themselves together is more important than experiencing life.
Superficial experience of emotion, self-denial, lack of empathy, lack of commitment, inability to handle conflict
Little awareness, little sense of choice, flow of behavior is blocked because of unexpressed emotion.
Carl Whitaker suggested that there were 3 contexts to our symptoms:
'Driven Crazy' in an interpersonal context in which person is belittled or disqualified.
'Going Crazy' a state of temporary disorganization.
'Acting Crazy' an adaptation to the context.


Increased personal integrity, greater freedom of choice, less dependence, expanded experiencing.
Strengthening the family as a system by increasing connectedness within the nuclear family and across generations. Enhance ability to support the completion of developmental tasks.


Battle for Structure
Battle for Initiative
Working Phase
Termination
Use of non-rational, symbol, and metaphor.
Use of self is paramount: any technique comes from the therapist's creativity.
Create a new therapeutic environment to alter the family's interaction in hopes of producing a different affective experience.
Interrupt rigid, repetitive cycles
Activate and allow for constructive anxiety or confusion.
Expand the presenting problem
Encourage and support any new decision (freedom to choose).
Create trans-generational boundaries.
Create a therapeutic supra-system in which the therapist and family are aligned, and the therapist still has the ability to differentiate (get in and get out).




Self-Worth:
How people learn to be people
Communication:
The ways people use to work out meaning with one another (Placating, Blaming, Computing, Distracting, Leveling/Congruence)
Placating (peacekeeper)
Blamer (im not happy its your fault)
Computing (have to have a rational explanation, ultra rationale)
Distracting (acts out when there is stress, someone who uses humor)
Leveling/Congruence
Rules:
The rules people use for how they should feel and act, which eventually develop into the family system.
Freedom to comment:
What can you say
To whom can you say it
How do you go about it if you disagree or disapprove of someone or something
How do you question when you do not understand
Taboo subjects
Taboo feelings
Expressing affection
Secrets
Overarching goal may be to loosen up the system so there is freedom to comment. Maybe you say it yourself, maybe use family sculpting,
Link to Society:
How the family interacts with the outside world


When communication patterns are rigid (other than congruence) and continual, and you can't comment on that.
Symptoms are symptoms of the system
Symptoms are created through the process of interaction


Low self-worth
Communication is indirect, vague, not honest
Rules are rigid and non-negotiable
Link to society is fearful, placating, and blaming


Congruence (you the therapist must be congruent) (as a therapist, when you have a sense of what is going on in the room, you say it
“Recording 20240412103404.webm” could not be found.
)
- Only with congruence can we know each other fully and we can use our differences creatively.
Focus of intervention
Helping people change and grow in:
Communication
Beliefs about being able to grow
Restoring the use of all the senses
Therapist use of self is key (as with all experiential models)
To alleviate symptoms you have to intervene in the process in a way that won't replicate their process.
Conditions for Chage
Trust
Development of awareness
Development of understanding
Development of awareness of options
Practice
Universal goal for all families
Development of self-worth
Freedom to comment


Techniques should emerge from the therapist/client interaction.
Techniques are only useful in a context of trust.

item.title: Philosophy of Change Perspective
item.description:
How do families operate?
How do families develop?


What is different about families that are 'healthy' and families that develop symptoms?
How do symptoms develop?


Given the theoretical conceptualizations from the first two sections, how can we intervene to change the way the family operates?
What is the focus of these interventions (i.e., insight, feelings, interaction patters, behavior, cognition)? You should use several examples of techniques to provide illustrations of this.


In this section, you are free to state your opinion, as well as the opinions of others. There are several assignments that critique the theories, you are also free to search for these critiques elsewhere. You need to support your critiques with literature. You should include culture/ethnicity, family structure (intact vs. Non-intact, or other alternative family forms) and gender issues.
I also encourage you to look at the way the theory is presented in the eyes of a beginning study of therapy and explore the possible 'dangers' that accepting a theory 'hook, line, and sinker' may create.

item.title: Carl Whitaker
item.description:
(1912-1995) Modeling
He was born in upstate New York and grew up on a dairy farm. He went to Syracuse University where he earned his M.D. in 1936. Whitaker first went into obstetrics and gynecology, but then switched to become a psychiatrist.
During WWII, he worked in Oak Ridge, Tennessee (top-secret project developing the atomic bomb was located).
He was mainly self-taught which made his take on a co-therapist, which became a mainstay of his practice.
In 1946, Whitaker was named chairman of the Department of Psychiatry at Emory University.
In 1956, he and colleagues opened the Atlanta Psychiatric clinic, a private practice where his approach, Symbolic-Experiential Family Therapy, was further developed.
In 1965, Whitaker moved back into academia, taking a position in the Department of Psychiatry at the University of Wisconsin.
Books include The Family Crucible and Dancing with the Family
Psychology of the Absurd (1975)
Blend of warm support and emotional goading.
Around Whitakers time, psychologically troubled people were seen as alienated from feeling and frozen into devitalized routines.
He worked with John Warkentin in 1943 in Oak Ridge, Tennessee.
He pioneered the use of co-therapy in belief that a supportive partner helped free the therapist to react without fear of countertransference.
Whitaker never seems to have an obvious strategy and did not use predictable techniques. He let his unconscious run therapy. He believed all interventions promoted flexibility. He challenged the family to open up and become more fully themselves and more fully together.
Whitaker organized a series of forums which eventually led to the Convention of Family Therapy Movement.
In 1946, Whitaker began twice yearly conferences where clinicians observed and discussed work with families.
He developed mutual observation and using one-way mirrors which became a hallmark of family therapy.
In 1955, Whitaker entered a private practice at the Atlanta Psychiatric Clinic and developed experiential-form of psychotherapy, treating families, individuals, groups, and couples.
In the late 70 s, Whitaker mellowed out and added greater understanding of family dynamics.

item.title: Ivan Boszormenyi-Nagy
item.description:
He originally was from the field of psychoanalysis.
He founded the Eastern Pennsylvania Psychiatric Institute in Philadelphia in 1957.
He worked with James Framo, a psychologist in the early family therapy movement, and Geraldine Spark, a social worker.
He added ethical accountability to usual therapeutic goals and techniques.
He believed neither pleasure nor expediency is sufficient to guide human behavior.
He believed family members have to base their relationships on trust and loyalty, and must balance the ledger of entitlement and indebtedness.

item.title: Natasha Slesnick, PhD
item.description:
Clinical Psychologist
Prevention of OUD: The HOME (Housing, Opportunities, Motivation, and Engagement)

Problem with research not being done on a wide scale with homeless youth.
NIH Heal Initiative (preventing opioid use disorder in older adolescents and young adults)
Testing CFT with adolescents as a treatment plan (1990s)
Engaging the family is difficult when child has to leave
Leaving justice system that have no where to go.
Individual interventions rather than using any relational therapy
Most kids on the streets deal with substance use. Mostly interested in giving the children a foundation to stand upon. Stability.
Vulnerable populations (adolescents and emerging adults)
How much is this children not knowing the resources that exist to help them

Some grants require you to work with other researchers on their projects who received the grant. Everyone collects data, have to make rules to what to do with the data, can be tedious.
Youth experiencing (Poly-drug users) homelessness (YEH) have extremely high rates of substance use and other risks
2-5 million YEH in the US (not rare), likely bearing the greatest burden from the epidemic. Replicable, evidence-based preventive interventions that comprehensively address these youth's range of needs are not established. While shelters are often the 'front door' or first contact for service provision among homeless populations, most of those under 24 years do not reach the shelter system.
in 2022, the overdose death rate in Ohio in 38.3 deaths out of every 100,000 residents. This is 85% higher than the national average OD death rate.
US has also seen a rapid increase in opioid use among youth, which has been described as the most alarming drug use trend.
Compared to housed youth:
YEH Have significantly higher rates of substance use, physical and mental health problems
YEH have 12 times higher mortality rate
Reports indicate that only 10% of YEH in need of services access available services.
Black persons make up 13% of the population, but 40% of the homeless population
Black youth have 83% higher change of reporting homelessness than their White peers.
Being Black is associated with a lower likelihood of finding permanent housing, with White families 1.9 times more likely to find housing than black families.
Youth identifying as sexual and/or gender minorities (SGM) are also overrepresented in the homeless population (40%)
Housing First:
Prevent opioids use disorder (OUD) and other risk behaviors associated with living on the streets, Housing First interventions may be necessary, as well as linkage to a range of services
Housing First is the name given to the philosophical approach that housing is a basic human right, and housing before or concurrent with other interventions make those interventions more effective.
Having autonomy to make choices and decisions for oneself
Do not take away housing if struggling with substance abuse/use or mental health
Prior prevention work:
The odds of recent hard drugs use among HIV positive adults experiencing homelessness were four times higher when they remained homeless.
Those who obtained housing were half as likely to use hard drugs and needs, to share needs, and engage in unprotected sex.
Engagement Challenges:
Services available but youth cannot or will not access them
Unless there's active outreach and meeting youth where they are, youth trying to live day to day will not take advantage of prevention services.
Youth often feel by betrayed by the system and its representatives.
18-24 are told to go to adult center
14-18 are sent to shelters
Strengths-Based Outreach Approach includes following deatures:
Use paraprofessional personnel
A focus on client strengths rather than deficits
A high degree of responsibility give t the client in directing and influencing the intervention that they receive from the system
Motivational Interviewing (MI):
Strong record of prevention in alcohol and drug problems.
Demands much less of a hard-to-reach population
Several studies have shown positive impact of MI on drug use among runaway and homeless youth
Prevention program / intervention description:
Using a housing first philosophy
6 months of rent
utility assistance
Eligibility
18-24 years
Youth experiences homelessness
Youth fails to meet DSM-5 criteria for Opioid Use Disorder (OUD)
Drug use (primarily marijuana use), showed a 35% Reduction in frequency of use
While statistical significant cannot be expected with a small sample, we found statistically significant improvement
no youth began opioid use during treatment
Qualitative Interviews:
17 participants; overall participants reported noticing positive changes in their lives from the intervention had nothing about the project they disliked.
5 landlords interviewed; generally positive experiences with project, willing to rent to future
Liked:
Consistent rent payments
Opportunity to help others
Disliked:
6-month lease (prefer full year)
Problematic Tenant (one landlord)
Phase I Summary:
Lessons learned:
Youth very engaged, even using remote strategies
HIV session attentance poor
landlord and youth experiences very good
Phase I Findings:
First study to engage at risk youth experiencing homelessness into a holist opioid prevention
Phase II:
Baseline Assessment -> Random Assignment
Housing and risk prevention services
Risk prevention services along
Conclusions:
Even though these youth are at high risk for OUD and overdose death and are considered difficult to engage, they CAN be engaged in m
Recommendations:
Transition planning would save money and prevent drug use and suicide if youth never go to street.
Need greater funding lalocations to drop-in centers AND for opiois and other prevention services - most federal funding overall given to shelters
Housing First:
If we conclude that housing is a powerful opioid prevention tool, then follows that housing for those experiencing homelessness has to be made a top priority in the drug precention world?
Support Housing First (not Housing Fourth)
Change rules on who is eligible for housing
Rules for obtaining identification
Justice record expungement to ease housing barriers
Address utility arrears.

item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Nathan Ackerman
item.description:
Ackerman sought out to understand a family to diagnose problems and develop family treatment.
He was a child psychiatrist.
He worked at the Menninger Clinic.
In 1937, he became the chief psychiatrist of the Child Guidance Clinic.
He followed the child guidance model of psychiatry to treat the child while the social worker saw the mother.
He began having the same therapist see both the mother and child around the 1940 s. he began to see the family as the basic unit of treatment.
In 1955, Ackerman organized the first session on family diagnosis at the Meeting of American Orthopsychiatric Association.
Don Jackson, Murray Bowen, Lyman Wynne (1954), and Nathan Ackerman learned about each others' work and joined in a common practice.
The Family Institute was founded in 1960.
They renamed the Family Institute to Ackerman Institute following his death in 1971.
He believed, even though families may give the appearance of unity, underneath they are split into competing factors.
His ideas were similar to the Psychoanalytic Family Therapy model
Despite the apparent unit of personality, families are actually minds in conflict driven by warring drives and defenses.
He believed families confront some issues while avoiding others, such as conflicts involving sex and aggression.
He saw his job as bringing the family secrets into the open.
He was unrestrained to encourage families to relax their emotional restraint.
He first sided with one member of the family and later with another.
He believed balance was achieved in the long-run by moving back and forth in giving support now to one, later to another family member.
He was described as unabashingly blunt.
He stated people get more reassurance from honesty than from false promises.

item.title: Robert MacGregor
item.description:
Multiple Impact Therapy (1967) was pioneered by him.
It is an intensive, crisis oriented form of family therapy where family members are treated in subgroups by a team of therapists.
His clinic served a population that was scattered widely over southeastern Texas, and clients had to travel hundreds of miles.
He developed Multiple Impact Therapy (1967) in 1967 at the University of Texas Medical Branch in Galveston.
He wanted the maximum impact in a short amount of time.
He worked intensively with families for two days.
His team approach is a hallmark in the family therapy field.

item.title: 1. Taking on the Challenge of Becoming a Therapist
item.description:
Read Patterson et al. Chapter 1 ✅ 2023-09-20 @iveyBASICATTENDINGSKILLS
Taibbi (2022) et al. Chapter 1 @roberttaibbiDoingFamilyTherapy2022
AAMFT Code of Ethics ✅ 2023-09-20 @AAMFTCodeofEthics2015



AAMFT Core Competencies:


Admission to Treatment:
All interactions between clients and therapist up to the point when a therapeutic contract is established.
Clinical Assessment and Diagnosis:
Activities focused on the identification of the issues to be addressed in therapy.
Treatment Planning and Case Management:
All activities focused on directing the course of therapy and extra-therapeutic activities.
Therapeutic Interventions:
All activities designed to ameliorate the clinical issues identified.
Legal Issues, Ethics, and Standards:
All aspects of therapy that involve statues, regulations, principles, values, and more of MFTs.
Research and Program Evaluation:
All aspects of therapy that involve the systematic analysis of therapy and how it is conducted efficiently.


Biological Dimension:
Biochemical systems, Cell Systems, Organ Systems, Physiological Systems
Psychological Dimension:
Cognition, Perception, Attitude, Personality, Behavior
Spiritual Dimension:
Faith, Spiritual Experiences, Higher Levels of Consciousness
Social Dimension:
Culture, Conditions, Circumstances, Human Interactions that encompass Human Beings



Stage 1: Essential Skills:
Basic Skills:
Learning to relax
Be present
Joining
Empathic Listening
Curiosity
Attending Skills
Advanced Skills:
Assessment
Diagnosis
Case Conceptualization
Treatment Planning
Theory Based Interventions
The Microskills Hierarchy:
Stage 2: Conceptualizing Cases:
Learning Theory:
Generating Systemic Hypotheses
A proposed explanation for how a particular couple or family interacts.
These hypotheses are made based on general principles of systems along with observing the patterned way a particular system interacts.
Systemic hypotheses help a clinician understand the functioning of a system and gain a working understanding of the influences that maintain the presenting problem.
Stage 3: Therapist as Self:
Understanding the therapist as an asset or a liability in therapy.
Important distinction between 'Person of the Therapist' and 'Therapist's Use of Self'.
Relationship of training to other variables:

item.title: 2. Locating Ourselves. Self of Therapist
item.description:
Read Location of Self @watts-jonesLocationSelfOpening2010
Read Packard Chapter 1 @iveyBASICATTENDINGSKILLS




Learning to relax
Be present
Joining
Empathic Listening
Curiosity
Attending Skill


Assessment
Diagnosis
Case Conceptualization
Treatment Planning
Theory Based Interventions
The Microskills Hierarchy:




Learning Theory:
Generating Systemic Hypotheses:
Systemic Hypotheses:
A proposed explanation for how a particular couple or family interacts.
These hypotheses are made based on general principles of systems along with observing the patterned way a particular system interacts.
Systemic hypotheses help a clinician understand the functioning of a system and gain a working understanding of the influences that maintain the presenting problem.
Theory Based Conceptualization:
Developing your own theory of change:


Understanding the therapist as an asset or a liability in therapy.
Important distinction between 'Person of the Therapist' and 'Therapist's Use of Self'.
Relationship of training to other variables:


Basic Attending Skills:
Attending Behavior:
Individually and culturally appropriate verbal and nonverbal behavior - culturally appropriate eye contact, vocal tone, body language, and verbal following.
Questions/Open Invitation to Talk:

Open vs. Closed Questions
- Open questions often begin with what, how, or could. They help the client explore issues and talk at greater length.
- Closed questions often begin with do, is, are, and lead to focused answers, often shorter in length.
- Clarifying - Encourage, Restate, Paraphrase:
- Encourages are brief responses such as head nods, "Uh-huh," and single words or phrases.
- They encourage client depth exploration and bring clarity as to meaning. Appropriate smiling is one of the most important encourages.
- Restatement:
- In the restatement you select several key words and repeat the back exactly. It works like an encourager, but focuses in more depth on a key issue.
- Paraphrase:
- The paraphrase feeds back to the client the essence of what has been said. The paraphrase provides a check on the accuracy of your listening and may enable the client to move on to a new topic.
- Reflection of Feeling/Responding to Emotion:
- Reflection of feeling is concerned with identifying and feeding back to the client the underlying emotional experience.
- Exploration of emotion is basic to understanding a client's deeper desires and wishes.
- Clarifying emotion leads to better client decision making and action.
- Summarization:
- This skill asks you to feed back to the client the essence of longer statements or a whole interview.
- Many summarizations will include descriptions of behavior, thoughts, and emotion.
- This skill is useful in clarifying what has happened in key interview segments and in beginning and ending the interview.
- Integration of Skills - Five Stages of the Interview:



Self-of-the-therapist work is the willingness of a therapist to participate in a process that requires introspective work on issues in their own life, that has an impact the process of therapy in both positive and negative ways.
Self-of-the-therapist work should focus on life events in such a way that therapists are able to see their past experiences as both potential obstacles and potential strengths.


How do your life experiences help you to be more compassionate to your clients?
How do your life experiences allow you to understand your clients on a deeper level?
How can you use your previous life experiences to inform your work?


What issues in therapy are 'too close to home'?
How are issues 'getting in the way'?
What are potential 'blind spots' in the therapy room?


Using a Both/And Perspective:
Discuss themes in terms of how they could get in the way of successful therapy and how it helps you become a better therapist.
Celebrate experiences not just pathologize them.


Establish:
Establish safety
Strive:
Strive for a balanced perspective that is inclusive of gender and culture.
Process:
Process therapist/supervisor and colleague/colleague relationships.
Be:
Be aware of dual-relationships.


My Therapy House:
Foundation:
The things you bring to graduate school, self-of-the-therapist, who you are, what you stand for, experiences that shape you.
House:
This is your theory, items about your theory that fit with your foundation (should be seamless and purposeful) (worldview)
Roof:
Borrowed techniques from other theories that fit with your population of interest, theory, self-of-the-therapist.
Chimney:
How you evaluate that what you are doing is helpful, and your self-care plan.


A process in which the therapist initiates a conversation with a family about similarities and differences in their key identities, such as race, ethnicity, gender, class, sexual orientation, and religion, and how they may potentially influence the therapy process.
Location of self begins with the therapist engaging in self-disclosure but continues beyond.


The revelation of personal rather than professional information about the therapist to the client.
When therapist disclosure goes beyond the standard professional disclosure of name, credentials, office addresses, fees, office policies, etc., it becomes self-disclosure.
Appropriate clinically driven self-disclosures carried out for the clinical benefit of the clients and unavoidable (non-harming).
Self-disclosure that takes place in the community are considered boundary crossings.
Inappropriate self-disclosures are considered a boundary violation.
Self-disclosure done for the benefit of the therapist
Clinically counter-indicated disclosures that burden the client with unnecessary information or creates a role reversal where a client takes care of the therapist.
Different types of self-disclosure:
Deliberate:
Self-revealing
Self-involving
Unavoidable
Accidental
Clients' deliberate actions

What is the therapist's intent?
The decision to self-disclose is based first and foremost on the welfare of the client.
Intentional and deliberate self-disclosure is made under the general moral and ethical principles of beneficence and nonmaleficence

item.title: 3. Introduction to Basic Attending Skills
item.description:
Referral
Making Contact (Initial Contact):
Listen and reflect to the client what you hear.
Assess if this is a crisis situation.
Consider scope-of-practice issues.
Respond as promptly as possible.
Consider why this particular family member made the initial contact, and keep in mind that a sense of rapport with each individual in the family is important.
Address the 'business' of therapy as quickly and efficiently as possible while not detract from client's need to be heard.
Planning
First Session
Inter-Session Analysis and Planning
Follow-up Sessions (Focused on Assessment, Information Gathering, Rapport Building, Initial Treatment Planning)


Follow-up Sessions:
Working the treatment plan
Interventions
Assessment of Progress
Review of goals
'Muddy Middle Phase'


Determine the appropriate time to end therapy.
This could be one or more sessions.
Create a plan for post therapy.
Engage in evaluation of therapy effectiveness.
Termination also represents the closure of the professional relationship between client and therapist.
Multiple reasons for termination are possible.


Listen and reflect to the client what you hear.
Assess if this is a crisis situation.
Consider scope-of-practice issues.
Respond as promptly as possible.
Consider why this particular family member made the initial contact, and keep in mind that a sense of rapport with each individual in the family is important.
Address the 'business' of therapy as quickly and efficiently as possible while not detract from client's need to be heard.


"What are the clients' expectations about therapy?"
"What are their anxieties about coming to therapy?"
"What motivates them to come to therapy, and who is the referral source?"
"Why do they want to come to therapy now?"


Determine the appropriate setting.
Fill in the necessary gaps in the referral.
Make a pre-session hypothesis.
Construct a plan for the first session.
Finalize arrangements with the family.



Client Inquiry

Initial Contact

Client Paperwork Completion

Clinician Pre-Planning:

Make initial contact.

Review intake paperwork.

Confirm intake appointment.

First Intake Session
Biopsychosocial Assessment, Risk Assessment, Preliminary Diagnosis and Goal Development

Intra-Session Planning

Second Session:
Treatment planning and goal development.

Ongoing sessions

item.title: 4. Beginning to Think Systemically - Family Systems Theory
item.description:
Circular Questioning



A method of interviewing developed by the Milan Associates in which questions are asked that highlight differences among family members. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)


"A person cannot do right in one department of life while attempting to do wrong in another department." - Gandhi


What is a system?
A set of objects (elements) that interrelate to form a whole
Closed System: no interchange with its environment (doesn't apply to social systems)
Open System: One that receives matter and energy from its environment (applies to communication).
Consists of:
Objects, or parts, elements, or members of the system
These parts may be physical or abstract.
System consists of attributes.
Internal relationships among its objects (mutual effects).
An environment. They are affected by their surroundings.
Wholeness and Interdependence:
In a system, the whole is more than the sum of its parts.
It is a product of the forces or interactions among its parts.
It's parts cannot be understood separately.
The interdependence creates organization in the system (e.g., a family).
Hierarchy:
Systems tend to be embedded within one another.
Every complex system consists of subsystems.
Given that systems are within systems, it is fuzzy as to where to locate the boundary between the system and the environment.
Interchange with the Environment:
Inputs and outputs.
The system affects and is affected by the environment.
Balance (Homeostasis)
Self-maintenance
Sensing deviations from the norm and correcting those 'faults.'
Self-Regulation and Control:
Systems are often viewed as goal-oriented.
They are governed by their purposes.
The parts operate according to guidelines and adapt to the environment on the basis of feedback.
This aspect of system functioning is cybernetics.
Change and Adaptability:
The system must adapt to its environment.
Equifinality:
A particular final state may be achieved in different ways.
Family as a System:
This model of a family as a system is extrapolated from the work of Ludwig von Bertalanffy and his General Systems Theory.
Holons:
A single cell is made up of holons, just as a family is made up of individuals.
Cybernetics:
First-Order Cybernetics (1940s-1960s):
Concepts:
Homeostasis
Control of the Observed Mechanism
Self-Steering
Information vs. Noise
Major Assumptions:
Modern vs. Post Modern
Level of analysis is the family or larger context.
The observer remains outside the system.
There is a particular way families 'should' behave.
Reality is objective.
Second-Order Cybernetics (1960s-1980s):
Concepts:
Stability vs. Homeostasis
Interaction with (vs. control of) mechanism
Observer's implication in the system
Major Assumptions:
Main difference is that the observer is a part of the system.
Reality is self-referential (i.e., everything we know and see is based on our personal frame of reference).
No reference to an outside environment.
More to a System:
Bounded:
A cell has a 'Feedback Loop,' enabling information to be transferred throughout the cell. All families have such a loop or Process for communicating.
Interdependent:
All holons are interdependent on each other. Change one and you change the system. The same holds true of individuals in the family system.
Homeostasis:
All cells expend energy to maintain a steady state or homeostasis. This explains the difficulty of change within family systems.
This thinking moves from linear causality to a more multi-dimensional approach to families.
From A->B->C to interconnections between A, B, and C.
Core Concepts:
Problems:
Understanding Problems:
Your Clinical Theory
Learning Problems vs. Problems about Learning
Problems as Bad Solutions
Problems arising from childhood wounds, outmoded, limiting coping styles
Problems arising from Larger Societal Changes (and Issues)
The Presenting Problem:
A presenting problem is an initial symptom that causes a person to seek professional help.
Describe the reason the client came to you.
Include the client's definition of their problem.
How long they've been experiencing the issue.
Process:
Understanding Process:
Content:
Stories about what happened; shared at length and with extraneous details
Process:
Access the client's internal experience and working through parts of it.
Process Questions in Therapy:
When a client is discussing something important to them tell the initial story and listen until your client invites you to help them. Otherwise, and after initial sessions you should mostly ask 'Process' questions that:
Focus on the client themselves and their internal experience
Help the client 'slow down' and reflect on ideas or feelings that seem significant
Use immediacy to ask about emotions you're noticing in a moment
Focus on themes, patterns, and affect
Example of Process Questions in Therapy:
"What is it like for you when..."
"I might be off here, but were you feeling... in that moment?"
When you notice heightened emotion, you can ask, "What's coming up for you right now?", "How are you feeling, talking to me about this?"
"What do you wish other people knew about what you are experiencing?"
"Today or in our previous sessions, have you found yourself thinking 'I wish they'd ask me about....?" "What question do you need someone to ask you, that no one has?"
"How did that make you feel about yourself, about your partner, about the relationship?"
"What you just mentioned about X seems important, at least to me. Could we slow down and stay with this idea/feeling for a moment?"
Patterns:
Observable repeated behavior, thoughts, or interaction that often manifest in human interaction and may manifest in therapy sessions.
For example, a client may have a patter of shutting down emotionally or becoming distracted whenever you approach painful material.
Writing a Systemic Hypothesis:
Circular Questioning:
Circular questioning is a technique used in systemic family therapy to 'invite participants in a conversation to consider relational aspects of the topic being investigated.'
Ask open questions to explore communication and relationship patterns
Types of Circular Questions:
Bridging the Past:
Circular questions bridge the past and the present together to find a moment in time when a shift in the family occurred. If this moment can be identified, it can give clues as to how to help the family.
Has conflict always happened like this in your family?
What was it like before?
When did it start happening like this?
Thirds:
Circular questioning often asks a third person for their thoughts on how a dyad operates. This often breaks an unspoken rule in families that states, 'We don't comment about others.'
This technique invites reflection on how two people's actions impact the behavior or mood of another. These questions are often used to assess how families respond to their members in different situations.
"Dad, when Son is showing signs of depression, what do you see Mom do?"
"Mom, when Dad is taking care of Son, what do you think Dad gets out of?"
Differences:
When a behavior occurs or a significant change occurred different family members reacted in different ways.
Circular questions help us understand the different ways people reacted and from that we can gauge how close people are, or how distant, enmeshment, and various other ideas.
How is this different than before?
Who is most likely to comfort...?
Who is least likely?
Has this always been true?
Resistance:
Being a Common Factors Informed Therapist:
Common Factors in Psychotherapy:
Active therapeutic factors that appear to account for the majority of treatment outcomes in over 400 forms of psychotherapy theoretical models and are applicable and effective in the treatment of various psychiatric conditions.
(Lambert, 1992, analysis)
Client Factors (40%)
Relationship Factors (30%)
Placebo Factors (15%)
Treatment Factors (15%)
Contributions of specific and general effects on therapy outcomes (Wampold, 2001)
General Effects (70%)
Unexplained Variance (in part client variables 22%)
Specific Effects (8%)
Percentage of Improvement in Therapy Clients as a Function of Therapeutic Factors (Asay and Lambert, 1999)
Client Variables and Extra-Therapeutic Events (40%)
The Therapeutic Relationship (30%)
Expectancy and Placebo Effects (15%)
Technique and Model Factors (15%)
Big View of Common Factors:
Client characteristics
Therapist characteristics
Therapeutic Relationship
Expectancy
Non-Specific Mechanisms of Change - Interventions that cut across all models
Other mediating and moderating factors
Common Factors Research in Couple and Family Therapy
When two or more treatments compared to each other are designed based on a sound theory about how people change, and treatment sessions are structured to target those theoretical change processes (i.e., active treatments), there are typically very few differences in patient outcomes.
Evidence-based research on common factors has shown that relationship factors in a therapeutic dyad or group setting predict the outcome of psychotherapy.
Couple and Family Therapy Common Factors:
Conceptualizing Difficulties in Relational Terms
Disrupting Dysfunctional Relational Patterns
Expanding the Direct Treatment System
Expanding the Therapeutic
Clinical Implications of Common Factors:
Practice professional modesty
Choose a model you believe in
Practice your model flexibly
Get honest feedback
Capitalize on CFT Specific Common Factors
The Cycle of Change
Precontemplation:
A logical starting point for the model, where there is no intention of changing behavior; the person may be unaware that a problem exists
Contemplation:
The person becomes aware that there is a problem, but has made no commitment to change.
Preparation:
The person is intent on taking action to correct the problem; usually required buy-in from the client (i.e., the client is convinced that the change is good) and increased self-efficacy (i.e., the client believes they can make a change)
Action:
The person is in active modification of behavior.
Maintenance:
Sustained change occurs and new behavior(s) replaces old ones. Per this model, this stage is also transitional.
Relapse:
The person falls back into old patterns of behavior.
Upward Spiral:
Each time a person goes through the cycle, they learn from each relapse and (hopefully) grow stronger so that relapse is shorter or less devastating
Specific Factors:
Elements clearly delineated by proponents of a given therapy as the active causes of change.
Empirically Supported Relationships:
Therapeutic interventions that possess empirical support for the efficacy of the therapeutic relationship, client values and beliefs, and the working alliance between client and therapist.

item.title: 5. Joining Skills, Intake, and Interviewing
item.description:
Patterson et al. Chapter 3 @pattersonEssentialSkillsFamily2018
Taibbi (2022) et al. Chapter 4 @roberttaibbiDoingFamilyTherapy2022
Taibbi (2022) et al. Chapter 5 @roberttaibbiDoingFamilyTherapy2022
Basic Skills of a Counselor (Video)
OSU CFT Clinic Informed Consent and Therapy Contract:“Informed Consent.pdf” could not be found.
Informed Consent:
Informed consent is the consent by a client to a proposed medical or psychotherapeutic procedure, or for participation in a research project or clinical study.
For consent to be informed the client must first achieve a clear understanding of the relevant facts, risks and benefits, and available alternatives involved.
Informed consent requires legal documentation in all 50 states.
Informed Consent - AAMFT Code of Ethics:
Informed consent generally necessitates that the client:
has the capacity to consent
Has been adequately informed of significant information concerning treatment processes and procedures
Has been adequately informed of potential risks and benefits of treatments for which generally recognized standards do not yet exist
Has freely and without undue influence expressed consent
Has provided consent that is appropriately documented
Things to include in Informed Consent:
Contact information
Your qualifications including training, experience, licensure and certifications
Any limitations on your practice such as being under supervision
Services offered
Your theoretical foundation and approach to therapy
Fee structure including broken appointments, collecting debt, and cancellation policy
Whether or not you will file insurance/provide documentation for your clients to file insurance
How you handle emergencies and client needs after business hours
Confidentiality and exceptions to confidentiality
Client rights and responsibilities
The professional code(s) of ethics that you adhere to
How to file a complaint against you
Steps to obtaining Informed Consent:
**Provide:
Provide client with information
**Evaluate:
Evaluate the client's capacity to understand the information.
Obtain:
Obtain consent from the client.
Document:
Document obtaining informed consent in the initial progress note.
Initial Session/Intake:
Welcome Stage:
Make sure participant(s) are comfortable.
Review clinic policies and procedures.
Address any questions.
Overall Goal: Orient clients to therapy.
Social Stage:
Get to know the clients outside of the problem.
Chat with each client briefly, asking about their occupations and interests.
Goal: Begin to join and build rapport with clients
Assessment State - complete Mental Status Exam, biopsychosocial assessment, and risk assessment:
Begin initial assessment with the client system.
This includes individual level and relational level assessment.
Complete the following:
Mental Status Exam:
The mental status examination is a structured assessment of the patient's behavioral and cognitive functioning.
In general, the components of a mental status exam include descriptions of the following:
Appearance
General Behavior
Speech and Language
Emotions
Thought and Perception
Cognition
Risk Assessment:
Risk Assessment includes consideration of psychological and social factors as part of a comprehensive review to capture client needs, and to assess their risk of harm to themselves or others.
Assessments often aim to categorize patients as at high, medium or low risk.
Examples of risk areas include:
Suicidal Ideation
Homicidal Ideation
Child Abuse/Neglect
Intimate Partner Violence
Physical Health Issues or Crises
Inability to care for self or others
Animal Abuse
Substance Use
Intake Checklist:
A Biopsychosocial Assessment is an assessment typically conducted by therapists at the beginning of therapy, which assesses for biological, psychological, and social factors that can be contributing to a problem or problems with a client.
Biopsychosocial Assessments enable therapist to diagnose and effectively treat clients.
Primary Goal: Gain context to help facilitate change.
Diagnose Disorders
Plan Treatments
Evaluate the effectiveness of interventions
Establishing the Problem:
Have each client state, without discussion, their view of the issue needed to be addressed in therapy.
Goal: To identify the presenting problem bringing the client(s) to therapy.
Investigating the Problem:
Discuss the issues with the client(s) to gain more detail about the nature and context of the
You may also choose to structure a directed interaction or engagement to understand the issue more thoroughly.
This is the time to add the who, what, when..., previous attempts, culture, gender, love, justice, spirituality, strengths, sequences, circular questioning, etc.
Goal: Understand the History and Contextual Factors Related to the Problem
Meeting Alone:
Only if appropriate, meet separately with one, or several, of the unit.
Establishing Goals:
Have the client(s) set short and long-term goals for the therapy.
These are initial goals and can be considered tentative.
Try to work with clients to identify SMART goals.
Developing Interventions:
Give the family members some task to do before the next session.
This is dependent on your model or approach. This is not always applicable.
Conclusion:
Conclude the sessions
Address any final questions
Provide a summary of the main points of the session
Determine if client(s)
Most Basic Initial Session/Intake:
Meeting Alone:
If appropriate, meet separately with one, or several, of the unit.
Establishing Goals:
Have the client(s) set short and long-term goals for the therapy.
Develop Interventions: Give the family members some task to do before the next session.
This is dependent on your model or approach. This is not always applicable.
Conclude the Session
Basic Interviewing Techniques:
Attending Behavior:
Individually and culturally appropriate verbal and nonverbal behavior - culturally appropriate eye contact, vocal tone, body language, and verbal following.
Non-directive Listening Responses:
Directive Listening Responses:
Direction Action Responses:
Skilled Use of Questions
Circular Questioning:
Questions that draw distinctions (broaden understanding)
Across Time
Between People
Between Situations
Between Parts of a Person
Questions that draw connections (narrow focus)
Behavior
Feelings
Beliefs
Meaning
Relationships
Common Circular Questions:
Temporal Questions:
Encourages reflection on what has happened in the past and the changes that have taken place over time.
eg., Was anything different in how you were treated before, compared with now?
Triadic Questions:
Invite reflection regarding how two people's actions impact the behavior or mood of another.
eg., How does your father react when your mother cries?
Mind-Reading Questions:
Invite individuals to consider what someone else might think in order to explore how their relationship works.
eg., If your father didn't arrive home as expected, how do you think your mother would react?
Reflection
Empathic Listening
Reflection of Feeling
Reflection to Emotion
Pinpointing:
Open-Ended Questions:
Open Invitations to Talk
Questions
Open vs. Closed Questions
Open questions often begin with what, how, or could. They help the client explore issues and talk at greater length.
Closed questions often begin with do, is, are, and lead to focused answers, often shorter in length.
Confrontation:
Self-Disclosure:
Silence:
Reframing:
Focusing:
Summarization:
Clarifying:
Encourage
Restate
Paraphrase
