item.title: 6. Assessment and Conceptualization
item.description:
Read Patterson et al. Chapter 4 @pattersonEssentialSkillsFamily2018
Read Patterson et al. Chapter 10 @pattersonEssentialSkillsFamily2018
Read Patterson et al. Appendix @pattersonEssentialSkillsFamily2018
Read Gerhart Chapter 11 Research Citations/Books/@gehartMasteringCompetenciesFamily2017
Read Gerhart Chapter 12 Research Citations/Books/@gehartMasteringCompetenciesFamily2017
Read Collaborative Assessment and Management of Suicidality (CAMS Framework)
Read and Review: “Media/Clinic Media/(CAMS) Collaborative Assessment and Management of Suicidality.pdf” could not be found.
Read (https://www.etr.org/blog/deescalation-techniques-coping-with-students-clients-coping-with-our-lives/)
Watch (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=h1xGjKuDAaQ&ab_channel=DianeR.Gehart%2CPh.D.)
Watch (https://youtu.be/R2PSExM-NhULinks to an external site.)
Watch (https://youtu.be/6B9Kqg6jFeILinks to an external site.
Review Diagnostic Assessment Outline:“Diagnostic Assessment Outline.pdf” could not be found.
Review Non-Violence Agreement: “Non-Violence-Agreement (4).pdf” could not be found.
Review Intimate Justice Scale: “Intimate-Justice-Scale.pdf” could not be found.
Review Gender Inclusive Power and Control Wheel: “PowerandControlWheel- gender inclusive.pdf” could not be found.
Review LGBT Power and Control Wheel for Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, and Trans Relationships: “LGBT power and control wheel.pdf” could not be found.
Review Safety Plan How-To Guide for Clinicians:“Safety Plan How-To Guide for Clinicians.pdf” could not be found.
Review Cultural Formation Interview: “APA_DSM5_Cultural-Formulation-Interview (3).pdf” could not be found.
Review How to Create a New Client in Therapy Notes: “How To_ Create a New Client in Therapy Notes.pdf” could not be found.
MAKE SURE TO COMPLETE OBSERVATION FORM AFTER OBSERVATION


Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD7): “GAD-7 (1).pdf” could not be found.
Patient Health Questionnaire: “PHQ9.pdf” could not be found.
Experiences in Close Relationships Scale - Short Form (ECR-SF):“ECR-S.pdf” could not be found.
Description: https://novopsych.com.au/assessments/formulation/experience-in-close-relationship-scale-short-form-ecr-s/Links to an external site.
How do we not make assumptions on how people feel? We can only guess, but that can come off.
- Don't want to jumpt to conclusions. Allow the client to describe it. Can you tell me what it looks like for you? Use open ended questions. using states like "I have heard people describe this before, how does it feel for you?

What is just suicidal ideation?
What if


Types of Clinical Assessment:
Two broad approaches to assessment:
Systemic Approach
Postmodern Approach
Formal Assessments:
Formal assessment involves the use of tools such as tests, questionnaires, checklists and rating scales.
Formal assessments often have data to determine their reliability and validity.
Examples:
Generalized Anxiety Disorder 7 Questionnaire (GAD7) - Individual
GAD-7 (1).pdf
Patient Health Questionnaire 9 (PHQ9) - Individual
PHQ9.pdf
Experiences of Close Relationships Scale - Couple
Informal Assessments:
Unstructured:
Writing or drawing activities
Journals
Games
Observation
Structured:
Checklists
Rating Scales
Interviews
Questionnaires

The mental status examination is a structured assessment of the patient's behavioral and cognitive functioning.
In general, the components of a mental status exam include descriptions of the following:
Appearance:
Casual dress, normal grooming and hygiene.
Attitude:
Calm and cooperative
General Behavior:
Unusual movements or psychomotor changes
Speech and Language:
Normal rate/tone/volume and without pressure
Emotions:
Reactive and mood congruent, labile, tearful, blunted, normal range, depressed, constricted, flat
Mood:
Euthymic, irritable, elevated, anxious, depressed
Thought and Perception:
Goal-directed and logical or disorganized
Suicidal ideation: passive, active, plan?
Homicidal ideation: passive, active plan?
Hallucinations or delusions during interview
Cognition
Orientation:
oriented to time, place, person, self

Biopsychosocial Model: “Screenshot 2023-09-27 at 10.25.48 AM.png” could not be found.
A Biopsychosocial Assessment is an assessment typically conducted by therapists at the beginning of therapy, which assesses for biological, psychological, and social factors that can be contributing to a problem or problems with a client.
Biopsychosocial Assessments enable therapist to diagnose and effectively treat clients.
Tasks and Process of Assessment:
Make Initial Contact
Develop a collaborative therapeutic relationship
Use a bio-psycho-sociocultural-spiritual assessment: Person-in-Environment
Defining problems
Assessing safety
Accessing and appreciating patient/clients' strengths
Assess systems collaboration issues and strengths
Expand awareness and perspectives
Assess goals
Biopsychosocial Assessment Areas:
Demographic Information (Age, Ethnicity, Religion, Relational Status, Referral Status, etc.)
History of the Presenting Problem
Psychiatric History
Trauma History
Family Psychiatric History
Medical History
Medication Use
Substance Use
Family History (Family of Origin, Relationship with Parents, Siblings, etc.)
Social History
Spiritual/Cultural Factors
Developmental History
Educational/Vocational History
Legal History
SNAP (Strength, Needs, Abilities, Preferences)
Other Important Information
Guiding Principles for Assessment:
A systemic view:
Everything is connected
Foundational importance of bio-physiological, psychological, sociocultural, and spiritual domains in relation to multiple service systems
A strengths-based perspective
Assessment as an ongoing process

Regular screening and tracking during sessions of the following:
Health status
Mobility
Wellness
Exercise
Nutrition
Sleep
Ensure that client has primary care physician
Communicate with primate care physician or other health providers as needed.

General Psychological Issues:
Cognitive skills and ability (e.g.. thought process, problem-solving/decision-making skills)
Behavioral skills
Emotional competencies:
Affect regulation
Capacity for relating
Motivational factors
Overall mental status
Risk Assessment
Specific Mental Health Concerns:
Depression
Anxiety
Substance Use
Appropriate referral if needed
Ongoing communication between external providers (collaboration of care)

Risk Assessment includes consideration of psychological and social factors as part of a comprehensive review to capture client needs, and to assess their risk of harm to themselves or others.
Assessments often aim to categorize patients as at high, medium, or low risk
Examples of risk areas include:
Suicidal ideation
Homicidal ideation
Child abuse/neglect
Intimate partner violence
Physical health issues or crises
Inability to care for self or others
Animal abuse
Substance abuse
Important factors:
Level of risk
Intent to act
Plan to act
Means to act
Risk and protective factors

Assessing Strengths:
Personal and Relational Strengths:
Bio-physiological
Psychological
Sociocultural
Spiritual
'Strengths' of the problem/symptoms
Strengths in systems collaboration
Exploring the 'Strengths' and Potential 'Contributions' of the Problem
When was the last time that you realized that the problem was helpful to you?
If your problem has a voice, what do you think it is trying to share or communicate with you?
How might the problem be helpful to you?
If we could get rid of the problem, what might be some aspect of it that you might want to retain?
Useful Questions for Assessing Strengths:
What has been helpful so far?
What are some of your successes?
What are the achievements that you are most proud of having accomplished?
What little things are you doing that make life a little better for you?
What kinds of things do people compliment you on?
When have you stopped doing something that was difficult for you to stop?
When have you made an important change in your life that was difficult to make?
When have you broken a habit that was hard to break?
Outcomes of Assessment:
Problems:
Bio-psycho-sociocultural-spiritual perspective
Problem and attempted solutions specifically and behaviorally described (SOLVABLE).
Goals:
Desired future outcomes
Specifically and behaviorally described (ATTAINABLE)
Professional and the patient/client mutually agree to the described problems and goals.
Treatment plan and interventions based on mutual consensus of problem and goal


David A. Jobes, Ph.D.
Creator of CAMS Framework
Collaborative Assessment and Management of Suicidality (CAMS)
It is a therapeutic framework for suicide-specific assessment and treatment of a patient's suicidal risk. It is a flexible approach that can be used across theoretical orientations and disciplines for a wide range of suicidal patients across treatment settings and different treatment modalities.
Every session of CAMS intentionally utilizes the patient's input about what is and is not working. All assessment work in CAMS is collaborative.
The clinician's honesty and forthrightness are key elements.
The CAMS clinician endeavors to understand their patient's suffering from an empathic, nonjudgemental, and intra-subjective perspective. The clinician never shames or blames a suicidal person for being suicidal.
Evidence-Based Psychological Treatments for Suicide:
Three evidence-based (randomized controlled trials) interventions and treatments that are designed to directly target suicide at risk.
Dialectical Behavioral Therapy (DBT)
Cognitive Behavior Therapy (CBT):
Suicide Prevention (CT-SP) and Brief CBT.
Collaborative Assessment and Management of Suicidality (CAMS)
Suicide-Specific Brief Interventions:
Evidence-Based (Random Controlled Trial):
Teachable Moment Brief Intervention (TMBI):
A one-time intervention 2 dats after an attempt.
Motivational Interviewing:
In-patient settings
Crisis Response Planning & Safety Planning (6 Steps)
Attempted Suicide Short Intervention Program (ASSIP):
3 Sessions in-patient settings
Malpractice Liability, Competent Practice, and Cases of Suicide:
Know the three 'pillars' for reducing malpractice liability (i.e. malpractice wrongful death torts):
Foreseeability:
Treatment Planning:
Follow-Up/Follow-Through:

item.title: 7. Introduction to Telehealth
item.description:
Read Caldwell (2017) @caldwellUsingScalingFacilitate2016
Read Holland (2021) @hollandRiskAssessmentCrisis2021
Read Maheu (2018) @maheuFrameworkInterprofessionalTelebehavioral2018
Read Suler (2001) @sulerAssessingPersonSuitability2001
Watch '20+ Telehealth Tips from a Certified TeleMental Health Therapist' (https://youtu.be/8Eotw2mbHkk%20)
How do we balance knowing what we know and what our clients can teach us

Dialectic, expertise and balancing feedback.
Don't take things personally from clients.
How do you
What would be the ideal way to approach feedback? How is it realistic? How would you like me to respond?
How can we acknowledge it being received.


Ethical Concerns and Telehealth:
Remember our ethical imperatives for in-person therapy.
Rely on common factors
Rely on our professional standards of practice
AAMFT Code of Ethics
Coalition for Technology in Behavioral Science (CTiBS) TBH Competencies
Know and adhere to legal guidelines (federal and state)
Continue education and training.
Seek supervision.
Assessing Appropriateness for Telehealth:
Conduct an initial assessment of the client to determine if telehealth is appropriate.
Conduct ongoing assessment to determine appropriateness to receive services via teletherapy throughout the court of treatment.
Consider:
Current Mental and Emotional Status
Is the treatment model conducive to telehealth?
Is the current delivery of the service effective?
Does the client have the technological ability and resources necessary?
A client may be inappropriate for telehealth if:
Recurrently experiences, or is likley to experience, crises or emergencies.
Is a suicide risk, or likely to become a suicide risk.
Has a history of previous non-suicidal self-injury.
Is violent, or likely to become violent.
Risk Management in Telehealth:
Suicidality
Homicidality
Child Abuse/Neglect
Intimate Partner Violence
Animal Abuse
Physical Health Issues or Crises
Obtain your client's physical location at the start of each session.
Complete Address
Make, Model, Color of Car
Nearest Physical Location
Obtain a client's emergency contact at initial intake and review regularly
Physical Location
Distance from the Client (nearest ETA)
Obtain contact information for local emergency resources:
Local police and fire departments
Local Crisis Centers
Family Pediatrician/PCP
National Crisis Numbers
Safety Assessment:
Is it safe for them to return or remain home>
Are there weapons in the house?
Are the children in danger?
Is the violence escalating?
Are they unwilling to complete a safety plan?
Is their situation too severe and they require a higher level of care?
The most important intervention a therapist can use when working with a suicidal client is compassion for the pain they are in and patience in listening to their story.
What is a Safety Plan?
A safety plan is a prioritized written list of coping strategies and sources of support developed by a clinician in collaboration with clients who are at high risk for suicide.
A safety plan is not a 'no-suicide contract,' which is not recommended by experts in the field of suicide prevention.
As generally used, no-suicide contracts asks clients to promise stay alive without telling them how to stay alive.
Safety Planning:
Safety planning incorporates elements of four evidence-based suicide risk reduction strategies:
Reducing Access to Lethal Means
Teaching Brief Problem Solving and Coping Skills
Enhancing Social Support and Identifying Emergency Contacts
Using Motivational Enhancement to Increase likelihood of Engagement in Further Treatment
Assessing for Child Abuse on Video Session:
On a video call, observe how the house appears:
Look for ongoing sings that go beyond messiness.
Is perishable good sitting out after multiple calls?
Is there an absence of food or do family members appear to be losing weight?
Are there signs of pests or rodents?
Do children appear significantly unkempt or not bathed?
Look for signs of increased frustration.
This is a time of great stress for parents, ask questions to see how well a parent is coping.
"How are things going with the kids?"
"What are you getting to do during the day?"
Speak with the Children:
Ask for time to speak with the children along.
Observe their reactions to who and what is around them.
What is their level of focus?
Do they seem particularly stressed or emotional?
Is their behavior atypical?
Be Understanding:
If a parent is expressing desperation, be empathetic.
It is normal for parents to express frustration with statements such as 'being over it' or 'giving up.'
Red flags for a listener include:
Over rigidity
Persistent expression of negative emotions
Inability to see beyond their immediate concern
Extreme frustration that suggest possible escalation to physical aggression
Telepresence and Virtual Professionalism:
Telebehavioral health (TBH) professionals can demonstrate how to apply appropriate techniques to maximize therapeutic atmosphere in both physical and virtual environments as well as minimize distraction and interruptions.
Professionals can show how to approximate an in-person relationship and foster spontaneity through TBH.
Creating a Virtual Office:
When setting up your virtual office, we must consider the following:
Physical Location
Privacy
Lighting
Comfort
Where is your home based or online office located physically?
Is it near a power source?
Is there a way to 'close the door' to your office? (i.e., is there at least a door between your office space and other common areas in your location?)
Is it a high traffic area?
How can you create a distraction free environment?
Turn off anything that makes noise.
A sign outside the door can help remind others not to make noise during the session.
Avoid a space with lots of clutter on the desk.
Be mindful of what is behind you in the camera's view.
How can you create a quality video image?
Make sure you are well lit.
Are there shadows being cast on my face?
Am I lit well enough to see me clearly?
Find the best source of lighting.
Overhead light (may not be the best)
Desk Lamp
Single Floor Lamp (Often Good: 4-5 ft, bulbs point up to the ceiling)
Make sure your camera is well placed.
Eye level with the camera straight at you (ideal).
Practice good posture (use the picture-in-picture)
How can you create a therapeutic environment?
Find an office space with minimal distractions or a solid color background.
Be mindful of clothing to limit distractions.
Solid colors are best
Avoid busy patterns
Avoid large jewelry and hats
Before the First Session:
Provide clear instructions to your clients about how to join the session.
Become aware of common technical problems that could arise and how to trouble shoot for these problems.
If possible, host a test call.
Both therapist and client obtain contact information in case of technology failure.
During the First Session:
Ask for initial feedback for sound and video quality
Allow for more time for interviews
Remain attentive
Keep eyes on camera
Avoid distracting behavior and excessive movement
Turn off anything that makes noise
Remain in view of camera at all times
Be mindful of possible delays and lags in video
Speak slowly and deliberately
Understanding Telebehavioral Health Competencies:
Clinical Evaluation and Care
Virtual Environment and Telepresence
Technology
Legal & Regulatory Issues
Evidence-Based & Ethical Practice
Mobile Health Technologies Including Applications (Apps)
Telepractice Development
Telebehavioral Health Competency Levels:
Novice:
Identify and describe issues
Conduct basic screening
List pros and cons of using various technologies
Protect security, privacy, and confidentiality
Educate clients about fundamental TBH, laws, rules, regulations, ethical requirements, policies, procedures, assessments, interventions, standards and communication styles.
Proficient
Authority:
Demonstrate the basics of using computers, remote patient monitoring, social media and mobile health and the issues related to recommending the use of apps.
Discuss how to legally and ethically market their own services online.

item.title: 8. Treatment Planning
item.description:
A treatment plan refers to a written document that outlines the proposed goals, plan, and methods of therapy.


Diagnosis
Presenting Problem
Treatment Goals
Treatment Objectives
Treatment Strategy/Interventions
Frequency and Duration of Treatment
Evaluation: Measuring Progress and Outcomes


Goals are the building blocks of the treatment plan.
They are designed to be specific, realistic, and tailored to the needs of the person in therapy.
The language should also meet the person on their level.
Treatment Goals must be SMART
A SMART goal provides structure and a sense of direction that supports members in increasing their chances of achieving their treatment goal (s).
Specific
Measurable
Achievable
Relevant
Time-Bound


Goals are often broken down into objectives to support the person in therapy through the process of taking small, achievable steps toward the completion of the larger goal.


Goals usually also include the various techniques and interventions the mental health professional will implement to support achievement of the larger goal.


Frequency refers to how often will they attend - weekly, every two weeks, once a month, once, as needed, etc.
Duration refers to how long someone will attend 1 week, 1 month, 3 months, etc.


Is the client achieving progress?
Measured in several ways:
Client self-report
Therapist observation
Informal and Formal Assessment



Case conceptualization is a report based on information gathered, organized, and assessed to provide an explanation of client’s behavior or presenting problem.
It is the therapist perspective on the case.
Theory guides our case conceptualization or our view of the problem.
Family systems theory
Specific theoretical approach or model
Case Conceptualization is not a diagnosis in itself
There is a diagnostic component


Introduction of the client
Presenting concern
Background information
Systemic assessment
Genogram


Listen to client's story and presenting problem.
Gather information about how they understand their world
Obtain demographic information
Explore social, cultural, and historical context
Assess client's strengths and coping skills


Assess for risk, create a problem list
Diagnose
Apply theoretical orientation and hypothesize about the nature of the problem
Develop goals
Plan interventions


Apply theory to information gathers in initial interview
What is your theoretical understanding of the client?
What patterns of thinking, feeling, and action need to be addressed?
How does theory inform the treatment goals?
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Pre-Practicum (8189.11)/Lecture/8. Treatment Planning.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 9. Clinical Writing and Documentation
item.description:
Clinical documentation is a tool that guides the clinical process and aids in measuring outcomes.
Client documentation provides the content required for clients' clinical chart, also known as the medical record or health record.
Medical/Health records are legal documents and are protexted under the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPPA)



When you meet with a client for the first time, you gather background information and outline policies and procedures for the therapy process.
An Intake Note allows you to document a full biopsychosocial evaluation of your client, including the presenting problem, a mental status exam, and history.
Is also allows you to document other important events that occur during the intake process, such as obtaining informed consent for treatment, reviewing practice policies and procedures, and discussing important topics like confidentiality and billing.


Limits of confidentiality
Payment procedures
Telehealth Procedures
Contact outside of the session
Risks and benefits of therapy
Cancellation policies
Reasons for coming to therapy
Previous experiences with therapy
How current problems are affecting the client
Medical history
Current medications
Substance use history
Any previous mental health diagnoses
Mental health history (including hospitalizations, SI, HI)
Family History
Employment
Trauma history
Education history
Cultural Background
Support system
Any assessments they've taken
Legal history
Strengths
Religious/spiritual concerns
Mental Status Exam


A treatment plan refers to a written document that outlines the proposed goals, plan, and methods of therapy.
A Treatment Plan must be completed prior to completing a Progress Note for a client's first scheduled Therapy Session after their intake session.
This is because the Diagnosis, Objectives, and Frequency of Treatment are initially recorded on a client's Treatment Plan and pull forward into subsequent Progress Notes for the client.


Diagnosis
Presenting Problem
Treatment Goals
Treatment Objectives
Treatment Strategy/Interventions
Frequency and Duration of Treatment
Evaluation:
Measuring Progress and Outcomes


Progress notes, are the official record of each therapy session. They're meant to be shared with other members of the client's care team and insurers when requested.
Progress notes include information such as diagnoses, interventions used, and progress toward treatment plan goals.
SOAP Notes:
Subjective:
This section details the session from the client's perspective. It includes information like the client's feelings on their progress or lack of progress, the effectiveness of therapy, and goals for the session.
Objective:
Next, you'll list your own observations of the client's overall demeanor, attitude toward therapy, how they responded to the interventions you used, and any results you achieved.
Assessment:
In this section, you'll digest the information from the above two secions and record your professional opinion. Include data like your clinical impressions and evaluations of their progress towards treatment goals.
Plan:
Here's where you'll lay out your course of action moving forward. What do you plan to address in the next session, and what interventions do you plan on using? How does your plan relate to the client's short and long-term treatment goals?


Key Things:
All clinical documentation including progress notes should be completed within 24–48 hours of the session or non-clinical event.
Failure to complete notes in a timely manner is an ethical violation.
Progress notes and other clinical records are legal documents.
They fall under several laws and protections.
Notes and other forms of documentation should be written with care.
Write your notes 'as if the client is standing over your shoulder.'


Psychotherapy notes are defined as notes recorded by a health care provider who is a mental health professional documenting or analyzing the contents of conversation during a private counseling session or a group, joint, or family counseling session that are separated from the rest of the individual's medical record.
Therapist may keep psychotherapy notes separate from patient's records.
Written by mental health professional to document/analyze conversations during counseling session.
The following information is not to be included in process notes:
Medication
Start and stop of sessions
Modalities and frequency of treatment
Results of clinical tests
Summaries of diagnosis, functional status, treatment plan, symptoms, prognosis, and progress to date.


Contact notes are non-clinical notes used to document communication between a staff member and a client or a client's contact.
If you intend to charge for the communication, a Contact also creates a billing line item.


The termination note is a non-billable note template used to record a client's discharge from treatment.
A discharge note, also called a termination note, is a written summary held in the client's chart of what happened during the time the client was in your care.
The discharge note also includes recommendations for future mental health care needs and referrals to help the client follow through on these recommendations.
To write a discharge note we should include:
Reasons for termination, including referrals to new providers
Symptoms at the time of intake
Initial reasons for seeking treatment
Diagnosis
Treatment goals, past and present
Modalities and interventions used and how the client responded
Progress (or lack thereof) made during treatment
Tips on Writing Clinical Documents:

Client Progress Notes are Legal Documents
Use the correct words (avoid jargon)
Beware of acronyms and abbreviations
Keep your entry professional
Acknowledge that Progress Notes contain confidential information and should be kept in a secure location.
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Pre-Practicum (8189.11)/Lecture/9. Clinical Writing and Documentation.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 10. Intervention and Treatment Skills
item.description:
Referral
Making Contact
Planning
First Session
Inter-Session Analysis and Planning
Follow-Up Sessions (Focused on Assessment, Information Gathering, Rapport Building, Initial Treatment Planning)


Follow-Up Sessions
Working the Treatment Plan
Interventions
Assessment of Progress
Review of Goals and Time Efficiency
'Muddy Middle Phase'


Interventions are intentional behaviors or 'change strategies' introduced by the counselor to help clients implement problem management and move toward goals.


Self-Disclosure
Normalizing
Reframing
Using Questions
Providing Support
Confronting
Crisis Stabilization
Psychoeducation


Psychoeducation refers to the process of providing education and information to those seeking or receiving mental health services, such as people diagnosed with mental health conditions (or life-threatening/terminal illnesses) and their family members.

Briefing the patients about their illness
Problem-solving training
Communication training
Self-assertiveness training


Information about a specific diagnosis or problem. See the handouts section below for further resources.
Explaining and revieing treatment options and combinations of treatments such as medication and CBT.
Explaining psychological concepts and the interventions that will be used in your specific approach to counseling or psychotherapy.
Assessing a client's psychoeducational needs to identify gaps in the client's life skills.
Value clarification to ensure your client understands what gives their life meaning.
Emotional literacy training.
Boundary clarification and boundary setting to develop and maintain healthy relationships while moving on from unhealthy situations.
Conflict resolution skills to help maintain relationships.
Coping with grief following relationships' breakdown, divorce, bereavement, or job loss.
Developing parenting skills.


Reframing involves presenting an alternative possible explanation, interpretation or perception of an experience.
This new interpretation may then facilitate positive change.
Common reframes are related to negative or blaming statements, negative behaviors of system memebers, or difficult family situations.
There are three main goals of reframing:
The first is to change the meaning of the problem(s) or behaviors.
Reframes provide system members with a potentially different direction to proceed in their situation.
Successful reframes connect system members together through the creation of a joint system focus.
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Pre-Practicum (8189.11)/Lecture/10. Intervention and Treatment Skills.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 11. Working with Families with Children
item.description:
The presenting problem is a window into the system dynamics that contribute to the problem.
Parents are your allies as well as members of the system. This gives them a unique position.
Keep in mind ages and stages.
When parents bring children to therapy, they are likely experiencing helplessness. They are tired.
Don't go it alone! Assessment and treatment often require referrals.
Allow everyone's voice to be heard.


The family life cycle theory was first developed around 1960.
This theory uses the term Family Life Cycle to describe the emotional and intellectual stages you pass through from childhood to your retirement years as a member of a family. In each stage, you face challenges in your family life that allow you to build or gain new skills.



Infancy → Early Childhood → Middle Childhood → Adoelscence → Young Adulthood → Middle Age → Later-Life → Aging


Space:
Flexible use of space
Safety:
Physical space
limits and discipline
Shared Responsibility:
Collaboration with children and parents
Co-therapy
Expectations:
Time management
Structure


Parental Psychoeducation
Connection with the School System


Boundaries
Autonomy
Identity
Technology
Limits and Discipline


"The systematic use of a theoretical model to establish an interpersonal process wherein trained play therapists use the therapeutic powers of play to help clients prevent or resolve psychosocial difficulties and achieve optimal growth and development. "
Child play therapy is a way of being with the child that honors their unique developmental level and looks for ways of helping in the 'language' of the child - play.
Licensed mental health professionals therapeutically use play to help their clients, most often children ages 3 to 12 years, to better express themselves and resolve their problems.


Real Life & Nurturing
Doll House
Dolls for Doll House and Furniture if able
Medical Kit
Baby Dolls and Bottles
Tools
Fake Food and Utensils
Phone
Fake Money and Jewelry
Mailbox (Optional)
Blocks or Legos
Roll Up Road Rug and Cars
Ambulance
Binoculars
Jail and Police Car
Acting Out & Aggressive
Fake Weapons
Aggressive Animals and Puppets
Destroyable Items (such as phone book or egg cartons)
Creative & Emotional Release
Various Art Supplies and Construction Paper
Play Dough and Tools
Dress Up Items and Magic Wand
Other Puppets
Heroic/Villain Figures
Therapeutic Games
Kinetic Sand



Allow for exploration of real-life experiences including cultural values, traditions, and roles.
Facilitate contact with the child by gaining the child's interest and attention.
Permit reality testing/limit setting.
Provide the opportunity for development of self-control.
Facilitate exploration of the self and others.
Allow children to express their needs symbolically (without any need for verbalization)
Provide for expression of a wide range of feelings
Provide opportunities for insight/self-understanding
Allow for creative expression
Toys should also be durable, simple, and easy to operate, allow for success and are fun.

item.title: 12. Working with Families with Adolescents
item.description:
Taibbi (2022) Chapters 10 and 11 @roberttaibbiDoingFamilyTherapy2022
Diamond et al (1999) @diamondAlliancebuildingInterventionsAdolescents1999



Boundaries
Autonomy
Identity
Technology
Limits and Discipline
(Micucci, The Adolescent in Family Therapy)


Multidimensional Family Therapy
Strategic Family Therapy (Brief)
Functional Family Therapy


Interactional Change:
Interventions in which therapists allow or prompt family members to interact with one another naturally to assess family dynamics, and direct in-session interactions among members to promote more effective ways of relating.
Relational Reframe:
Therapist efforts to transform symptom-focused and/or adolescent-focused perceptions of clinical problems into a new understanding of those problems as being fundamentally relational, thereby motivating families to pursue changes in family relationships as the primary clinical solution.
Adolescent Engagement:
Interventions in which therapists join with adolescents by seeking their unique points of view, and foster treatment engagement by presenting family therapy as an opportunity to address personally meaningful issues within and outside the family.
Relational Emphasis:
Interventions that focus on the family as a whole, assessing systemic attributions and processes and intervening to improve overall family functioning.

item.title: 13. Working with Couples
item.description:
Read Patterson Chapter 9 @pattersonEssentialSkillsFamily2018
Read Taibbi (2022) Chapter 12 @roberttaibbiDoingFamilyTherapy2022



Telebehavioral health (TBH) professionals can demonstrate how to apply appropriate techniques to maximize therapeutic atmosphere in both physical and virtual environments as well as minimize distraction and interruptions.
Professionals can show how to approximate an in-person relationship and foster spontaneity through TBH.


When setting up your virtual office we must consider the following:
Physical location
Privacy
Lighting
Comfort
Where is your home based or online office located physically?
Is it near a power source?
Is there a way to 'close the door' to your office? (i.e., is there at least a door between your office space and other common areas in your location?)
Is it in a high traffic area?
How can you create a distraction free environment?
Turn off anything that makes noise
A sign outside the door can help remind others not to make noise during the session
Avoid a space with lots of clutter on the desk
Be mindful of what is behind you in the camera's view
How can you create a quality video image?
Make sure you are well lit.
Are there shadows being cast on my face?
Am I lit well enough to see me clearly?
Find the best source of lighting.
Overhead light (may not be the best)
Desk lamp
Single floor lamp (often good; 4-5 ft.; bulbs point up to the ceiling)
Make sure your camera is well placed.
Eye level with the camera straight at you (ideal)
Practice good posture (use the picture in picture)
How can you create a therapeutic environment?
Find an office space with minimal distractions or a solid color background.
Be mindful of clothing to limit distractions
Solid colors are best
Avoid busy patterns
Avoid large jewelry and hats





Learning to relax
Be present
Joining
Empathic listening
Curiosity
Attending skills


Assessment
Diagnosis
Case conceptualization
Treatment planning
Theory based interventions


Couples therapy is dyadic.
The relationship is the client.
It is important to have 1 (no more than 2) shared goals for therapy.
Both partners must participate.
We need to establish clear treatment objectives.


Session 1: Initial Intake Session (80 minutes)
Session 2: Individual Subsystem Session (Partner 1) (50 minutes)
Session 3: Individual Subsystem Session (Partner 2) (50 minutes)
Session 4: Conjoint Couples' Session (50 minutes)
Session 5 and Beyond: Conjoint Couples' Session


Welcome and Introductions
Orientation to Therapy and the First Session
Review Informed Consent and Clinic Policies
Question and Answer
Risk Assessment
Initial Understanding Presenting Problem
Begin Development of Treatment Goals
Reflection and Wrap-Up


Welcome and Quick Overview of the Session
Remind clients of no secrets policy.
Risk Assessment (Past and Present)
Assess for Infidelity
Review Individual Functioning
Understanding Presenting Problem from the Individual Perspective
Continue Development of Treatment Goals
Reflection and Wrap-Up


Before this session, therapist should have an initial systemic hypothesis and theory based conceptualization of the case.
During the session:
Provide clients with a summary of information gathered in sessions 1-3.
If necessary, discuss new information or secrets shared in sessions 2 and 3
Review and confirm treatment goals and objectives
Goals and objectives must be SMART
Continue assessment as needed for individuals and/or relationship
Begin intervention or working phase


WORK the treatment plan
Continue to evaluate your hypothesis and conceptualization between sessions
Interventions should be based on the client's presenting problem as well as your theoretical conceptualization

item.title: 14. Individual Work in a Family Context
item.description:
Read Taibbi (2022) Chapter 7
Read Taibbi (2022) Chapter 13 @roberttaibbiDoingFamilyTherapy2022
Read Patterson Chapter 12 @pattersonEssentialSkillsFamily2018



Intake and Interview
Referral
Making Contact
Planning
First Session
Inter-Session Analysis and Planning
Follow-Up Sessions (Focused on Assessment, Information Gathering, Rapport Building, Initial Treatment Planning)


Follow-Up Sessions
Working the Treatment Plan
Interventions
Assessment of Progress
Review of Goals and Therapy Effectiveness
"Muddle Middle Phase"


Determining the appropriate time to end therapy
This could be one or more sessions
Creating a plan for post therapy
Engaging in evaluation of therapy effectiveness
Termination also represents the closure of the professional
Relationship between client and therapist


Notify clients several sessions in advance
Summarize the therapy experience
Wish clients well
Possible memento - can be co-created
Review ethical requirements - in public won't speak first
Provide referral and emergency numbers
Open Door Policy


Clients have achieved goals
Clients have discontinued services
Clients have discontinued contact
Insufficient Progress
Planned Pause in Treatment
Client referred
Clinician closing practice/graduation


Mental Status Exam (MSE)
Risk Assessment
Biopsychosocial Assessment


How does this person's behavior exist in the current pattern of relational contexts?
What is the role of the diagnosis in maintaining balance in their current relationships?
How do the person's behaviors and physiology interact and reciprocally affect one another?


Diagnostic labels may be used as a source of identity eclipsing strengths, capabilities, resilience, power, and agency.
We can use alternative client-generated descriptions of the problem and identify to access their strengths, power and agency.

item.title: 15. Self-Care and Self of Therapist Revisited
item.description:
Read Taibbi (2022) Chapter 14 @roberttaibbiDoingFamilyTherapy2022


Create a consistent plan to engage in mentally, emotionally, physically, and spiritually nourishing activities.
Schedule restorative rejuvenation when anticipated stress.
Prepare a list of emergency strategies for unanticipated stress.
Meet regularly with peers or colleagues for support.
Evaluate counselor-specific professional, perceptual, and personal challenges to self-care.
Record and review successes.
Include self-compassion as an essential element of self-care.


Protect your mornings (or whenever you wake up)
Less cortisol, more intentionality
Go outside
perspective, context and something larger than this.
Be active
In body, mind, and spirit.
cultivate relationships
Those that are edifying and healthy
Nurture gratitude
What is one thing, right now, that is going well?
Detox:
if navigating addictions be wise and safe
Spend time with animals
low stress hormones and high comfort
Simplify:
(less is more)
be mindful of decision
Fatigue and cognitive overload
Admire art
the gift of feeling transported
Laugh
Pure humor = a sustaining force
Foster Humility and Extend Grace
Self-righteousness and hubris = unhelpful
Sleep
To cleanse and repair brain and body
Clarify intentions:
How can i refrain from causing harm, how can I contribute meaningfully?
