item.title: My Declaration of Self-Esteem
item.description:
In all the world, there is no one else exactly like me. There are persons who have some parts like me, but no one adds up exactly like me. Therefore, everything that comes out of me is authentically mine because I alone chose it.
I own everything about me: my body, including everything it does; my mind, including all its thoughts and ideas: my eyes, including the images of all they behold; my feelings, whatever they may be: anger, joy, frustration, love, disappointment, excitement; my mouth, and all the words that come out of it: polite, sweet or rough, correct or incorrect; my voice, loud or soft; and all my actions, whether they be to others or to myself.
I own my fantasies, my dreams, my hopes, my fears.
I own all my triumphs and successes, all my failures and mistakes.
Because I own all of me, I can become intimately acquainted with me. By so doing, I can love me and be friendly with me in all my parts. I can then make it possible for all of me to work in my best interests.
I know there are aspects about myself that puzzle me, and other aspects that I do not know. But as long as I am friendly and loving to myself, I can courageously and hopefully look for the solutions to the puzzles and for ways to find out more about me.
However I look and sound, whatever I say and do, and whatever I think and feel at a given moment in time is me. This is authentic and represents where I am at that moment in time.
When I review later how I looked and sounded, what I said and did, and how I thought and felt, some parts may turn out to be unfitting. I can discard that which is unfitting, and keep that which proved fitting, and invent something new for that which I discarded.
I can see, hear, feel, think, say, and do. I have the tools to survive, to be close to others, to be productive, and to make sense and order out of the world of people and things outside of me.
I own me, and therefore, I can engineer me.
I am me and I am okay.
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Experiential Family Therapy/Satir/My Declaration of Self-Esteem.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Satir's Growth Model (Human Validation Process Movement)
item.description:
Virginia Satir (1916-1988)
In the late 1950 s, she joined Don Jackson, Jay Haley, and others in developing the Mental Research Institute (MRI).
Satir wrote one of the first books about family therapy, Conjoint Family Therapy, in which she provided transcripts of how she worked.


Every person has resources available to them, but when troubled, they do not usually utilize these resources to their utmost abilities.
Self-Mandala:
The individual is at the center, and surrounding them are the eight universal human resources: spiritual, contextual, nutritional, interactional, sensual, emotional, intellectual, and physical.

Each part is interconnected. The less these 8 areas are given energy and time, the lower a person's self-esteem.
When people experience low self-esteem, they attempt to cope by using Survival Stances.
These stances help people temporarily deal with presumed threats and protect their self-worth. The stances help to protect us, but do not help us or other people to grow and thrive. The four survival stances are:
Placating (Placator):
Occurs when people discount themselves and privilege the other person and the context. Individual tends to apologize a lot, feels worthless, and may become depressed or suicidal. They tend to be quite sensitive and caring.
The placating stance discounts self and privileges the other person and the context.
Blaming (Blamer):
Privileges self and context while discounting the other.
To cope with low self-esteem, the person attacks another individual.
On the outside the individual seems assertive, but on the inside feel isolated and alone.
Their experience leads them to sometimes feel paranoid and even potentially homicidal.
Super-Reasonable (Computer):
Privileges the context and discounts the self and others.
Focuses on the rules rather than on emotions and relationships.
Very data driven and people appreciate them for their intellect.
To offset their internal vulnerability, the super-reasonable person doesn't allow themselves to connect with any emotions. This can lead to a rigidness that may be displayed via obsessive-compulsive behaviors.
Irrelevant (Distractor):
Discounts self, other, and context.
Engage in distraction to avoid having to deal with their low self-esteem.
People may describe them as fun and spontaneous. However, you cannot have a serious or straightforward conversation with them. This leads to a psychological orientation of confusion and possible psychosis.
The goal of Satir's therapy is to help people enhance their own and others' self-esteem. When we do so, we function from a Congruent (Congruence) communication stance. This is the healthiest position we can operate from.


The Satir Growth Model is a strength-based approach, focusing on the existing resources that family members bring with them.
Faulty coping strategies maintain problematic interactions.
Therapy provides a safe space for people to choose alternative ways of coping. Therapy increases people's self-esteem, leading them to be able to lean into their uniqueness and provide a space for their loved ones to feel comfortable in their own uniqueness as well.
Whatever techniques the therapists uses, they are designed to help raise awareness within and between people in hopes of increasing self-esteem and self-worth so that people feel freer to be authentic. (Congruence)
Self-Esteem Maintenance Kit:
Detective Hat:
Used when there is something new that the person wants to understand better. It helped them shift away from judging an experience to exploring it.
Medallion:
Two-sided and says 'yes' on one side and 'no' on the other. It is intended to help the person recognize that they can say either word, depending on what they truly want, so they can maintain their integrity.
Wand (Empowering wand, courage stick, wishing wand):
Helps people move from inaction based on fear to action based on desire.
Golden Key:
Opens any door - helping the person ask questions they might not have previously, so the unsayable, and do the undoable.
Wisdom Box:
Helps connect the person to the wider world and all that has come before them.
Experiential therapists are interactive in the therapy room. They try to use their whole self for contact. This includes adopting an I-Thou Perspective, where they try to promote human-to-human interaction.
Since one of the main goals of therapy is to help the client become more congruent, it is important for the therapist to engage the client congruently. The therapist must be a real person who helps model a way of being for the client.
Experiential therapists conceptualize a few main processes:
Status Quo:
The family is currently in this process, and is leading to difficulties bringing them to therapy.
Foreign Element:
The family's expression of the desire to change.
Chaos:
The therapist's introduction of novelty into the system.
Integration:
Family members put what they learn from therapy into practice.
Practice:
Involves trying out these learnings.
New Status Quo:
- New homeostasis takes hold.

The therapist raises the intensity of interactions so that people encounter their own experiences and can thus become more authentic. Therapy then helps people to allow others to be more authentic.
Sculpting:
Sculpting helps people get in touch with their inner experience and express this experience to others in a way that bypasses the typical spoken word.
Sculpting can be done in one of two primary ways:
The client is asked to sculpt their family based on their experience of what it is like to be part of this family now. Then the therapist can sculpt the family based on their own inner picture of the family's experience.
Family members are asked to place other people in physical poses spatially located around the room and then to position themselves somewhere within. This provides the family with a new way of engaging with self and other. This allows for new meanings to come forth, where people can become more authentically themselves.
The therapist will begin with one member of the family. The choice of person will depend on the family organization, the presenting problem, and the therapeutic process. Once that person has presented their image of the family, the therapist acts as a guide for each family member, bringing forth their perceptions of this picture and what it represents about the various relationships in the family. Therapist then shifts to another family member to explore their experience, as every family member unique has their own way of seeing and being in the family.
Therapist may also end the sculpt by having family members sculpt their desired picture of the family. This sculpt shifts the energy in the room from a focus on past problems and dysfunction to a future functional and supportive arrangement of relationships.
Satir viewed people as housing energy and as able to transfer this energy through physical connections with one another.
Family Reconstruction:
Designed to help an individual connect better to the historical and psychological interconnections of their family. By seeing self and family of origin with a new perspective, the individual might then feel more freedom to engage in new possibilities for the future.
Star:
The person whose relationship with the family is being explored and worked on.
The therapist prepares the reconstruction by talking with the star about their family history. This involves developing a Family Map, or the primary family that can include the grandparents, a Family Life Chronology, highlighting three generations of the star's family, including important dates and historical events (similar to the genogram), and the Wheel of Influence, a chart including all the people who influenced the star when they were growing up.
The therapist ('guide') begins the family reconstruction by telling the star's story; then sculpts the family of origin, the star's parents' families of origin, and the star's parents' relationship; and then resculpts the star's family of origin.
The overall goal is to increase the star's self-esteem so they are empowered to engage with themselves and others in new and more productive ways. This should engender more hope in them for their future.
Parts Party:
Based on the notion that people have many faces (or aspects of self), a parts party helps people to accept that they also have many possibilities. Some of our parts may be lying dormant, and when we access them, we increase our resources.
The parts party helps people to acknolwedge, accept, transform, and integrate their parts.
Other participants play the role of the various parts to help the person move from internal processes to more interpersonal processes.



"The Growth Model," where the focus was on helping people access their inner resources as opposed to, "The Medical Model," where the emphasis was on pathology and symptom reduction.
Satir likened the role of a family therapist to that of a gardener in that people are like seeds, they carry all the resources they need for growth if nurtured and protected from blocks to their growth. She believed that the key resource for each person was their Unique Spirit from which emanated other resources such as: self-awareness, self-acceptance, change, choice, compassion, curiosity, determination, hope, love, and wisdom.
"The question for me was never whether (people) had spirits, but how I could contact them... It was as though I saw through to the inner core of each being, seeing through to the inner core of each being, seeing the shining light of the spirit trapped in a thick black cylinder of limitation and self-rejection. My effort was to enable the person to see what I saw; then, together, we could turn the dark cylinder into a large, lighted screen and build new possibilities." (Satir, 1988, p. 340-341)
Her goals for family therapy included helping the individual members increase their sense of worth and value by accessing their inner resources and by decreasing any emotional blocks. And for the family as a whole, she saw the goal as being to increase congruent communication and heart connections.
She began to observe that there were some universal unspoken rules that blocked the individual members from functioning at full capacity and also hindered the connections between members. These were:
It is not okay to see what is going on in the family.
It is not okay to feel what you feel.
It is not okay to talk about what you see and feel.
It is not okay to ask for what you want.
It is not okay to take risks.
She would observe the family members and their interaction and if she detected any of these rules in the family, she would help them break them by asking questions such as:
"What do you see going on between your and your ?"
"What are you aware of feeling at this moment?"
"Can you tell your ___ what you are feeling?"
"Can you ask your ___ for what you want?"
"I invite you to use your courage and say what you see happening in your family."
She also helped them to make better connections with each other by decreasing their defensiveness. Satir identified the primary defensive stances as Blaming (Blamer), Placating (Placator), Distracting, and being Super-Reasonable (Computer).
Forms of Fight:
Blaming (Blamer) (This is all your fault.)
Generalizing (You always think you are right.)
Labeling (You are so stupid.)
Threatening (You better shape up or else.)
Physically Attacking the Other.
Forms of Flight:
Placating (Placator) (Do what you wish, my needs don't matter.)
Being Super-Reasonable (Computer) (I don't care what you feel, just give me the facts.)
Emotionally Withdrawing (Physically present but not emotionally present.)
Physically Withdrawing (Leaving the room or hanging up on someone.)
Cutting-Off (Refusing to talk to the other for days or longer.)
Within a family system, these defenses can be played out in interactional patterns such as:
Blame - Blame
Blame - Withdraw
Placate - Placate
Blame - Placate
Blame - Distract
Withdraw - Withdraw


Satir developed a process for helping people change and become more connected. Her process is described as having six phases:
Phase 1 - Making Contact
Satir would reach out using her body position, eye contact, and facial expression to make contact with each member. She would also consciously work to connect from her spirit to theirs.
Phase 2 - Validating
Satir worked to help people feel validated in many ways such as reflecting their feelings, affirming their values and highlighting their inner resources. Examples include:
"You feel scared because your son got suspended from school."
"You value education."
"You are courageous to seek help."
Phase 3 - Facilitating Awareness
Satir had many different ways that she would attempt to bring awareness to a family about their defensive patterns in a non-blaming way.
Sculpting:
Satir placed the members in body positions to give them a picture of their defensive behavior.
For the blaming stance, she would position the person leaning toward another and pointing at them and for the placating stance, she would position the person down on one knee with their head down and their hand up in a pleading position.
Satir would also bring awareness to members by exploring their inner experiences. She used the metaphor of an iceberg to help the family therapist to conceptualize the inner level so experience driving defensive behaviors.
Above the water line were the inner levels of experience such as feelings, perceptions, expectations, beliefs, and yearnings. (What meaning are you giving to what your ___ said that is causing you to feel hurt? Is that a familiar place for you to go to when someone is disappointed in you? What is it you yearn for?)
Phase 4 - Promoting Acceptance
One of the ways that satir promoted acceptance was through 'normalizing,' that is, reassuring the family member that what they were experiencing was normal. ("It is normal to...")
Another way that she promoted acceptance was by 'bridging' between conflicting parties. ("I am hearing that is is not easy for _, I would be interested to know how life was for you when you were their age?")
Phase 5 - Eliciting Positive Choices and Changes
Once Satir observed that the family members were aware of and accepting of their unhelpful patterns, she would lead them into seeing new possibilities for their interactions.
After sculpting the family, she would ask them to each to stand in a balanced way and look at each other. She would then guide them in a dialogue helping them to express themselves in non-defensives ways. Other times she would simply have them sit face to face and she would guide the dialogue between them.
"What happens for you when your says you choose over your ? You feel... Did you know that your felt __? What happened for you when you heard them express their feelings? You long to be more connected with them. You miss them. How do you feel to hear how much they miss you?"
Phase 6 - Reinforcing Change
Satir would often combine verbal responses with some supportive touch to reinforce a positive shift.
The therapist also needs to work on their own personal growth. This is true for working with individuals but it is even more true when working with families as the chances of being triggered by your own family experience are even greater.
As Satir used to say, "You are the most important instrument in the room!"


Under threat and reward, change is painful: change is viewed as unnatural, the unknown is feared, the status quo is maintained, life's natural 'flow' is blocked, and the familiar is valued despite discomfort.
The seed model has people viewing change more positively; as naturally occurring at a variety of levels (from cellular to cosmic) and as scary, but offering new opportunities. Discomfort is seen as a signal for change.
Therapists using the seed model keep in mind that families entering therapy are problem-focused and will maintain the status quo as a necessary survival behavior.
Therapist should make contact with each person to communicate a climate of acceptance (e.g., people do the best they can) and hear them out to discover 'what is.'
Understanding the status quo stage is essential to clarify how the change process gets started or is blocked. This stage is explored further by examining resistance and readiness concepts in detail.
The coin of change has resistance and readiness as its head and tail sides. Experientially, we may want to change in one moment and fear or sabotage it in the next. Then status quo is considered a trance, accounting for change resistance as well as a medium in which change may be fostered.


Changing circumstances elicit shifts in perception, which in turn stimulate changes in thinking, feeling, and acting. But when circumstances shift back, behavior also reverts.
Perception can appear to create change of behavior when the meaning of an event is reframed, but the underlying pattern is not altered. Altering the underlying pattern requires dealing with resistance to change.
Resistance is a coping behavior intended to preserve the organism rather than obstruct change. Reframing resistance in terms of its positive intention.
The way we are socialized has us, "Gradually acquiring a variety of commitments which constrain the person into following a consistent pattern of behavior."
The effect is to develop a lifestyle that stabilizes the events in our lives, our interdependence of meaning of these events, and the way we define ourselves, as well as predisposing us to seek consistent situations.
Experientially, change involves invoking the unfamiliar. Intellectualizing, avoiding feelings, compulsive activity, impatience about change, and dwelling in the past are all ways of dealing with the confusion by maintaining the status quo.
The tasks at this stage are to cope with the threat to past security and sense of competence and self-esteem; deal with feelings of loss and longing for the past.
Conservative impulse, the will to change has to overcome an impulse to restore the past, to resist the change. Survival depends on this impulse. By stabilizing perceptions, the conservative impulse enhances the ability to learn from experience. Only when it does not fit this construct is its 'newness' experienced.
Readiness refers to what Satir considered the unstable balance of elements in the Status Quo.
Persons considering change are more open to consciousness-raising interventions, more aware of themselves, more conscious of their psychic distress, and more likely to seek out information about their problem.
Variation in readiness for change (even in one person) depends on social circumstances, timing, opportunity, location, change goal, the degree of social pressure or support for the goal, alternations in environments circumstances, developmental crises, and physical or emotional pain.
Four patterns emerge reflecting the relative influence of these readiness factors. These patters are based on the degree of difficulty involved in making the change and the degree of responsibility the person is wiling to take for making the change.
Preemptive Change:
This pattern describes 'overnight' change. The inordinate strength of the motivating influences lowers the degree of difficulty in making the change. The degree of responsibility for the change is also low.
The change in circumstances preempts issues of loss (leaving family and friends), self-efficacy ("Can I do it?"), and self-esteem ("Am I worth the effort?") that are ordinarily addressed in making changes. Problems maintaining the change may require attention at a later point in the change process. Change literally 'happens' to us in this pattern, but we have little sense of ownership of it.
Self-Managed Change:
In this pattern, the influences motivating the change are less extreme or immediate than those noted in the preemptive patter. The person is influenced to take a conscious and self-responsible approach to change and is required to deal with one or more of the issues of loss, self-efficacy, and self-esteem in order to resolve the resistance to change.

Experiential family therapies include four approaches:
Satir's Growth Model (Human Validation Process Movement)
Symbolic-Experiential Family Therapy
Emotionally Focused Therapy (EFT)
Internal Family Systems Model


Targeting emotional transactions
Warmth, empathy, and the therapist's use of self
Individual and family focus




Five Communication Stances:
Congruent (Congruence)
Able to acknowledge what you are thinking and feeling, what the other person may be thinking or feeling
Placating (Placator)
Ignore their own thoughts and feelings and focus on the thoughts and feelings of others. Quick to put aside their own emotions for the sake of others. They often are so quick to deny their own feelings. Your job as a therapist is to help them learn to acknowledge their own thoughts and feelings but also the thoughts and feelings of others.
They do not want to increase tension when needs are not met and risk having tension in the relationship.
Minimizes self
People-pleasing tendencies
Needs less directive therapy methods
Blamer
Assert their needs and desires while minimizing those of others.
You will find placator and blamer married in therapy because their stances are complimentary.
Your job as a therapist is to help blamer to learn how to acknowledge and develop empathy for the thoughts and needs of others.
Minimizes other
Needs to increase awareness of others' thoughts and feelings
Direct confrontation often strengthens therapeutic relationship (they will find placators as weak)
Super-Reasonable (Computer)
When they are feeling threated, they revert to the context. Some logical external system. They are typically not emotional.
Minimizes self and others
Logic and rules reign supreme
Therapists must refer to context to gain validity
Therapist should understand the logic and/or rules they use to organize their world. Therapists may need to refer to this context in order to gain validity. It is important to understand the logic of the system, but at the same time bringing in recognition and value to their own needs AND the needs and desires of others are valid. Learning how to teach them how to acknowledge all three areas of functioning.
Irrelevant (Distractor)
Under distress, they distract. The class clown. When tension rises in a relationship, they distract with humor or something off-topic. They may distract. They are more likely to see this in schizophrenia.
Your job as a therapist is to get the client reengaged with the difficult topic that they would prefer to just avoid in one way or another.
Minimizes self, others, and context.
No consistent grounding in self, other, or context
Must increase ability to recognize thoughts and feelings of self and others.
The focus for the therapist is on creating safety. Help them learn to recognize, and not be afraid of their thoughts and the thoughts of others.
Stances acknowledge or minimize three realities:
Self
Other
Context
When we feel unsafe, we revert back to one of these communication stances. These are the stances used when someone is frightened. When we don't feel safe as children, we evolve communication stances to survive when we do not feel safe when we are young.
You can use the communication stances to help better understand how to intervene, or how to communicate with your client.
When you are working with a placator, be cautious if you are going to be making a suggestion it may help to give options. "Which do you think is the best fit or might work for you?" Ask them to give voice to their thoughts and opinions because they will be very quick even to please the therapist. Their task us to learn to assert themselves in a healthy way, how can they assert their needs so that they don't become resentful, depressed (needs do not get taken care of because they are not advocating for themselves)



Therapy involves going through stages several times.



Can be a new way of looking at the interactions and how to communicate in a more congruent way.

Therapist's self
The way the therapist is in the room.
Ingredients of an interaction
Whenever the therapist is talking with clients about difficult situations and interactions with others, they ask a series of questions. Go back to the iceberg. What do I hear and see? What is happening at the behavioral level without any interpretation. What are the meanings I make of this? What are they saying? What feelings do I have about these meanings I am making? What feelings do I have about those feelings? What defenses do I use/am I using? How does this trigger me and what kind of defensive behaviors might I bring, that makes them …. ?
What are the rules within the system about how to comment about what's going on? What is allowed and what is appropriate? How am I responding and what part do I play in the system?
Facilitating emotional expression
What is allowed and what is appropriate? What is my response and what am I doing in this situation?
Congruent expression, without the communication stances, turn chairs to each other directly, hold hands, make eye contact
Softening family rules
When families have rigid rules about who can say what, when, where, and how, she will soften some of these to create more space for everyone's particular way of communicating in a comfortable way to hopefully reduce the use of communication stances.
Communication enhancement
Helping each member of the family learn to communicate congruently in stressful circumstances, even when they do feel threatened by their partner or their child,
Rather than reverting to a survival stance, to help them learn how to be fully congruent and present and to have more effective communications.
Sculpting or spatial metaphor
She would position each person in the family to metaphorically represent their role. (Example: A placator may be sculpted as being on their knees and begging, the blamer may be there pointing their finger angrily at someone, the irrelevant type might be in a strange position far off from everybody else, the super-reasonable might be sitting there in a very cold, distant, "I am citing the rulebook")
Because it is more visual than verbal - you can add a verbal element to it by having each person say a motto of theirs (eg., "Please be nice to me," "Do what I say," "Follow the rules,") - that represents their position in the family. It can push past the survival stances, intellectual defenses, the family could sculpt themselves.
It can be a powerful intervention.
Touch
Touch clients, help clients learn to hold and touch each other in nurturing ways,



The therapist must be aware of cultures that have different attitudes towards emotional expression.
The therapist adjusts to the client's level of intimacy.


Used commonly in the LGBTQ community
Focus is on the burden of societal rejection when being the authentic self.

Theory:
Describe the following elements of the Satir model and emotionally focused therapy:
Process of therapy
Therapeutic relationship
Case conceptualization
Goal setting
Interventions
Case Conceptualization and Treatment Plan
Complete a theory-specific case conceptualizations and treatment plans for Satir family therapy and emotionally focused couples therapy using templates that are provided.
Research
Provide an overview of significant research findings for Satir family therapy and emotionally focused couples therapy.
Diversity
Analyze strengths, limitations, and appropriate applications for using experiential approaches with clients in relation to their social location/diverse identities, including but not limited to ethnic, racial, and/or sexual/gender identity diversity.
Cross-Theoretical Comparison
Compare how experiential therapies utilize interpersonal patterns (IPs) with other approaches described in this book.


Integrating systemic theory with humanism, experiential family therapists are noted for their warmth and direct emotional engagement with clients. These approaches include:
The Satir Model
Emotionally Focused Therapy (EFT)
EFT integrates experiential, systemic, and attachment theories to help couples and families create emotional safety to foster wellness interaction patterns.
Symbolic-Experiential Family Therapy
Carl Whitaker developed symbolic-experiential therapy, which focuses on symbolic meanings and emotional exchanges within the family using a balance of warmth and confrontation to promote change.



Whereas systemic, strategic, structural, and cognitive-behavioral family therapists primarily track behavior interaction sequences, experiential family therapists focus more on the affective or emotional layer of those same interactions - while still attending to behavior and cognitions.
Assessment and interventions target the emotional exchanges between family members and significant others in relation to the presenting problem.


Experiential family therapists use warmth and empathy in building relationships with clients.
Therapists use themselves - their personhood - to make this strong affective connection with clients.
This approach creates a sense of safety that allows clients to explore areas of emotional vulnerability.


Experiential family therapies affress individual and family concerns as distinct sets of problems.
In contrast, systemic, structural, and integenerational therapies conceptualize individual systems as part of the family system. They assume that individual symptoms will resolve if the family system is treated.




She began her career in family therapy at the Mental Research Institute (MRI) working alongside Jay Haley, Paul Watzlawick, Richard Fisch, and the other leading family therapists in Palo Alto.
Her therapy focused on fostering individual growth as well as improving family interactions.



The Communication Stances in the Satir model offer a clinician an efficient and effect means of conceptualizing how best to communicate and interact with the client.
She describes 4 communication survival or coping stances:
Blaming (Blamer)
Placating (Placator)
Super-Reasonable (Computer)
Irrelevant (Distractor)
These stances develop in childhoodand reveal how a person communicates under stress, especially when they do not feel emotionally safe in intimate relationships.
A person can use more than one, but typically a person uses one style predominantly.
Each stance acknowledges or minimizes three basic realities:
Self
Other
Context
The goal is to move people toward Congruent (Congruence) communication in which they respectfully balance the needs of self and others while responding appropriately within and acknowledging the context .

item.title: Self of the Therapist Reflections
item.description:
Making Contact
When are you able to make authentic contact as Satir describes? Describe relationships in which you feel most authentic and able to fully connect with another. Why does this connection matter? What helps you to 'make contact' with others? (Research Citations/Books/@gehartMasteringCompetenciesFamily2017)
Communication Stances
With a partner or on your own, identify the survival communication stances that each member of your family of origin used when there was a loss of relational safety. What contexts or situations are most likely to trigger you to feel unsafe and revert to your survival stance? In what contexts have you learned to maintain congruent communication even when you feel threatened? (Research Citations/Books/@gehartMasteringCompetenciesFamily2017)
Six Levels of Experience
With a partner or on your own, identify a recent stressful event that made you feel strong negative emotion of some kind. Use the iceberg to describe the multiple layers of experience related to the one event. Are some levels incongruent with other layers? Does identifying the different layers of experience help you understand the situation differently? Do you see any new options?
Building Self-Esteem or Self-Worth
@satirNewPeoplemaking1988
Relax for a moment now. Close your eyes and feel your condition now. How are you feeling about yourself? What has happened or is happening at the moment? How are you responding to what is happening? How are you feeling about how you are responding? If you are feeling tight, give yourself a message of love, physically relax yourself and consciously be in touch with your breathing. Now open your eyes. You will feel stronger as a result.
Since the feeling of low worth has been learned, it can be unlearned, and something new learned in its place. The possibility for this learning lasts from birth to death, so it is never too late.
Other
Stop reading for a few minutes and think about some families you know that would fit the description “troubled.” Did the family you grew up in have some of these characteristics: Was your family at times cold, deadening, super polite, secretive, confusing? What are the characteristics of the family you are living in now? Can you discover any signs of trouble that you haven’t been aware of before?
Can you think of a family that you would call nurturing at least part of the time? Can you remember a time recently when your family could be described as nurturing? Try to remember how it felt to be in your family then. Do these times happen often?
Invite your family members to try the following experiment with you. Take a partner, then tell one another your feelings ("Right now, I feel scared/tight/embarrassed/happy/etc."). Each partner simply thanks the other without judging or commenting. You thus hear one another's feelings so you can know each other better. We need a lot of practice to break the taboo against sharing our feelings. Practice as much as you can with people you trust. Now, tell each other what makes you each feel low, or high. You may find new dimensions to the people you have been living with all these years and feel closer or more real to them as a result. When you have finished the exercise, give yourself permission to share what happened for you.
Tonight, when the family has settled around the table for dinner, notice what is happening to your feelings about yourself when other members speak to you. There will be some remarks to which you have no special response. However, you may be surprised to find that even "Pass the potatoes, please" can give you a feeling of or depreciation, depending on the speaker's tone of voice, facial expression, timing (did the message interrupt you, or ignore something you said?), and how good you are feeling about yourself. If you are feeling good about yourself, you may find that you have a lot of options for how you respond. If you are feeling low, however, you might find that your options are limited (see chapter 6 on communication). Halfway through dinner, change the perspective. Listen to what you are saying to others. Try to be in the other's shoes and imagine how you might feel if you were talked to as you are doing now. Would you, for instance, feel loved and valued?
Tomorrow night explain this little game to the other members of the family and invite them to join you. It will be helpful to read this chapter aloud before you do this as a family. After dinner, talk together about what you discovered and how you felt.
Take a Saturday morning or a Sunday afternoon. The topic is “What new has been happening to me lately?” Everyone has a chance to share, not just the children. Leadership can rotate among the members.
Don’t forget the celebration party afterward. You will probably find these times can be very enjoyable. You might try creating a funny or romantic theme, for instance.
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Experiential Family Therapy/Satir/Self of the Therapist Reflections.md

item.description:
Happens when people restrict themselves to a rigid way of believing and doing. Negative craziness leads people to continue behaving in ways that are not working without being able to see new possibilities.
When people act in ways that conform to limiting norms.
Symbolic-Experiential Family Therapy

Occurs when people don't restrict themselves to rigid roles and rules. Rather, they can be spontaneous and allow themselves to experience the full possibilities of their being. This type of craziness leads to growth.
When people act in ways that conform to limiting norms.
Symbolic-Experiential Family Therapy

item.title: Dancing with the family: a symbolic-experiential approach
item.description:
Bibliography: Whitaker, C. A., & Bumberry, W. M. (1988). Dancing with the family: A symbolic-experiential approach. Brunner/Mazel.
Type: Book
Title: Dancing with the family: a symbolic-experiential approach,
Author: Whitaker, Carl A.; Bumberry, William M.;
Publisher: Brunner/Mazel,
Location: New York,
Year: 1988
ISBN: 978-0-87630-496-9


Keywords: Case studies; Experiential psychotherapy; Family Therapy; Family psychotherapy; Need to Read; methods
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Experiential Family Therapy/Whitaker/@whitakerDancingFamilySymbolicexperiential1988.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Symbolic-Experiential Family Therapy
item.description:
Attempts to free people from perceived restraints so they can be whole and fully functional.
Carl Whitaker, developer of the model, sometimes called it a 'therapy for the absurd.'
He believed people limited themselves based on not accepting their full selves.
He was opposed to theory. He believed if a theory became regimented, so did the therapist. This would be problematic because the therapist would be unable to be fully present and spontaneous, which is the goal for both family therapists and clients. The more people can allow themselves to be spontaneous, the more authentic they will likely be.
Absurdity:
Happens when people realize what they have been thinking is not as fearful or destructive as they originally imagined.


Families tend to have problems because they are engaging in rigid and repetitive ways of interacting. People have developed limiting roles. Operating only from this one role, people don't access all aspects for self. However, people are not usually aware they are operating from such a limiting role. Further, they are not connected to their emotions and how they suppress them.
This restriction of experiencing was considered crazy.
Craziness:
Can be viewed in two ways:
Negative Craziness:
Happens when people restrict themselves to a rigid way of believing and doing. Negative craziness leads people to continue behaving in ways that are not working without being able to see new possibilities.
Positive Craziness:
Occurs when people don't restrict themselves to rigid roles and rules. Rather, they can be spontaneous and allow themselves to experience the full possibilities of their being. This type of craziness leads to growth.
Symptoms happen in families when members develop expectations of themselves and others that are limiting. They've learned how to be with one another using fused or rigid boundaries. When there are fused boundaries, members become overly dependent on one another. They then are unable to assert their individuality. With rigid boundaries, members feel isolated from one another. Each extreme boundary limits people's expectation of self and others, where they are unable to access the full range of their experience.
These extreme boundaries get pushed further away from the center when the family experience some type of stress. Some stress comes from outside the system, stress also happens when the family moved to a different development stage.
Families may also have intergenerational stress. In these situations, family members tighten up and try to become even more rigid in how they view themselves and others, as this is how they think they can better handle their problems. When they do so, they restrict the possible alternatives that could help the family to grow.


The goal of symbolic-experiential family therapy is about growth rather than symptom remission. Symptoms are a result of restrictions. When the family grows through the development of autonomy in its members, individual symptoms are likekly to recede.
Therapy attempts to enrich people's lives, pushing them to experience happiness, sadness, anger, jealousy, joy, and the full range of all human emotions. Therapy is not about education but rather about experiencing, helping people to move beyond arbitrarily placed limits on what they can think, say, or do.
The therapist is considered a 'coach' but not a player on the team. They will challenge people to examine the interdynamics happening in the family, but family members always have free choice in what they do.
- Whitaker discussed two types of battles that happen in therapy:
- Battle for Structure:
- There is a determination of what therapy will look like. In this battle, the therapist must win. Families come to therapy and try to recapitulate their interactional process, incorporating the therapist into it. It is exactly this process that is maintaining the problem and that needs to be altered. If the therapist capitulated to the family's demands, they would be reinforcing the dysfunctional family process.
- From the start of therapy, the therapist needs to send the message that something different will happen.
- Battle for Initiative:
- There is a determination of what family members will do in their lives. This battle needs to be won by the family. Symbolic-experiential family therapists do not try to tell family members what to do or how to live their lives. If they do so, they would be discouraging family members from being authentic. The family must take the initiative in how they want their life to go, with the family members actively supporting this push.

Symbolic-experiential family therapy attempts to shake up the family. The therapist increases the anxiety in the therapy room, so that the family's normal ways of dealing with stress do not relieve it. They will then need to develop new ways of being with one another.
The therapist has an unlimited amount of tools available to them. Anything can be used if it serves the purpose of helping people be more authentic.
One of the hallmarks of this model is the use of a co-therapy team. The co-therapists are there to help augment each other. While one person is engaged with the family, the other can sit back and get a wider view of the family process. They can then put this information back into the conversation to try to stir up the family.
Having a co-therapist can model for the family how to engage one another productively, even if at times they disagree with one another.
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Experiential Family Therapy/Whitaker/Symbolic-Experiential Family Therapy.md

item.title: Michael White
item.description:
Founder of the narrative movement, based out of Adelaide, Australia (Dulwich Centre)
Passed away in 2008
Drawn to the work of Gregory Bateson but found himself more interested in what Bateson said about how people construe the world than in the behavioral patterns of systems-based models.
Ideas about how problems affect people - regarding them as something operating on individuals rather than as things people are doing.
University Resources/Couple and Family Therapy/Keywords/Externalization

item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Deconstruction
item.description: A postmodern approach to exploring meaning by taking apart and examining taken-for-granted categories and assumptions, making possible newer and sounder constructions of meaning. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Narrative Family Therapy/Keywords and Concepts/Deconstruction.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Deconstructive Listening
item.description:
Listen 'deconstructively' to family stories - the listening is guided by the belief that those stories have many possible meanings.
Ask families to tell their stories, look for opportunities to reflect our sense of what they said, they are saying, and to ask whether the meaning we are making fits with their intended meaning.
We wonder aloud whether they are useful or desirable?
And, what difference it makes to think of it 'that way'?
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Narrative Family Therapy/Keywords and Concepts/Deconstructive Listening.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Deconstructive Questioning
item.description:
Cultivate an awareness of the dominant (and dominating) stories in our society/
Develop ways of collaboratively examining the effects of those stories when we sense them at work win the lives and relationships of the families with whom we consult.
There are 'taken-for-granted' realities at play.
Deconstructive questions aim to examine problems in detail and expose discourses that suppose them, as well as those that might undermine those discourses.
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Narrative Family Therapy/Keywords and Concepts/Deconstructive Questioning.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Dominant Discourses
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Narrative Family Therapy/Keywords and Concepts/Dominant Discourses.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Externalizing Conversations
item.description:
The person/family is not the problem; the problem is the problem.
Externalizing - problems are seen as separate from people.
As we listen to people's stories, we listen for the ways they refer to their problems in their lives. If we hear names like 'fear' or 'blowing up,' we orient to those things as entities or processes that are external to families.
If we are not hearing the name, we might ask the family to name them.
What would you call that something?
What 'feeds' the problem?
What 'starves' the problem?
In what settings might the problem be useful?
Who advocates for the problem?
What groups of people would be opposed to the problem and its intentions?
What are the effects of the problem on members of the family? On their lives and relationships?
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Narrative Family Therapy/Keywords and Concepts/Externalizing Conversations.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Problem-Saturated Stories
item.description:
The usual pessimistic and blaming accounts that clients bring to therapy, which are seen as helping keep them stuck. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Narrative Therapy
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Narrative Family Therapy/Keywords and Concepts/Problem-Saturated Stories.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Reconstruction
item.description: Reweaving narrative accounts into more palatable and coherent histories. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Narrative Family Therapy/Keywords and Concepts/Reconstruction.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Relative Influence Questions
item.description:
Questions designed to explore the extent to which the problem has dominated the client versus how much he or she has been able to control it. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Narrative Therapy
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Narrative Family Therapy/Keywords and Concepts/Relative Influence Questions.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Social Constructionism
item.description: Like constructivism, challenges the notion of an objective basis for knowledge. Knowledge and meaning are shaped by culturally shared assumptions. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Narrative Family Therapy/Keywords and Concepts/Social Constructionism.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Unique Outcome
item.description:
Michael White's term for times when clients acted free of their problems, even if they were unaware of doing so. Narrative therapists identify unique outcomes as a way to help clients challenge negative views of themselves. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Narrative Therapy
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Narrative Family Therapy/Keywords and Concepts/Unique Outcome.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Lecture on Narrative Therapy
item.description:
Modernism vs. Postmodernism:
Postmodernism was a response in many ways to modernism and, hence, they can be considered to be two aspects of the same movement. But there are major differences between modernism and postmodernism.
Two central tenets of the Enlightenment (beginning of the 'modern' period) were as follows:
The perfectibility of human nature
The belief in human progress through the development of human knowledge, especially the sciences.
In the 20
th century, scientific findings, like quantum physics, seriously undermined the possibility of a deterministic model of the world. As a guiding principle, reason was still affirmed as was the belief in human progress.
The project of modernism was to examine the impediments still holding society back.
Individuals ceased to believe that art and literary works bore one unique meaning; rather, postmodernists believed in deriving their own meanings from works of art and literature.
Modernism:
It was an emancipatory project whose main idea was that traditional values and institutions were oppressive, divisive and inefficient and should, therefore, be replaced by rational values and institutions.
Modernism led to progress in many spheres of life by changing the approach of mankind towards culture.
Ultimately, modernism attempted to free humanity from its historical baggage through the use of philosophy and science.
Postmodernism:
Postmodernism was a reaction to modernism and was influenced by disenchantment brought on by the second world war.
Postmodernism refers to the state that lacks a central hierarchy and one that is complex, ambiguous, and diverse.
Postmodernists are the nihilists.
Postmodernists like Heidegger, Derrida, and Lyotard attacked the modernist belief in rationality, objectivity and universalism in favor of relativism (the view that there is no objective truth) as well as identity.
Grand narratives like freedom, societal progress, scientific progress were criticized by postmodernists, who instead emphasized that difference, rather than forced unity, should be celebrated.
Postmodernism is a backlash against modernity.
The collapse of tradition created a frightening situation whereby meaning became difficult to discern amid the horror of societal breakdown.
Postmodernism, hence, represented a loss in faith in human reason. Postmodernism provides a bleak prognosis of the human condition and offers no real solutions.
Conclusion:
- Modernism and postmodernism were both movements that emerged from an analysis of events within the modern period from the perspective of the values of the Enlightenment.
Postmodernism:


Theory that knowledge of things are not real unless we give them meaning.
The sense of self is a social construct. Our identity is created by interactions with other people and our reactions to society.
Two threads:
Weak (Social Constructionism):
Proposes that social constructs are dependent on brute facts (most basic and fundamental facts and do not rely on other facts).
Institutional facts are created by social conventions and rely on other facts.
Strong (Social):
The whole of reality is dependent on social habits. All knowledge is a social construct and there are no brute facts.
It would say we created the idea of something and how to explain it.
Main criticism:
Does not take into consideration the effect of natural phenomenon that goes on in society.
Social constructionism only explains reality through the thoughts of humans, not by using fundamental brute facts.


Michael White
David Epston
Gene Combs
Jill Freedman


Knowledge is constructed.
Therapy is concerned with the ways people interpret their behavior rather than how they behave.
Experience is understood in interpretation and meaning making.
Experiences can have multiple interpretations.
The Narrative Metaphor:
Focuses on self-defeating cognitions - the stories people tell themselves about their problems.
\Problems affect people.
Problems operate on people rather than problems being things people are doing.
For clients to maintain their new narratives, they need supportive communities.
Hence letter writing, outsider witness, reflecting teams.
The truth of experience is not DISCOVERED, it is CREATED.
Narrative accounts affect people's perceptions, stories don't just mirror life, they shape it.
Instead of trying to solve problems, the focus is on enriching the narratives of people's lives - bringing forth 'thick descriptions' of those aspects of people's narratives that life outside the influence of problems.
Alternative stories allow people to live out new identities, new possibilities for relationships, and new future.
People find meaning in their lives by experiencing, telling, and circulating stories of un-stories aspects of their lives and relationships.
Dominant discourses are socially constructed within our culture.



We 'story' and create meaning of life events using available dominant discourses - broad social stories, practices, assumptions, and expectations about how we should live.
'Problems':
Experienced when a person's personal life does not fit with these societal discourses and expectations.


Process involves separating the person from the problem.


Understanding Oppression: Dominant vs. Local Discourses
Dominant discourses are culturally generated stories about how life should go.
Local discourses occur in our heads, our closer relationships, and marginalized communities.
Narrative therapists help clients become aware of how these different discourses are impacting their lives.


Avoid judgements about what is 'normal.'
Avoid categorizing.
Avoid the idea of general principles of what causes problems or what resolves them.


The stories people tell themselves.
Interpret their experience in unhelpful ways.
Patterns of tunnel vision.
Problem-saturated stories take hold and encourage people to respond to each other in ways that perpetuate the problem story.


Separate the problem-saturated stories to open space for:
New and more constructive views of themselves.
Look for unique outcomes
'Sparking events'


Deconstruction:
View the problem as an external entity to start challenging its influence.
Unique Outcomes:
Resistance to the problem's influence
Opens room for counter stories


Involves finding new ways to view, interact with, and respond to problems by defining the role of the problems in their lives.
Broadly involves the following phases:
Meeting
Listening
Separating persons from problems
Enacting preferred narratives
Solidifying
Process thickens and enriches a person's identity and life accounts.
Therapist negotiates the time of each next meeting as therapy progresses, one meeting at a time.
At the end of each meeting, the therapists asks whether the conversation has been useful, if it has, they ask how?
Then, the therapist asks whether the family would like to meet again, and if so, when?
Meetings are typically 60 minutes
Length of therapy varies with each family (from a single consultation to years, most somewhere in between)


Collaborative
Carefully observe, inquire into, and document the family's particular situation in relation to their problem
With permission, share knowledge from previous work with families, and ask the family to evaluate the 'fit' and usefulness of that knowledge in relation to their problem
Takes notes of what works and what doesn't
Decentered, but influential - they have skills in facilitating a conversation


Meeting the person apart from the problem
Separating people from problems:
The problem is the problem
Optimism and hope
Co-author/co-editor
Investigate reporter


Problem-saturated stories
Unique outcomes and sparkling events
Dominant cultural and gender discourses
Local and alternative discourses:
Attending to client language and meaning


Holds a position of curiosity.
Cherishes each person/family's unique stories.
Invite clients to develop and live out narratives that they prefer for their lives
Is decentered, not an expert, but an interested collaborator.
They are skilled at asking questions to bring forth the knowledge and experience carried in particular stories of the family.
Narrative Therapy Principles:
Therapist influential, but decentered.
Person separate from problem.
All problems have exceptions.
Opposite of problem is preferred.
Preferred story woven into identity.
Impact of relationships explored.
Deconstruct societal norms.
Personal decision making supported.


Instead of having a problem or being a problem, clients are struggling against their problems.
The problem is the problem.
Aren't interested in problem-maintaining sequences (strategic), structural issues (structural), or solutions (solution-focused), they are interested in the problem's impact on the family.
Social Constructionism:
There is no absolute truth, instead shift toward deconstructing (reexamining) established truths that oppress people's lives.


People have good intentions (they do not need or want problems).
People are profoundly influenced by the discourses around them.
People are not their problems.
People can develop alternative empowering stories once separated from their problems and the cultural myths they have internalized.


Therapist is interested in families' own evaluations of what is problematic and what is preferred.
Clients name how the problem is affecting their lives and relationships.
Therapist invites people to bring their 'best selves' into consideration of the problems that diminish their relationship and an exploration of how they might choose ways of living that diminish the effect of the problems on their relationship.


Reject categorizing people.
In the spirit of collaboration, the therapist situates themselves WITH clients.
They disclose the beliefs that inform their therapy so that clients can know what they're getting into.
Clients are encouraged to educate the therapist on their cultural predicaments and to correct the therapist when they make assumptions that don't fit for the client's experience.
Problems are likely to persist as long as unhelpful stories remain fixed and obscure other more helpful versions of events.


Cautious about applying terminology (diagnosis).
Want to hear the family's stories of how the problems they name affect their lives and relationships.
When one of these problems appears to have invaded a relationship, it is the therapist's responsibility to ask questions that invite family members to consider the effects of that problem on their relationship, and to consider the stand they want to take in relation to it.
Problems are things that are separate from the families they afflict.
Therapists look for problematic discourses and offer families the opportunity to describe and evaluate the effects of those discourses on their relationships and lives.


Problem-saturated stories encourage people to respond to each other in ways that perpetuate the problem story
Problems may be regarded as alien invaders


Separate from problem-saturated stories (and destructive cultural assumptions)
Open space for new and more constructive views of themselves.
Separate individuals from problems and unite the family to fight a common enemy
Search for unique outcomes (sparkling events, exceptions) - times when they resisted the problem or behaved in ways that contradicted the problem story.


Help clients deconstruct unproductive stories in order to reconstruct new and more productive ones.
Deconstruction involves questioning assumptions
Reconstruction involves creating new and more optimistic accounts of experience
Effects Questions:
Elicit effects of the problem
"How does the problem affect you? Your ideas about yourself? Your relationship?"
"Clients can begin to notice areas of their lives where the problem has been less powerful."
Identifying unique outcomes creates room for counterplots


Telling and retelling, witnessing, and living out of multistoried lives.
Once people notice how their stories are problem saturated and try to change their narratives, what they do and perceive will change as well.
Facilitate this process by asking questions to highlight un-storied events and to encourage meaning making around those events, then tie the meaning to memorable actions and contexts.


Therapist negotiates the time of each next meeting as therapy progresses, one meeting at a time
At the end of each meeting, the therapist asks whether the conversation has been useful, if it has, they ask how?
Then, the therapist asks whether the family would like to meet again, and if so, when?
Meetings are typically 60 minutes
Length of therapy varies with each family (from a single consultation to years, most somewhere in between)


CAUTION:
Often therapy invites people to re-immerse themselves in their most problematic stories
INSTEAD:
narrative therapy invite families to explore, describe, and experience new directions in life that are already unfolding - new positions, new stories
Counterstory
Asking permission is central to the model
At the start of the first meeting, the therapist ask if it would be okay to get to know the family in ways that have nothing to do with the problem before they describe what brought them to therapy.
Later meetings often start by the therapist reading their notes from the previous session aloud and asking question, such as:
Can you tell me about new developments that relate to what we were talking about last time
Other times the therapist begins by wondering whether there have been important thoughts or events that connect to possibilities identified in the previous conversations
Therapists use letters, documents, and videos to document and circulate alternative stories.
For example, after a therapy session a therapist may write a letter posing questions that invite the family to develop an alternative story even further than they did in the session
Or sending a document noting the stands the family has taken in regard to a problem
Reading a document between sessions, and the conversations that can follow a reading, keeping a story alive and growing


Collaborative
Carefully observe, inquire into, and document the family's particular situation in relation to their problem.
With permission, share knowledge from previous work with families, and ask the family to evaluate the 'fit' and usefulness of that knowledge in relation to their problem.
Takes note of what works and what doesn't
Decentered, but influential - they have skills in facilitating a conversation
Therapy is a relationship - a conversation
Ask questions to expose gaps in problematic stories
Open space for describing alternatives
Invite families to add, subtract, or describe differently
Encourage families to ask questions about the therapist's questions and comments
The therapist wants the family to make meaning of their own experience, but the therapist's questions inevitably shape the inquiry.
Families are in a better position to interpret, making meaning of, and evaluate their own experiences than outsiders are, even trained outsiders
Therapists have more questions than answers


It sounds as though problem is part of your life now.
How long have you been noticing this problem?
What effect does the problem have on your life?
How does the problem impact your relationships?
Does problem have an impact on your relationship with other family members?
What do you think about the effects the problem is having on your life?
Are you accepting what problem is doing?
Are these effects acceptable to you or not?
Why is this? Why are you taking this position on what problem is doing?
How would you prefer things to be?


People's lives are multi-storied, each new telling of a story generates new possibilities for making meaning and taking action.
The therapist invites family members to:
Evaluate their current situation
Name the problems involved
Evaluate their relationship to those problems
Take a stand in regard to them
Tell more satisfying stories of their lives
Evaluate the usefulness of the alternative stories
In telling and living out the newly developed strands of alternative stories, clients evaluate aspects of their lives.
Private hopes and fears
Family interactions
Contributions of culture of origin
Traditions, legacies
Questioning:
Is that the problem speaking?
Whose values are guiding you in saying that?
By exposing discouses that support problems, families can separate from the ways of being that are supported by those discourses, and identify and recognize preferred perceptions, attitudes, and actions.


What name would you give the problem?
What is it like to experience the problem?
What effect does the problem have on your life?
What effect does the problem have on your relationship with each other?
What talks have you have about the problem in your family? What impacts has that had?
What effects does the problem have on your other relationships?
How does the problem alter your relationship with yourself?
Is this what you want for your life? Why or why not?
Are we talking about what you want to be talking about?
Is this conversation useful? How is it useful?


Externalizing conversations
Relatice influence questions
Who's in charge, the person or the problem?
Identifying unique outcomes
Reading between the lines of the problem story
Can you remember a time...
Reauthoring
What does it say about you...
Illuminating or creating the counter-story
Reinforcing the new story
Finding audiences, supportive witnesses, allies
Letter writing
Deconstructing destructive cultural assumptions



Listen to stories as stories.
Be attentive and responsive to their intended meaning in telling the story.
Ask about non-problematic aspects of the life of family members and of their relationship.
Make sure the problem does not trick us into mistaking 'them' for 'the problem.'
Unless families insist on moving quickly into talking about problems, spend a while listening to stories about their preferences.
At some point, families spontaneously start to tell problem saturated stories.
Try to put yourself in their shoes.
Do not assume you understand the meaning their experience holds for them
Listen and ask
Listen with focused attention, patience, and curiosity while building a relationship of mutual respect and trust.


Listen 'deconstructively' to family stories - the listening is guided by the belief that those stories have many possible meanings.
Ask families to tell their stories, look for opportunities to reflect our sense of what they said, they are saying, and to ask whether the meaning we are making fits with their intended meaning.
We wonder aloud whether they are useful or desirable?
And, what difference it makes to think of it 'that way'?


Cultivate an awareness of the dominant (and dominating) stories in our society/
Develop ways of collaboratively examining the effects of those stories when we sense them at work win the lives and relationships of the families with whom we consult.
There are 'taken-for-granted' realities at play.
Deconstructive questions aim to examine problems in detail and expose discourses that suppose them, as well as those that might undermine those discourses.


The person/family is not the problem; the problem is the problem.
Externalizing - problems are seen as separate from people.
As we listen to people's stories, we listen for the ways they refer to their problems in their lives. If we hear names like 'fear' or 'blowing up,' we orient to those things as entities or processes that are external to families.
If we are not hearing the name, we might ask the family to name them.
What would you call that something?
What 'feeds' the problem?
What 'starves' the problem?
In what settings might the problem be useful?
Who advocates for the problem?
What groups of people would be opposed to the problem and its intentions?
What are the effects of the problem on members of the family? On their lives and relationships?


Naming a problem can open a way for examining it and thinking differently about it.
As we ask people to evaluate their relationship to problems, they often tell us what they would prefer to have in their lives in place of the problem.
What are the family's preferred directions?
'Standing against' the problem.


Have you ever been able to escape the problem even for a few minutes?
Is the problem always with you?


Listen for purposes, values, hopes, and commitments that are absent but implicit in family's narratives.
Double listening.
If a person experiences despair, they must have hopes, dreams, or visions of the future that are not being fulfilled.
If a person experiences injustive, they must have a conception of a just world.
When we hear problematic stories, we listen for these sorts of implications.


Stories need listeners as well as tellers.
Attentive witnesses.
The therapist serves as a witness, but including other witnesses, especially those involved in people's lives, can be very helpful.
What was it like to hear what so-and-so was saying?
What thoughts were you having as so-and-so was talking?
It is useful to ask questions that, rather than leaving the field for response wide open, more specifically invite people to respond to unique outcomes and preferred directions.
Were you surprised when so-and-so described you as taking the time to let others know you care?
What did it mean to you to hear so-and-so say how important the relationship is to them?


Creating a setting where people can tell their preferred stories to a group of outsiders, who then amplify and accredit the stories that they witness.
What stood out for them?
What images it brought forward?
How it resonated with their own experiences?
Where they were transported by the interview?
Situate their reflections in their own experience.
Comment on the difference that being part of the conversation makes on their own lives.


We are interested in documenting and circulating the new stories that emerge in therapy to thicken them and keep them alive.
We take notes in therapy to document new stories as they develop.
We often refer back to these notes and read them aloud.
We may create videos or documents about what they have learned, with their permission, that can be viewed or read by others facing similar problems.
We sometimes write letters between therapy sessions.
In these letters, we ask questions that we did not ask in the therapy session.
Our intention in letter writing is to thicken and extend the knowledge that has begun to emerge in session.
We might invite the family to share these documents with other people in their lives.


Opening space questions (unique outcomes)
Has there been a time when arguing could have taken control of your relationship but didn't?
Preference questions (preferred experiences)
Was this way of handling things better or worse? And how?
Story development questions
How is this different from when arguing is in control?
Meaning questions
What does it say about you that you were able to...?
Questions that extend the story into the future
What do you predict...?


Aims to separate the individual from the issue and externalize problems instead of internalizing them.


Reality is socially constructed.
Reality is influenced by and communicated through language.
Having a narrative can help us organize and maintain our reality.
There is no 'objective reality' or absolute truth.


Telling One's Story:
A technique that involves re-telling your own story to find new meaning in old experiences.
Externalization Technique:
Externalizing helps you separate you from your problems, making it easier to change something you don't like about yourself.
Deconstruction Technique:
This technique involves breaking problems down into smaller, more specific issues that are easier to understand and address.
Unique Outcomes Technique:
To help you see from a new, more positive perspective, broaden your view to see more of your own storylines, and focus on one that doesn't include your most pervasive problems.


Some families prefer a different kind of therapy than narrative, some are seeking instruction and expert advice.
Regularly ask families how the therapy is going for them, and be open and willing to refer families if they are seeking a different kind of relationship.
Most families coming to therapy are concerned less with how the therapy is structured than with whether their family relationships improve
Emphasis on 'practice-based evidence' over evidence-based practice
More qualitative research rather than quantitative studies
Little empirical support currently exists
Randomized controlled trials of narrative therapy do not yet exist.

item.title: Narrative Therapy
item.description: An approach to treatment that emphasizes the role of the stories people construct about their experience. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)

item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Emotionally Focused Therapy (EFT)
item.description: A model of therapy based on attachment theory, in which the emotional longings beneath a couple's defensive reactions are uncovered as they are taught to see the reactive nature of their struggles with each other, developed by Leslie Greenberg and Susan Johnson.
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Other Therapy Theories/Emotionally Focused Therapy (EFT)/Emotionally Focused Therapy (EFT).md
item.dc:creator: Millie
