item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Other Therapy Theories/Attachment Theory.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Basic Assumption Theory
item.description: Bion's concept that group members become diverted from the group task to pursue unconscious patterns of flight-fight.
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Other Therapy Theories/Basic Assumption Theory.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Communications Theory
item.description: The study of relationships in terms of the exchange of verbal and nonverbal messages. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Other Therapy Theories/Communications Theory.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Concurrent Therapy
item.description: Treatment of two or more individuals, seen separately, usually by different therapists. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Other Therapy Theories/Concurrent Therapy.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Conjoint Therapy
item.description: Treatment of two or more individuals in sessions together. Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Other Therapy Theories/Conjoint Therapy.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Conversion Therapy
item.description: Literature on conversion therapy is focused on the clients' experiences and rationales for seeking therapy.
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Other Therapy Theories/Conversion Therapy.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Family Systems Theory
item.description:
Murray Bowen
"Based on the assumptions that the human is a product of evolution and that human behavior is significantly regulated by the same natural processes that regulate the behavior of all other living things. A corollary assumption is that clinical disorders are a product of that part of man he has in common with the lower animals." (@kerrFamilyEvaluation1988)
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Other Therapy Theories/Family Systems Theory.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: General Systems Theory
item.description:
A biological model of living systems as whole entities that maintain themselves through continuous input and output from the environment; developed by Ludwig con Bertalanffy.
Developed by Ludwig von Bertalanffy
A system is 'any entity maintained by the mutual interaction of its parts.'
A system can be composed of smaller subsystems.
Every system is a subsystem of larger systems.
Open vs. Closed Systems
Unlike machines, families change when necessary to adapt to new circumstances.
Systems:
Individual and Nuclear Family (Nuclear Family, Family One Lives Within)
Extended Family (Grandparents, Relatives, Significant Others)
Social Level (School, Work, Friends, Neighbors, Faith)
Multi-Cultural Level (Socioeconomic, Cultural, Ethnic, Racial, Geographical, Religious Context)
Implications for MFTs:
What shows up as one individual's behavior may be a product of the relationship.
MFTs use concepts to describe how people in a relationship contribute to what goes on between them (e.g., pursuer/distancer; overfunctioning/underfunctioning)
Families tend to resist change, which explains why so many clients remain stuck despite heroic efforts to improve.
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Other Therapy Theories/General Systems Theory.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Medical Family Therapy
item.description: A form of psychoeducational family therapy involving collaboration with physicians and other healthcare professionals in the treatment of individuals with medical problems. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Other Therapy Theories/Medical Family Therapy.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Monadic Model
item.description: Explanations based on properties of a single individual or object: Johnny shoplifts because he is rebellious. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Other Therapy Theories/Monadic Model.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Multiple Family Group Therapy (1950)
item.description: Treatment of several families at once in a group therapy format; pioneered by Peter Laqueur and Murray Bowen. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Other Therapy Theories/Multiple Family Group Therapy (1950).md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Multiple Impact Therapy (1967)
item.description:
An intensive, crisis-oriented form of family therapy developed by Robert MacGregor in which family members are treated in various subgroups by a team of therapists.
Robert MacGregor
He developed Multiple Impact Therapy (1967) at the University of Texas Medical Branch in Galveston.
His clinic served a population that was scattered widely over southeastern Texas, and clients had to travel hundreds of miles.
He wanted to have a maximum impact in a short amount of time. He worked with families for two days.
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Other Therapy Theories/Multiple Impact Therapy (1967).md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Network Therapy
item.description:
A treatment devised by Ross Speck in which a large number of family and friends are assembled to help resolve a patient's problems. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Ross Speck
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Other Therapy Theories/Network Therapy.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Systems Theory
item.description:
A generic term for studying a group of related elements that interact as a whole entity; encompasses general systems theory and cybernetics
General Systems Theory
Cybernetics
It is the science of feedback.
How information, especially Positive Feedback and Negative Feedback loops can help self-regulate a system.
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Other Therapy Theories/Systems Theory.md

item.title: Complainant
item.description:
De Shazer's term for a relationship with a client who describes a complaint but is at present unwilling to work on solving it. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Solution-Focused Therapy
Steve de Shazer

item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Compliments
item.description:
Used in solution-focused therapy to convey support and encouragement. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Solution-Focused Therapy
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Solution-Focused Therapy/Key Terms and Concepts/Compliments.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Coping Questions
item.description: Used in Solution-Focused Therapy to help clients realize they have been managing difficult circumstances. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)

item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Customer
item.description:
De Shazer's term for a client who not only complains about a problem ('Complainant') but also is motivated to resolve it. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Solution-Focused Therapy
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Solution-Focused Therapy/Key Terms and Concepts/Customer.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Exception Question
item.description:
Used in solution-focused therapy to help clients remember times when they haven't been defeated by their problems. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Solution-Focused Therapy
Steve de Shazer
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Solution-Focused Therapy/Key Terms and Concepts/Exception Question.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Miracle Question
item.description:
Asking clients to imagine how things would be if they woke up tomorrow and their problem was solved. Solution-focused therapists use the miracle question to help clients identify goals and potential solutions. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Solution-Focused Therapy
Steve de Shazer
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Solution-Focused Therapy/Key Terms and Concepts/Miracle Question.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Scaling Questions
item.description:
Solution-focused clients are asked to rate on a 10-point scale how much they want to resolve their problems, how bad the problem is, how much better it is then the last time, and so on. Designed to break change up into small steps. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Solution-Focused Therapy
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Solution-Focused Therapy/Key Terms and Concepts/Scaling Questions.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Visitor
item.description:
De Shazer's term for a client who does not wish to be part of therapy, does not have a complaint, and does not wish to work on anything. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Solution-Focused Therapy
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Solution-Focused Therapy/Key Terms and Concepts/Visitor.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Lecture on Solution-Focused Therapy
item.description:
“Media/Clinic Media/HDFS 8874_ SFT Handout.pdf” could not be found.


Solution Focused Brief Therapy Association - Home
What is Solution-Focused Therapy · Solution-Focused Therapy Institute


Steve de Shazer:
1979:
Started the Brief Family Therapy Center (BFTC)
Worked in University Resources/Couple and Family Therapy/Keywords/Palo Alto (1952); influenced by MRI
Focuses on solutions that work rather than solutions that do not work as in the MRI model.
Insoo Kim Berg:
BFTC
Applied the model to alcoholism, marital therapy, and family-based services to the poor.


Derived from MRI
Focus on cognitions rather than behavior
Focus on the presenting the problem
Find the simplest solution
Focus on exceptions
Exceptions to client's problem are the solution
Assumed people are capable of behaving effectively; blocked by negative mindset
People already have the solution(s) to their problems.
People constrained by narrow view of their problems.
Rigid patterns of false solutions
Future-oriented
Look to future where problems can be solved.
Changing the way people talk about their problems.
The language of problems tends to be different from the language of solutions.
Problem talk:
Negative
Focuses on the past
Implies permanence of problems
Solution talk:
Hopeful
Future oriented


Avoid judgements about 'what is normal'
Clients as experts in their situation
Interest in language
How people describe themselves and problems
Focus on complaints presented
Should not impose values by suggesting clients address other un-presented problems.


Solutions to problems are unrelated to the development of the problem.
Tracking the development of the problem should be avoided.
Problem-focused thinking prevents effective solutions from being recognized.


Set clear goals and build on exceptions to problems.
Good therapy is more than implementing specific techniques, it also involves therapeutic alliance.
The goal of solution-focused therapy is to resolve the presenting problem as expeditiously as possible.
The goal is not about how families should be structured, but only what they want different in their lives.
The model emphasizes the importance of assisting clients in creating well-defined goals, framed in positive terms and modest enough to be achievable.


Resolve presenting complaint by helping clients do or think differently.
Trust clients to reach their own goals.
Help clients identify the problem-solving skills they have lost sight of.
Help clients locate their resources.


Time limited
Sessions are made one at a time
One may be enough
Typical course includes 3-5 sessions
Clients can return as-needed
Often a week to a few weeks apart
Once you know more of what works, do more of it


Consultant
Don't get bogged down in 'problem talk'
Direct clients away from the problem-saturated narrative
Therapists attempts to create a context for the family to develop more useful ways of responding
Focus on the 'here and now'
The future provides a blank canvas on which the family can paint a picture of their wishes and hopes
Assumes a position of 'not knowing'


Very little intake information
Avoid assessing how problems develop
Concentrate on assessing future goals
Therapy should only include people concerned about the problem
Hear the client's constructions of their problems without preconceptions


What do you think the problem is now?
How will you know when the problem is solved?
How will you know when you don't have to come here anymore? What will the signs be?
What will have to be different for that to happen in terms of your behavior, thoughts, and feelings?
What will you notice that is different about others involved in the situation?
What is your wildest fantasy about what you want to happen?


What needs to happen as a result of coming here so that afterward you will look back and be able to say it was a good idea?
What needs to happen so that this will not have been a waste of your time?
Often in our experience, we have found that in between scheduling an appointment and coming in, something happens that contributes to making a problem better. Has anything happened to improve the problems that brought you here today?


Once a description of the goal has been developed, the therapist asks the clients to assess their current level of progress toward that goal by imagining a scale of 1-10.
Where 1 represented the problem at its worst, and 10 is the point at which the problem is gone or the clients are coping so well that its no longer problematic


Solution-focused therapists help clients identify their preferred solution by:
Talking about the problem, exceptions, and desired outcomes.
Working with clients to take small active steps in this general direction each week.
This can take 1-10 sessions or it may take years depending on the complexity of the case.


How do we know when to stop meeting like this?
Goals should be:
Small
Salient to clients
Concrete, behavioral, measurable
Achievable
Involve hard work
Start of something
Involve new behaviors
What will be present? What will be happening?



Activates problem-solving mindset by giving people a vision of their goal.
Helps clients to look beyond the problem to see what they really want
Might not be the elimination of the problem but to be able to do things that the problem has been obstructing
"Suppose one night there is a miracle and while you are sleeping the problem that brought you into therapy is solved."
How would you know?
What would be different?
What will you notice the next morning that will tell you there has been a miracle?
What will your family member notice?


Directs clients' attention to times when they did not have the problem and expand on exceptions.
Helping families see that their problems have exceptions - times when they don't occur.
Exceptions are solutions that families already have in their repertoire.
Finding exceptions in the recent past is most useful because clients can remember them in greater detail; also since these exceptions just happened, it is more plausible they could happen again.
When in the recent past might the problem have happened but didn't (or was less intense or more manageable)?
What's different about those times when the problem doesn't happen?
How have you let your partner know when they do something that makes a positive difference to you?


Punctuate with enthusiasm and support.
Work to keep solution talk in the forefront.
Listen carefully for an exception by getting more details about it and congragulating the family on it.
Connect the exception to the family's goals by asking how the goal would be reached if this exception were to occur more often.
"How did you manage that?"
"What keeps you going under such difficult circumstances?"
"How come things aren't worse?"
"What have you done to keep them from getting worse?"


Help therapist and clients talk about vague topics (e.g., depression)
On a scale from 1 to 10, how sad do you feel?
Help clients to set goals in a clear/manageable manner.
What do you think you need to do to achieve a 3?


To be effective, compliments should point toward what to do more, not what to eliminate.
Compliments can be used to highlight successful strategies and keep clients focused on those that work.


Formula first-session task
Do more of what works
Do soemthing different
Go slow
Do the opposite
The prediction task


Devote to finding, amplifying, and measuring progress.
Inquire about progress, seeking detailed descriptions of any movement toward the family's goal and the clients' role in attaining it.
What's better?
What happened that you liked?
Tell me more. Walk me through how the two of you did that.
How did you keep things from getting worse?
What's your idea about what might be helpful?


How can we know when to stop meeting like this?
What needs to be different in your life as a result of coming here for you to say that meeting with me was worthwhile?


Toxic positivity
Therapist doesn't get to know client's past, which make it harder to understand and empathize with client
The brief, goal-oriented focus does not work with every kind of person or problem
It is easier to focus on the positive and solutions than to do the deep, difficult work of talking about trauma and the past

Steve de Shazer's term for a style of a therapy that emphasizes the solutions that families have already developed for their problems. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Steve de Shazer

item.title: Don Jackson
item.description:
Family Homeostasis

Don Jackson developed the concept of Family Homeostasis.
He and Jay Haley were influential in developing family treatment.
They explored marital family therapy within the framework of communication analysis.
Family therapy was started by John Elderkin Bell (1951), Don Jackson, Nathan Ackerman, and Murray Bowen.
Family Rules
Rules can describe regularity rather than regulation.
Families only use a fraction of the full range of behaviors available to them. Therapy allows the family to access a wider range of behaviors.
Jackson's strategies are based on the premise that psychiatric problems resulted from the way people behave with each other.
To discern functional interactions from dysfunctional ones is to understand problems in context.
Even positive change can be a threat to the defensive order of things.
Some therapists believed symptoms serve a purpose by some families needing a sick member, which leads to parents victimizing scapegoated children.
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Strategic Family Therapy/Key Figures/Don Jackson.md

item.description:
University Resources/Couple and Family Therapy/Keywords/Palo Alto (1952)
Metacommunication
Homeostasis
Double Bind

item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Jay Haley
item.description:
Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019:
"Jay Haley was always something of a maverick. He entered the field without clinical credentials and established his reputation as a gadfly and critic. His initial impact came from his writings, in which he infused sarcasm with incisive analysis. "
Strategies of Psychotherapy, Jay Haley
Covert messages are used in the struggle for control that characterizes many relationships
Symptoms represent an incongruence between levels of communication
Since symptomatic behavior wasn’t reasonable, Haley didn’t try to reason with patients to help them
Defined therapy as a directive form of treatment and acknowledged his debt to Milton Erickson, with whom he studied hypnosis. In what he called brief therapy, Haley zeroed in on the context and possible function of a patient’s symptoms.
therapist is directing patients to do precisely what they would do anyway and thus subtly gaining the upper hand
The decisive techniques in brief therapy were directives
it isn’t enough to explain problems to patients; what counts is getting them to do something about them.
paradox here is that you can’t accidentally make a mistake if you are doing so deliberately
The cybernetic principle here: People will do anything to get out of housework
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Strategic Family Therapy/Key Figures/Jay Haley.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.description: A descriptive term for redundant behavioral patterns. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)

item.title: Feedback Loop
item.description:
The return of a portion of the output of a system, especially when used to maintain the output within predetermined limits (negative feedback) or to signal a need to modify the system (positive feedback). (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Positive Feedback
Negative Feedback
Cybernetics

item.title: First-Order Change
item.description: Temporary or superficial changes within a system that do not alter the basic organization of the system itself. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)

item.title: Hierarchical Structure
item.description: Family functioning based on the clear generational boundaries, where the parents maintain control and authority. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)

item.description: A balanced steady state of equilibrium. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)

item.description:
Basic change in the structure and functioning of a system. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)

Structural Family Therapy

item.title: Background:
item.description:
Strategic grew out of Gregory Bateson's project on schizophrenia at the Mental Research Institute.
The initial emphasis was on observation and research on families, but due to the influence of University Resources/HDFS Classes/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Solution-Focused Therapy/Key Figures/Milton Erickson's work, intervention strategies were also formulated.


Believed in using the resources of his clients and designing a 'strategy for each specific problem.'
He did not care about perspective (insight) as long as their actions produced beneficial results.
Conducted therapy by paying extreme attention to details of symptoms his clients presented.
IN therapy:
Accepted and emphasized positive
Used indirect and ambiguously worded directives.
Directed routine behaviors so that the resistance is shown through change and not through normal and continuous actions.
The MRI Model, Milan Model, and Haley and Madanes all overlap.


The MRI Pioneers:
Don Jackson
Gregory Bateson, as a consultant
Virginia Satir (1988)
John Weakland
Jay Haley
Paul Watzlawick
Richard Fisch
Jules Riskin


The hallmarks of strategic therapy are:
Using a set of novel strategies to solve family problems.
Generating change rather than generating insight.
Circumventing resistance rather than dealing directly with it.


People are always communicating.
All behavior is communicative
One cannot not communicate.
All messages have report and command functions.
Report = CONTENT = Information = WHAT IS SAID
Command = PROCESS = Underlying Relationship = HOW IT IS SAID


Families often perpetuate problems by their own actions.
Directives tailored to the needs of a particular family can sometimes bring about sudden and decisive change.
The exchange of multilayered messages between family members define their relationships.
Interrupting vicious cycles that occur when attempts to solve problems only make them worse.
Focuses on identifying and interrupting 'ironic processes' which occur when repeated attempts to solve a problem keep the problem going or make it worse.
The aim of therapy is simply to resolve the presenting complaint as quickly and efficiently as possible, so clients can get on with life.
BSCT makes no attempt to specify what constitutes a functional or dysfunctional family relationship.
The therapist attends to what clients do, as well as, how they view the problem, themselves, and each other.
Often see family members individually in the context of family therapy, even when the focus of the intervention is a relational complaint.
If no one registers a complaint, there is no problem.
Patterns (e.g., quiet detachment, volatile engagement) may be dysfunctional for some families and adaptive for others.


What matters is the extent to which interaction patterns based on attempted solutions keep a complaint going or make it worse.
The problems clients being to therapy persist only if they are maintained by ongoing current behavior of the family.
How a problem persists is much more relevant to therapy than how the problem originated.
The behavior of one member of the family is stimulated and shaped by the response of the others.
Well-intentioned yet ironic solutions break the vicious cycle (positive feedback loops) that maintain an impasse.



The rules or regularities of family interaction that operate to preserve family stability.


The conservation aspect of family systems (similar to cybernetic concept of negative feedback).




When a specific behavior within a system changes.


When the rules of a system change.




Rules are typically unspoken, and govern most behavior.
When rules promote rigid attempted solutions, it isn't just the behavior, but the rule needs to change.
When a specific behavior within a system changes = First-Order Change
When the rules of the system change = Second-Order Change


Families are stuck in a spiraling positive feedback loop.
They make common sense but ineffective attempts to change responses.
For example: When a younger sibling arrives, the older sibling, feeling unloved, starts screaming for attention. The parent punishes him which reinforces his feelings of being unloved, and he continues to throw tantrums.
The job is simply to get the family moving again.
Help families define clear and reasonable goals so that everyone knows when treatment has been successful.


Alter specific patterns of communication that maintain problems.
MRI:
The way to resolve problems is to reverse the misguided solutions that have been maintaining them.
Haley:
Changes in behavior alter perceptions (rather than the other way around).
Milan:
Get families to see things differently (through reframing or positive connotation), rather than in getting family members to behave differently.


MRI Group:
Carefully defining the presenting problem and figuring out why it is perpetuated.
Non-historic and symptom focused.
Haley and Madanes:
Examine behavioral sequences around the problem.
Examine structural anomalies (weak parental hierarchies, cross-generational coalitions)
Milan Group:
Preliminary hypothesis tested using circular questioning (systemic explanations).


Find the most motivated person in the system.
Gain clear understanding of problem (symptom).
"What will be the first signs that things are getting better?"
Inquire about attempted solutions.
Observe and interrupt problem-maintaining sequences.
Use therapeutic paradox.
Family encourages depressed member to be sad so he feels less guilt for not being happy.


The solution is to deny that a problem exists; action is necessary but not taken.
The solution is an effort to solve something that isn't really a problem; action is taken when it should not be.
The solution is an effort to solve a problem within a framework that makes solution impossible; action is taken but at the wrong level.


Haley joins and interviews the entire family.
Social Stage -> Problem Stage -> Interaction Stage -> Goal-Setting Stage -> Task-Oriented Stage


Each family member should speak and introduce themselves.
Therapist should ensure problems are not discussed until everyone can speak.
Therapist should examine family seating arrangements to assess organization.
Keep conclusions tentative.


Shift to the therapy stage.
Inquire why the family is there and what the problem is.
Be general and ambiguous so the family can expand.
Respect the family hierarchy to gain cooperation.
Treat those who have power and influence in the family with respect.
Therapist should not share observations with the family.
Therapist should think of the problems in terms of more than one person.


It is critical family members interact with one another rather than with the therapist.
Therapist should redirect family members toward each other.
Assess family organization through interactions.


Families need to define desired changes.
Therapist can act as wise advisor and assist the family in setting goals.


Use of directives (interventions aimed at targeting and changing specific behaviors).


Pre-Session, Session, Intersession, Intervention, Post-Session Discussion
Positive connotation (reframing without blaming)
Circular questioning
Team approach (Reflecting team, greek chorus)
Neutrality


Responsible for guidance of treatment.
We are going to focus on what the problem is.
Be aware of timing and pacing.
Meet client where they are.
Take the time (to form treatment plans)
Respond to subtle pressure from clients.
Avoid attempting interventions prematurely.
Gather enough data about where the client is at before making attempts at intervention.
Use of Qualifying Language:
"I have a suggestion to make, but I am not sure how much it will accomplish. It will depend on your ability to use your imagination..."
Getting client to be specific.
Taking one-downmanship.
The inherent power difference in therapy
Determining the format of meeting.
Individual vs. Conjoint
In what situation will individual session be beneficial?


'Window Shopper' Client:
Re-negotiate contract
Working with the complainant
Get them down to business
Restrictive Client:
Ask permission to redirect
Setting specific boundary



Asking a couple to deliberately have an argument during the week in order to help the therapist to understand how they get involved in such no-win encounters and how they are able to get each other to act unreasonably.
Discouraging families from trying to change too fast, warning them to go slow and worrying out loud about the possibility of relapse when improvements do occur.
Never tell client why we do this.


The family is told to continue or embellish the behavior they complain about.
Sometimes the therapist prescribes the symptom while secretly hoping the clients will rebel against the directive.
As soon as a family member is overwhelmed they are instructed to make a list of all of the things that they might do to sabotage their life. Doing so can take the rebellion out of self-destructive behavior, thus making it less appealing and less impulsive.


Offering a different perspective/framework to understand problem behavior.
"The use of language to give a new meaning to a situation." (Piercy et al., 1996)
Reframes can be offered by asking circular questions:
"Who makes you depressed?"
"What does dad do when you and mom are fighting?"
Changing the frame of reference for understanding behavior leads to change in the rules governing interactions which in turn leads to sustainable change.

Enmeshment

Structural Family Therapy:

item.title: Boundary
item.description: Emotional and physical barriers that protect and enhance the integrity of individuals, subsystems, and families.

item.description: Negotiating the boundaries between members of a relationship and between the relationship and the outside world.

item.title: Coalition
item.description:
Structural Family Therapy

An alliance between two individuals or social units against a third. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)

item.title: Complementarity
item.description: The reciprocity that is the defining feature of every relationship. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)

item.title: Disengagement
item.description: Psychological isolation that results from overly rigid boundaries around individuals and subsystems in a family. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)

item.description: Understanding someone else's beliefs and feelings. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)

item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Enactment
item.description: An interaction stimulated in Structural Family Therapy in order to observe and then change transactions that make up family Structure. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Structural Family Therapy/Key Terms and Concepts/Enactment.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Enmeshment
item.description: Loss of autonomy due to a blurring of psychological boundaries. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Structural Family Therapy/Key Terms and Concepts/Enmeshment.md

item.title: Family Structure
item.description: The functional organization of families that determines how family members interact. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)

item.description:
Linked to Narrative Family Therapy
The art of analyzing literary texts or human experience, understood as fundamentally ambiguous, by interpreting levels of meaning.
Narrative Therapy
Structural Family Therapy

item.title: Hierarchy
item.description:
Structural Family Therapy

Structure
Therapist approaches family problems involving children by assuming Hierarchy in the family is in confusion.
Family therapy focuses on the parents to synchronize parenting efforts to strengthen parental hierarchy.

item.title: Intensity
item.description: Salvador Minuchin's term for changing maladaptive transactions by using strong affect, repeated intervention, or prolonged pressure. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Structural Family Therapy/Key Terms and Concepts/Intensity.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Joining
item.description:
A Structural Family Therapy's term for accepting and accommodating to families to win their confidence and circumvent resistance. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Clients feel a sense of connectedness with you, which usually arises when they feel you understand, respect, and care about them. Joining is both a technique (developing rapport) and an attitude.

Structural Family Therapy

item.title: Structure
item.description:
Recurrent patterns of interaction that define and stabilize the shape of relationships. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Structural Family Therapy
Structure is:
The way a family is organized into subsystems whose interactions are regulated by interpersonal boundaries.
The organized pattern in which families interact
Patterns are formed based on rules that are implicit or explicit.
Over time, as patterns develop, roles for family members are established.
Patterns are isomorphic (i.e., interaction patterns are repeated in different relationships in a system).
The focus of treatment is on changing the family structure rather than changing individual family members.
The process of family interaction is like the patterns of conversation at the dinner table. The structure of the family is where family members sit in relation to one another.
As family transactions are repeated, they foster expectations that establish enduring patterns.
Family structure is reinforced by the expectations that establish rules in a family.
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/Couple and Family Therapy/Therapy Theories and Modalities/Structural Family Therapy/Key Terms and Concepts/Structure.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Subsystem
item.description:
Smaller units in families, determined by generation, sex, or function. (Research Citations/Books/@nicholsFamilyTherapyConcepts2019)
Boundaries
Structural Family Therapy:
Families are differentiated into subsystems based on generation, gender, or function.
Adults are the 'organizational leaders' of the family system so whatever is present in the adult subsystem relationship will be felt throughout the whole system.
Children are common 'symptom bearers'
Organization is most healthy when there are 3 clearly defined systems:
Marital/Couple
Parental
Child/Sibling

item.title: Lecture on Structural Family Therapy
item.description:
Family is depicted as a system that comprised of Subsystem.
A family is functional to the degree that it nurtures its members to negotiate well the demands of the outside world.
Boundaries set limits distinguishing subsystems from one another in varying permeability (from diffuse to rigid).
Subsystems separated by a diffuse boundary are enmeshed, whereas subsystems separated by a rigid boundary are disengaged.


Major Concepts:
Family
Family Structure Structure
Predictable sequences or organized patterns in which families interact
A set of rules governing behavior patterns
Structures typically have some form of hierarchical structure.
Reciprocal and complementary functions.
Parental involvement with children, over versus under involvement.
Structure is expressed through transactional patterns such as:
Hierarchy
Determines who (or which subsystem) has power in the system.
Any structure in a family is not static, it is developed over time.
Hierarchies can be rigid and unfair or weak and ineffective.
Power
Alliances
Structure:
The way a family is organized into subsystems whose interactions are regulated by interpersonal boundaries.
The organized pattern in which families interact.
Subsystem:
Subsystems are often formed based on the patterns of interactions in a family.
Patterns of interaction are largely based on roles and rules.
Covert coalitions are often more significant than obvious groupings.
Families are differentiated into subsystems based on generation, gender, or function.
Adults are the 'organizational leaders' of the family system so whatever is present in the adult subsystem relationship will be felt throughout the whole system.
Children are common 'symptom bearers.'
Organization is most healthy when there are 3 clearly defined systems:
Marital/Couple
Parental
Child/Sibling
Boundaries
Each subsystems is demarcated by interpersonal boundaries.
Boundaries range from rigid to diffuse.

Rigid Boundaries (Disengaged Subsystem)
Rigid boundaries are restrictive and permit little contact with outside subsystems, resulting in Disengagement.
Disengaged systems are independent, but isolated.
On the plus side, this fosters autonomy. But limits affection and support.
Diffuse Boundaries (Enmeshed Subsystem):
Diffuse boundaries are result in Enmeshment.
Enmeshed systems offer closeness, but at the expense of independence.
Too much closeness can cripple initiative.
Coalition
Patterns
Patterns are formed based on rules that are implicit or explicit.
Over time, as patterns develop, roles for family members are established.
Patterns are isomorphic (i.e., interaction patterns are repeated in different relationships in a system)
Triangles
Loyalties


Assumptions:
The family could have developed a structure different from the dysfunctional one now being displayed.
The family processes adaptive resources in its relational repertoire that currently lie dormant.
Therapy attempts to activate what is already there, but latent.
Offers a framework that brings order and meaning to family transactions.
The consistent patterns of family behavior reveal family structure.
The emotional boundaries and coalitions that make up a family's structure are abstractions.
The concept of family structure enables therapists to intervene in a systematic and organized way.
Families seek help for a specific problem.
Family therapists look beyond the specifics of those problems to the family's attempts to solve them.
Exploring dynamics of interaction.
Recognizing the overall organizations of the family regulates those interactions.
The model attends to subsystems and boundaries that regulate contact between members.
The model emphasizes enactments wherein family members are encouraged to deal directly with one another in session, permitting the therapist to observe and modify their interactions.
Structural family therapy provides therapists with a blueprint for how to view patterns of family dynamics.


Theoretical Formulations:
Basic assumption is that families are organized structurally in certain ways to cope with stress.
Organized patterns ensure the survival of the system, all patterns have this purpose.
Systems both responds and reacts to internal and external stressors.
Problems are symptomatic of the family's inability to be flexible and accommodating of changing needs.
All family behavior, even destructive behavior, has the goal of balancing the system to ensure its survival.
Family problems do not result from stresses in the system but from the effects of reactions and responses to the stresses.


The focus of treatment is on changing the family structure rather than changing individual family members.
The process of family interaction is like the patterns of conversation at the dinner table. The structure of the family is where family members sit in relation to each other.
As family transactions are repeated, they foster expectations that establish enduring patterns.
Family structure is reinforced by the expectations that establish rules in a family.


Healthy families not defined by the abundance of problems.
But rather by a functioning structure
Healthy families can modify their structure to accommodate changing circumstances.
Unhealthy families increase rigidity of structures that are no longer functional.
Less adaptive families increase rigidity of structures and are no longer functional.


Problems arise when there are:
Weak hierarchies; conflict avoidance; cross-generational coalitions
Inflexible structures
Failure to adjust to changing circumstances
Failure to reorganize themselves in order to deal with stresses in the home environment.


The ultimate goal of therapy is structural changes to the family
Alter the family structure so that the family can solve its own problems.
General goal: create or strengthen executive subsystem


Therapists have two types of assessment tools:
Enactment
Spontaneous behavior sequences
Enactments occur when a therapist stimulates a family to demonstrate how they handle problems
Therapists guide the family how to modify the enactment, creating new behavior sequences.


Joining and accommodating (effective therapy requires challenge and confrontation)
"The structural therapist needs to relate to family members in a way that validates their experience but does not preclude a challenge to the status quo."
Working with interaction (Use of enactments)
Mapping structural patterns (Observing enmeshment and disengagement)


Focus on the underlying family structure:
Highlight and modify interactions
Intensity (interrupt rigid and difficult patters)
"Challenging to be effective must be predicated on the client's strengths. Contrary to a common misconception, it is not the 'opposite' of joining. Joining and challenging need to be seen as simultaneous qualities in any therapeutic intervention."
Help people do things themselves
Therapists can invite family members to participate and interact in ways that will
Help them function more efficiently


Transformation of family structure
Boundary Making
Loosen boundaries in disengaged families
Strengthen boundaries in enmeshed families
Unbalancing
Reframing (adding cognitive constructions)


Unbalancing
Blocking
Stopping usual transactions
Exaggerating
Encouraging or sustaining interactions
Keeping silent
When a response is expected, doing the unusual by not giving one, thereby demanding the family to react.
Manipulating the intensity
Therapist's comfort level with intense emotions
Enactment
Complementarity
Summarize the cycle of interaction and clarify the systemic nature of the symptoms, relieve blame from any one person, and direct the way to change.

item.title: Salvador Minuchin
item.description:
(1921-2017)

Structural Family Therapy
Enmeshment:
Disengagement:
First-Order Change
Second-Order Change
Became the director of the Philadelphia Child Guidance Clinic in 1965.
In 1981, Minuchin started his own center in New York, where he continued to practice and teach until 1996, when he retired and moved to Boston. He retired (again) and moved to Boca Raton, Florida, in 2005, where he conducted professional trainings and taught courses at Nova Southeastern University until his death in 2017.

item.title: Structural Case Conceptualization
