item.title: 4. Cognitive-Behavioral Family Therapy
item.description:
Engaging and making comfortable
Joining
Creating alliance
Building rapport
Active listening
Open-ended questions
Identifying strengths and why now
Reinforcing positives
Mapping family system/ Genogram
Exploring family dynamics (assessment)
Reflecting
Summarizing
Reframing
Circular questioning
Acknowledge/reinforce


Thoughts and perceptions
Acting or behaving
Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) is a form of psychological treatment that has been demonstrated to be effective for a range of problems including depression, anxiety disorders, alcohol and drug use problems, marital problems, eating disorders, and severe mental illness.
Problems are based in unhelpful thinking and behavior.
Families can learn better ways of coping, which improves symptoms.


Behavior is maintained by its consequences.
Consequences that increase behavior are reinforcers.
Consequences that decrease behavior are punishers.


Behavior is regulated by its consequences.
Responses that are positively reinforced will increase.
Responses that are punished or ignored will be extinguished.
CBT/CBFT is a highly efficacious intervention to assist families in a variety of contexts (this model has empirical support)
CBT has focused on family's cognitive processing and behavioral interactions, while minimizing the influences of individual differences between family members.
CBT also addresses characteristics that each family member brings to their relationships, explaining why family members behave and interpret events in maladaptive ways.


Scarcity of positive outcomes available for each family member.
Deficits in communication and problem solving.
High frequency of negative or punishing exchanges reciprocated by partners, parents, family members.
Family members are more likely to track negative behavior selectively and to make negative attributions for such behavior.
They reciprocate negative behavior with negative behavior.
Primary distress results from unmet fundamental needs create secondary distress (withdrawal or verbally abuse among family members)


Behavior is maintained by its consequences.
Ratio of costs and benefits to behavior (something is maintianing it)
Good relationships are under positive reinforcement ocntrol


CBT recognizes the influence of both the family's behavioral interactions (processes) and the major themes (content) that serve as the basis for relationship discord.


Thoughts change to promote behavioral change (thoughts -> behavior)
Emotions and actions are mediated by cognitions (thoughts -> emotions)
Understand cognition (beliefs, attributions, expectancies) makes it possible to identify triggers to behavioral patterns.
Uncovering hidden/automatic assumptions that keep people stuck.


Overgeneralizations
Magnification and minimization
Personalization
Dichotomous thinking
Labeling and mislabeling
Also called black and white thinking, catastrophizing, defense mechanisms


Help families become more active observers and evaluators of their own automatic thoughts, long-standing assumptions, and of their relationship standards.


Individual family members vary in the extent to which they have a clear understanding of the factors affecting their relationships and clear goals for treatment and how their own contributions affect the achievement of their goals.
Therapist determines the appropriate sequence of addressing goals in therapy.
Extinguish undesired behavior and reinforce positive alternatives.
Ignoring the tantrum; rewarding the child for putting feelings into words
Redefine the family's goals of decreasing negative behavior into increasing positive responses.
Families have difficulty describing the behavior they want to see more of
The therapist helps by asking families to make a list of things the other person did that they liked throughout the week.
Reviewing the list in session the next week provides an opportunity to emphasize the importance of positive feedback.
This agenda of therapy is educational:
Teach communication, problem-solving, and negotiation


Behavior will change when the contingencies of reinforcement are altered.
Identify behavioral goals
Learn techniques to achieve these goals
Facilitate social reinforcement of change


Brief (about 20 weekly sessions)
Use of homework assignments
Phase out therapy gradually.
Once the family shows evidence of substituting positive interactions for negative ones and goals are achieved.
Booster sessions


Collaborate with families in designing homework to complete between sessions.
Homework is based on the learning principle that to replace existing ingrained dysfunctional interactional patterns with new ones, families rehearse the new patterns repeatedly, particularly under 'real life conditions.'


CBFT has been popular in two primary sub-systems:


All couples run into conflict.
Conflict resolution is a critical skill.
Healthy families are not problem free, but they can resolve conflicts when they arise.
They describe their own feelings and request changes in the behavior of others rather than criticizing or complaining.


Good relationships are not made in heaven, they are a product of learning effective coping behavior.
Families need problem solving skills
Therapy includes:
Clinical interview
Rating specific behaviors
Relationship satisfaction questionnaires


Couples are taught to express themselves in clear, behavioral descriptions, rather than in vague complaints.
Couples are taught new behavior exchange procedures, emphasizing positive reinforcement.
Couples are helped to improve their communication.
Couples are encouraged to establish clear and effective decision-making.
Couples are taught strategies to problem-solve future complaints to extend the benefits of therapy.
Ask each partner to list three things they would like the other to do more often.


Imagery
Role-play
Coaching (to switch places, to increase their empathy for one another's feelings)
Communication training
For example:
Engaging in an argument without attacking
'I' statements (Using 'I' Statements.pdf)
Speaker listener exercises (Practice Exercise (Speaker Listener Activity))
Problem-solving training
Homework assignments
Mindfulness and meditation
Sensate focus (p. 164)
In vivo desensitization (p. 164)


Parents ahve control over the rewards and punishment of children.
If parents change the contingencies of reinforcement, the child's behavior will change.
Skills are taught in sequence (shaping)
Help parents define the child's positive and problematic behaviors in specific observable actions.
Tracking target behaviors
Reinforcing desired behavior through contigent encouragement with incentive charts.
Disciplinary tehcniques include Time-Out and ignoring the problem behavior.


Observe/Assess the frequency of problem behavior, what precedes it, and what reinforcement follows (Behavior Chaining)
Shaping (reinforcing small steps toward change)
Token Economy (reward good behavior)
Contingency contracting (agreements by parents to make certain changes following changes made by their child)
Time-Out
Once assessment is complete, the therapist decides which behaviors should be increased or decreased.
Once effective rewards are chosen, parents are taught to shape desired behavior by reinforcing approximate behaviors.
Ignoring
Rewards


Identifying Automatic Thoughts
Assist family members in identifying automatic thoughts
To improve the skills of identifying automatic thoughts, clients are encouraged to keep a diary to jot down situations that provoke the thoughts and the resulting emotional reactions.


Joining with all members of the family simultaneously can be challenging.
Families in conflict often desire to form an alliance with the therapist, each family member trying to convince the therapist that the other members are responsible for relationship problems.
Do not be triangulated!


CBFT therapists hear the seriousness of the concerns while not siding with individual family members.
CBFT therapists use empathic reflective listening with one family member and then the other, followed by statements summarizing the reciprocal interwoven concerns of all members.
CBFT therapists are a neutral party whose agenda is to help family members achieve their personal goals for family relationships.
CBFT therapists often define relationship problems in 'dyadic terms.'
Blocking (e.g., interrupting) if necessary


Inclusion of other individuals if necessary
Medication, and individual therapy can be used in conjunction with CBFT
Co-therapy model is allowed
Both individual and conjoint sessions are allowed.
Clients may be more likely to divulge information about their past in private sessions.
CBFT therapists tell clients they will keep this information confidential, but if it might be influencing the family's current interactions, they encourage the person to share it in a joint session
Secrets
Be up front with clients about the limits of confidentiality
Assist them with sharing in a joint session (rather than outing them)


Didactic role early on to strike a balance between directiveness and collaborationl
Reviews homework assignments, model skills, coaches family members in practicing them, and fosters motivation.
Balances alliances and interventions with all the family members or subsystems so that they feel supported.


Sets the pace of sessions so that the goals of treatment are addressed in a timely and sequential fashion.
Sets the agenda each session
Monitors the use of time
Responsible to stay on task and address the goals of session
Teaches the clients to self monitor as well
Maintains control of the session with confidence and credibility
Assumes multiple roles:
Director
Educator
Facilitator
Collaborator
Advocate
Balances the alliance and interventions with all members, so they feel supported and invested.


Primary Goals:
Identify the concerns and potential areas of enrichment/growth.
Clarify the cognitive, behavioral, and affective factors associated with family members, dyadic subsystems, and the family environment.
Determine the appropriateness of family therapy
Including each family members' level of commitment and goals for treatment.


Information gathering:
Self-report questionnaires, clinical interviews, observation of interactional patterns
Initial conjoint interviews:
How the couple met, what attracted them to each other, how they developed a deeper involvement, positive and negative life events, prior experiences in therapy.
Inquires about the family members' current concerns and strengths of the relationship.
Orients the family to the process of therapy by describing the structure and course of CBFT and the roles of therapist and family.


Increasing the frequency and magnitude and positive behaviors
Love days
Date night
Departing with a kiss
"Work together with the family to develop a series of agreements on how they want to make changes in their relationships to meet the needs of the family members, to help their relationship function effectively, and to interact positively with their environment." (Gurman et al., 2015, p. 36)


For sharing thoughts and emotions (p.38)
For listening (p. 38)
For decision-making conversations (p. 38)
"The therapist provides the family with instruction in the use of particular behavioral skills, through didactic discussions and/or other media (e.g., readings, videos). The instruction is followed by opportunities for the family to practice behaving in the new ways."


Selective Attention
What each person notices about the partner and the relationship
Attributions
Inferences about determinants of relationship events
Expectancies
Predictions of what will occur in the relationship in the future
Assumptions
What each person believes people and relationships actually are like
Standards
What each person believes people and relationships should look like
Socratic Questioning
Understanding the underlying issues through evaluations of the logic of thinking
Guided Discovery
Clarify each person's standards.
Discuss advantages and disadvantages of existing standards.
If standards need alteration, help revise them to form new acceptable standards.
Problem solve how new standards will be taken into account behaviorally.
If partners standards continue to differ, discuss ability to accept differences.


Normalize emotional experiences, positive and negative
Clarify thoughts, then relate these to emotions
Use questions, reflections, and interpretations to draw out primary emotions
Describe emotions through metaphors and images
Discourage attempts to distract the self from experiencing emotions
Encourage acceptance of the individual's experience by family members
For example, asking one family member to recount a particular incident in detail while helping the individual enrich their expression in a way that helps the individual and the family.


Schedule times to discuss emotions and related thoughts with your partner/family member
Practice 'health compartmentalization'
Seek alternative means to communicate feelings and elicit support
Tolerate distressing feelings


Roles become familiar and predictable
Knowledge and skill deficit
Reluctant to change due to being hurt in the relationship


Intimate partner aggression
Infidelity
Individual psychopathology
Health problems
Obsessive-compulsive disorder
Anorexia nervosa


Widely evaluated
Found to be efficacious for distressed couples and families and improving relationship functioning
Effective in alleviating distress and improving communication
Effects have been found in relatively brief interventions (lasting 8-12 weeks)
Finding generalize across continents with experienced and student therapists
Most families appear to maintain gains in relational adjustment for up to 1 year.

item.title: 5. Solution-Focused Therapy
item.description:
Steve de Shazer
Insoo Kim Berg


Miracle question
Rating/Scaling (1 to 10)
Break
After intermission, the therapist will give the client/family compliments, sometimes followed by a suggestion or homework.


If it ain't broken, don't fix it.
Once you know what works, do more of it.
If it doesn't work, don't do it again, do something different.


Solution-focused family therapy begins with clients' descriptions of how they want their lives to be different.
It can be understood as beginning with the end of the story, rather than the beginning of the problem.
The basic idea is to avoid escalating problem talk by instead focus on eliciting movement in a helpful direction (i.e., focusing on solutions).
Focus is on solutions, on what works for clients.
Respect clients own resources.
Directed toward building solutions rather than increasing insight into punitive maladaptive psychological mechanisms.
Future-oriented
Focusing on those times when the problem was not present (exceptions).
The task of therapy is to do something different.
What is happening in your lives that you want to continue to have happen?


The most fundamental difference between the emphasis between problem-focused therapy and solution-focused therapy is the emphasis each give to the concept of 'solution.'
Solution-focused family therapy seeks to identify exceptions to the problem and develop new solutions that work.
What brings you in?
What are your best hopes for this meeting?
Therapists avoid diagnostic categories and preconceived notions of what may be healthy or unhealthy.
Accept the client's version of what is, and what is not, the problem.
It isn't necessary to know what causes problems in order to make things better.
Families that come to therapy are capable of behaving effectively, but their effectiveness has been blunted by a negative mind-set.
The model draws attention to forgotten capabilities, which release families from preoccupation with their failures and restores them to their capable selves.
Problems are seen as overwhelming because families see them as always happening, times when problems are not happening, aren't noticed, or are dismissed.


People are constrained by narrow views of their problems that perpetuate rigid patterns of false solutions.
The meanings people attribute to behavior limit the range of alternatives they will use to deal with a situation.
Changing the way people talk about their problems.
The language of problems tends to be different from the language of solutions.
Problem talk:
Negative
Focuses on the past
Implies permanence of problems.


Clients are experts in their own lives.
Clients know what they need
Is there anything else I should have asked you or that you need to tell me?
The therapist needs to know how to set aside their own frame of reference as much as possible and explore those of their clients.
People are resourceful.
Problems are normal life-cycle complications.
Families have the abillity to construct solutions that can enhance their lives.


Solution-focused therapists steer families away from speculating about problem formation.
Problems persist in the way people define situations and in the misdirected actions they persist in taking.


Set clear goals and build on exceptions to problems.
Good therapy is more than implementing specific techniques, it also involves therapeutic alliance.
The goal of solution-focused therapy is to resolve the presenting problem as expeditiously as possible.
The goal is not about how families should be structured, but only what they want different in their lives.
The model emphasizes the importance of assisting clients in creating well-defined goals, framed in positive terms and modest enough to be achievable.
What will you be doing instead?
The model works by helping clients amplify exceptions to their problems – effective solutions already in their repertoire.
Changing the way people talk about their problems is all that needs to be accomplished.
As the family and therapist talk more and more about the solution they want to construct together, they come to believe in what they are talking about.
It is easier to get people to talk differently about their problems than it is to get them to change their behavior.
Getting people to talk positively will help them think positively and ultimately act positively to solve their problems.
Change perception helps with the change of behavior. As a picture of positive future develops, the family begins to see themselves differently and they respond to what they see.
They begin living in the solution, not the problem.
The 'virtuous cycle' gets going, the family gets unstuck, and they move forward.


Time limited
Sessions are made one at a time
One may be enough
Typical course includes 3-5 sessions
Clients can return as-needed
Often a week to a few weeks apart
Once you know more of what works, do more of it


Gather a brief description of the presenting problem.
Move to directly asking clients about how things will be different in their lives then their probelms are solved.
Ask about times in the clients' lives when their problems do not happen or are less severe.


What do you think the problem is now?
How will you know when the problem is solved?
How will you know when you don't have to come here anymore? What will the signs be?
What will have to be different about others involved in the situation?
What is your wildest fantasy about what you want to happen?


What would it take to get your family member (or the court) off of your back?


Takes little intake information because they want to hear clients' constructions of their problems firsthand (in session).
Asks more about perceptions than feelings.
Affirms clients' positions by conveying understanding of their point of view.
Doesn't function as an expert; clients are experts on what they want to change.
Takes an active position in moving clients away from worrying about their predicament and toward steps to solution.
Anyone who is concerned about the problem should attend sessions and are part of the solution.
Consultant
Guardian of the conversation
Don't get bogged down in 'problem talk'
Focus on what is right
Direct clients away from the problem-saturated narrative.
Therapist attempts to create a context for the family to develop more useful ways of responding.
Focus on the 'here and now'
The future provides a blank canvas on which the family can paint a picture of their wishes and hopes.
Assumes a position of 'not knowing.'


What needs to happen as a result of coming here so that afterward you will look back and be able to say it was a good idea?
What needs to happen as a result of coming here so that this will not have been a waste of your time?
Often in our experience, we have found that in between scheduling an appointment and coming in, something happens that contributes to making a problem better. Has anything happened to improve the problems that brought you here today?
Constructing a more detailed description of the therapeutic goal.


Once a description of the goal has been developed, the therapist asks the client to assess their current level of progress toward

item.title: Acceptance versus Change Interventions in Behavioral Couple Therapy: Impact on Couples' In-Session Communications
item.description:
#Research


Bibliography: Cordova, J. V., Jacobson, N. S., & Christensen, A. (1998). Acceptance versus Change Interventions in Behavioral Couple Therapy: Impact on Couples’ In-Session Communications. Journal of Marital and Family Therapy, 24(4), 437–455. https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1752-0606.1998.tb01099.x
Type: Journal Article
Title: Acceptance versus Change Interventions in Behavioral Couple Therapy: Impact on Couples' In-Session Communications,
Author: Cordova, James V.; Jacobson, Neil S.; Christensen, Andrew;
Journal: Journal of Marital and Family Therapy,
Volume: 24,
Issue: 4
Pages: 437-455
Year: 1998
DOI: 10.1111/j.1752-0606.1998.tb01099.x
ISSN: 0194-472X, 1752-0606

Integrative Behavioral Couple Therapy (IBCT) attempts to improve Traditional Behavioral Couple Therapy (TBCT) by incorporating an emphasis on promoting acceptance into TBCTs emphasis on behavioral change. This study examined changes in couples' communication over the course of IBCT and TBCT. Early, middle, and late sessions were coded to measure couples' communication of acceptance. Results showed that IBCT couples expressed more nonblaming descriptions of problems and more soft emotions than TBCT couples during late stages of therapy. IBCT couples significantly increased their nonblaming description of problems and significantly decreased their expressions of hard emotions and their problematic communication over time. Results support the hypothesis that structural differences between the therapies affect initial levels of emotional expression in session. Increases in nonblaming descriptions of problems were significantly correlated with increases in marital satisfaction.


Keywords: #Research
Purpose: The purpose of the current pilot study was to investigate whether these two different approaches to couple therapy lead to theoretically predictable differences in couples’ in-session communication processes.



“Integrative Behavioral Couple Therapy (IBCT) attempts to improve Traditional Behavioral Couple Therapy by incorporating an emphasis on promoting acceptance into TBCT emphasis on behavioral change.” (Cordova et al., 1998, p. 1)
“IBCT couples expressed more nonblaming descriptions of problems and more soft emotions than TBCT couples during late stages of therapy. IBCT couples significantly increased their nonblaming description of problems and significantly decreased their expressions of hard emotions and their problematic communication over time.” (Cordova et al., 1998, p. 1)
“Structural differences between the therapies affect initial levels of emotional expression in session. Increases in nonblaming descriptions of problems were significantly correlated with increases in marital satisfaction.” (Cordova et al., 1998, p. 1)
“Integrative Behavioral Couple Therapy, developed by Andrew Christensen and Neil S. Jacobson” (Cordova et al., 1998, p. 1)
“an emphasis on promoting acceptance into the traditional emphasis on overt behavioral change.” (Cordova et al., 1998, p. 1-2)
“IBCT suggests that fostering acceptance is an essential step toward improving couples’ relationships.” (Cordova et al., 1998, p. 2)
“TBCT suggests that effective skill building is not only necessary but sufficient for ameliorating distress.” (Cordova et al., 1998, p. 2)
“TBCT is primarily a skill-building approach to treatment. It is designed to quickly and effectively teach distressed couples the skills thought to be necessary for improving the relationship and maintaining those improvements over time.” (Cordova et al., 1998, p. 2)
“Behavior exchange focuses on teaching partners to identify those things they do that are pleasing to each other and instructs couples in the utilization of those behaviors as a means of improving the quality of the relationship. Communication and problem-solving training focus on teaching partners specific techniques useful in facilitating effective communication and problem definition and resolution. Communication training teaches partners the effective use of I messages and active listening as well as the clear distinction between the speaker’s role and the listener’s role. Problem-solving training teaches specific steps to be followed in the process of solving a problem, including problem definition, brainstorming solutions, selecting workable solutions, solution contracting, and solution testing.” (Cordova et al., 1998, p. 2)
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/HDFS Classes/Family Theory II (HDFS 8875)/Lecture/3. Behavioral Family Therapy/@cordovaAcceptanceChangeInterventions1998.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 3. Behavioral Family Therapy
item.description:
Linear thinking:
Behavior is based on previous consequences.
Major Tenet:
Behavior is determined by its consequences more than its antecedents.
Types of conditioning:
Classical Conditioning
Operant Conditioning


Big Picture:
Behavioral Family Therapists are less likely to talk about how families develop and/or operate. They are concerned about the present, and how the problem is being reinforced.
Symptoms:
Although they are reluctant to do so, Behavioral Therapists have delineated what distinguishes a 'healthy family' and a 'dysfunctional family' (pg. 69-74 and 97-104 in FT Handbook chapters)


Mutually shared goals and expectations.
Support for the stresses associated with the expected transitional life stages, and other stressful life events.
Mutual influence, that is positive more than negative.
Boundaries (more implicit by separating family into dyads)
Tolerance for Deviance
Skills in conflict resolution
Adaptability
Flexibility
The ability to change when necessary


The goal of treatment is to change the problem behavior by changing the consequences of it, or the contingencies of it.
Techniques
Use of Self


Parent Training:
Intervention begins with an assessment of the target child's behavior. The goal of the assessment is to get a baseline of the behavior so that you can quantify change.
Functional Analysis of Behavior:
Once the problem behavior is identified, then the antecedents and consequences surrounding the behavior are explored. (stimuli, organismic variables, target behavior/response, consequences, contingencies).
Report the assessment to the family.
Intervene in the pattern.
Step 1: Induction (teach the lingo)
Step 2: Demonstration (show them how it works)
Step 3: Implementation (contingency contracts, time-out, star charts, marble game, etc.)
Generalization:
The goal is that this training will be generalized to other behaviors, but booster sessions are also helpful.


Alexander and Parsons (1982) created for troubled adolescents and their families. Incorporates cognitive aspects and takes a more systemic approach, while the goal is behavioral change.
Integrates three perspectives:
Ecological
Learning Theory
Cognitive
Two Phases of Treatment


Therapy:
Designed to modify attitudes, assumptions, expectations, labels and emotions of the family. The major focus is to relabel (reframe) the problem behavior into something positive.
Education:
Help family behave differently in conjunction with reattributions.


Resistance to treatment is considered an impediment to change. It is a natural consequence of the inappropriate application of technology and failure of the clinician to understand the meaning of the behavior.


Functional Family Therapy relabels behaviors to reduce resistance and to motivate change by providing reattributions for the causes of family members' behaviors.
Change in meaning is a necessary precursor to behavior change.
The relabeling (reframe, positive connotation, etc.) operates at three levels:


Interactional Level:
Benign description of the interpersonal impact of the behavior (distance regulation)
Motivational Level:
Recasts the motive for the behavior in a benign light.
Systemic Level:
Emphasizes the similarities between people, a family theme.
If the reframe works it interrupts automatic processing, interrupts the behaviors that follow from this processing, and thus, changes the contingencies around the problem behavior.


Functional Family Therapy emphasizes paying attention to the interpersonal functions of behaviors:
Functions:
A person's pattern of behaviors, feelings, and thoughts mediate amounts of psychological relatedness in a relationship with another person (distance regulation)
The expression of the function can be labeled good, bad, or neutral, the function itself is not judged.
These functions are properties of relationships not traits.


Linear Thinking:
Cognitive processes need to be incorporated, although some would argue that they were never eliminated in the first place (i.e. cognition is a behavior). Meanings of behaviors, attribution processes, belief sets, automatic thinking can get in the way of contingency change.
Unit of analysis tends to be the dyad:
Behavior therapists have moved toward more contextual assessments, but each move out focuses on the one to one relationship rather than the system as a whole.
Dependency on the therapist?
Therapist teaches the model.
Based on postivism
Not postmodern, it is modern.
Politics of behavioral couple therapy, acceptance.


Same process as parent training. Assessment is always first. Social Exchange Theory viewpoint.
Could include couple discussing an issue in the room, with therapist observing communication patterns. Also includes evaluating the relationship itself (pg. 106-107).
Strengths
Major complaints
Sex life (affection)
Future goals
Alternatives to the relationship
Individual functioning of each spouse
Intervention:
Once assessment is complete you set goals with the clients, focusing on one problem (well defined) at a time, this comes in the form of a contract.
Major Goals:
Increase positive control while decreasing aversive control.
Improve communication, which should facilitate future problem solving.
Interventions:
Active listening with behavioral descriptions of the problem
Teach new behavior exchanges
Encourage couple to establish clear and effective means of sharing power and decision making.
Teach strategies for future problem solving
Techniques:
Caring Days
Make a list of what your partner could do to make you feel cared for. The partner does not need to do anything in return. Do not include sex as it can be seen as coercion.
Quid Pro Quo Contracts
Not very common because we get into the standstill of 'they have to do it first'
Good Faith Contracts
Both partners engage in those behaviors whether their partner does or does not.
Politics and Power


Politics of Behavioral Couple Therapy (i.e. Jacobson)
Jacobson saw the issue with classic BMT as a problem with power, who gets to say what needs to change?
IBCT was developed from these concerns, the focus shifted to acceptance and forgiveness.
IBCT Deep Analysis:
D
Key differences between partners in personality, interests, goals, etc.
E
Emotional sensitivities or vulnerabilities that each partner brings to the relationship (create a vicious cycle)
E
External circumstances (i.e., stressful circumstances which could exacerbate the problems created by differences and vulnerabilities)
P
Patterns of interaction that couples get into as they try to navigate what comes from DEE above.
Intervention based on the idea that all relationship problems result from the combination of a triggering action or inaction and a sensitive reaction.
They suggest that relationship problems can be resolved by altering the triggering action and the vulnerable response (emotional acceptance).
Empirical support for the model in both clinical trials and efficacy research.

item.title: @byng-hallRewritingFamilyScripts1995
item.description:
"We may feel secure enough to explore if we can predict that support will be readily available if and when it is needed, especially if new ventures run into trouble or if potentially dangerous situations arise. Difficulties that lead to consultations with a family therapist often arise out of conflict within the family's own relationships."
"The family script can provide routines for family life which can be followed almost automatically."
"Repetition becomes the background against which change is the foreground, that which is new becomes the focus of attention. In contrast, chaos obscures potentially significant change, unless the new behavior facilitates consistency, in which case that new patter becomes the foreground, thus becoming the new center of attention."
"Rewriting family scripts follows the sequence of a scripted pattern giving way to some improvisation followed by the establishment of a new pattern."
"Family scripts can be defined as the family's shared expectations of how family roles are to be performed within various contexts."
The term 'expectations' implies anticipation of what is to be said and done within family relationships, as well as family pressures to perform the roles as expected. If one member fails to perform in the prescribed way, another member of the family may be recruited to take up that role instead.
The plot is 'scripted' while the cast can change.
Family scripts are revealed when repeating patterns of family interaction are either observed or described.
Family Scenario:
An encounter of which it can be said that something significant happens within family relationships.
Basic elements of family scenario:
Context
Families engaging with each other around a particular task or situation
Plot
Family members 'motives' become clear as the scenario unfolds
Outcome
The consequences of the encounter are revealed
The expected scenarios for each particular family situation thread together to create an overall script for how all family relationships are expected to be conducted in general.
"Problem Scenarios":
Instead called 'Attempted Solution Scenarios'
This helps us to focus attention on how each person tries to solve the problem.
The behavior that is experienced now as problematic may have started out as an attempted solution to an earlier problem.
The co-constructed story may then become part of the family beliefs about what to expect of itself.


Improvising implies abandoning the set script and extemporizing instead. This may happen when the old script does not fit the current situation, or when those involved are in sear of something different.
The therapist can help to create a new co-constructed scenario by suggesting a goal which the family then achieves in their own way.
Suggest a scenario in which it becomes necessary for the family to improvise. (in two parent families, the parents should devise a strategy together)
Try to block each move that has not worked in the past.
Unraveling some of the origins of the scripted scenarios frees families to explore new pathways. Work on the present and the past can reinforce each other.


Replicated Scripts
Parents with their own individual scenarios from childhood that are repeated
Corrective Scripts
Choice of the opposite style of parenting
Improvised scripts
Corrective scripts repeated over time


The therapist's background also plays a part in shaping scenarios in therapy.


Positive Labeling
Can be given to replicative scrips by labeling them as being loyal to the family of origin.
Corrective scripts can be given a positive frame by pointing out to parents that they are struggling to provide a better experience for their children than their parents were able to provide for them.
Improvised scripts (unlike the historical replicative and corrective scripts) are written in response to current situations. They are improvised either out of necessity or driven by curiosity and a wish to explore new ways of relating.
A stimulus for improvisation is a degree of uncertainty about what to do next so that interaction must be played off the cuff.
Positive comments can be made about how much the family is exploring unknown territory.


Attachment behavior
The behavior of a person seeking proximity to his or her attachment figure in a potentially dangerous situation. (This is a mechanism that protects children - or adults - when vulnerable)
The child uses the parent as a safe base from which to explore, and parent and child stay in contact to ensure that they can get together in the presence of any potential danger.
In terms of script theory a potentially threatening situation evokes tightly scripted behavior in which parent and child predictably got together. Exploration allows for more improvisation.
The therapist can become a temporary attachment figure to the family. The therapist must be aware of the factors that threaten the family's relationship.
Any new behavior of uncertain origin emerging in a relationship (e.g., unexplained impatience) might be seen as either strange and treated as potentially dangerous, or novel and will arouse curiosity.
If it is perceived as strange, attempts may be made to avoid reprovoking the impatience, returning to old familiar ways instead.
If the impatience arouses curiosity, then it will probably lead to trying to discover what it is all about, and to improvise ways of dealing with it.
If it becomes clear that the impatience poses a problem and something has to be done about it, new solutions may be improvised out of the necessity to sort things out.
There are two main forms of improvisation in family relationships:
Improvisation that comes out of necessity (Something has to be done when old solutions are not working)
Improvisation out of curiosity when it feels safe to try something new, even if it is uncertain where it will lead.
A therapist who is trusted by the family can make the risks involved in improvisation feel less frightening, even when family relationships are insecure.
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/HDFS Classes/Family Theory II (HDFS 8875)/Lecture/4. Psychoanalytic Models of Family Therapy/@byng-hallRewritingFamilyScripts1995.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 4. Psychoanalytic Models of Family Therapy
item.description:
Most psychoanalytic models are based on Freud's idea around the identity, ego and super ego, or the development of self. For Freud the drives were sexual (in terms of possession and control), for newer psychoanalytic ideas the drives are more around connection and validation of the self (good or bad).
Object Relations Theory in some ways provides a bridge between psychodynamic theory and systems theory. We relate to people in the present based on expectations formed by early experience.
Normal Development (?)
Early development is based on attachment theory/separation-individuation constructs.
Infant is born ready to be in a reciprocal relationship. This is activated by relating to a parent, by being loved and loving.
Stages of development based on object relations: internal object (mental image of self and other, and self in relation to other).


Objectless (primary narcissism/autistic) there is no other, only self.
The following stages focus on the development of self through relations with internal and external objects: first the actual interactions and then the unconscious residue of the interactions.
As humans, we exist in the context of relationships not as single units: There is no self without an object, there is no object without a self.
Infants develop in a context of concentric 'holding environments.' As infants internalize the guarding, protecting, soothing and nurture of this 'holding environment' they begin to form a self (even if the environment is inadequate).
These early experiences then form our 'unconscious' drives for connection or separation. 'Real' others are 'used' to satisfy those drives, and we find others to validate our sense of self (good or bad).


Health: achieving and preserving psychic wholeness through good object relations, integrating our 'unconscious' with our consciousness.
Self and its relationships with others rest on and are expressed by the degree to which relations between the self and object are gratifying (but some theorists would suggest that since we are so narcissistic in the beginning, the relationships with others are never gratifying enough. Is it possible to be healthy?)


Fairbairn suggest that as we internalize objects we are inevitably disappointed by them, in order to defend against this pain, we do the follow:
We split off those aspects that are too painful to be tolerated.
Repress these intolerable aspects.
This modifies the ego.
Pathology occurs when some aspects of the repressed self-object system are excessively repressed, leaving the central self depleted with an impoverished relationship to the 'ideal object.'
Other forms of pathology occur when the central self system is taken over by one of the usual repressed systems, such as those whose relations are characterized by continual patterns of distance and rage with the apparent disappearance of reality.
Fear-dictated flight from early object relations is also considered the deepest root of psychological problems.


Skynner (1981)
Diffuse boundaries
Unclear identities
Satisfaction from fantasy as opposed to reality
Difficulty coping with separation and loss
Attempts to preserve past states of relationships
Attempts to manipulate others into rigidly held views of them


The major goal of Object Relations Theory is to free family members of unconscious restrictions so that they will be able to interact with one another as whole, healthy persons on the basis of current realities rather than unconscious images.
The encounter between the therapist and client is the intervention. The relationship is the crucible for change and growth.
The therapeutic process is the same as 'normal development' during infancy. The therapist provides the holding environment, contains/introjects the clients' emotions, resolves them, understands them, somehow makes them acceptable, and then the client introjects the resolution of the emotions. Therapist projects back a 'corrective experience.'
Self of therapist is key:
Transference and counter-transference are the keystones of any psychoanalytic therapy, meaning the therapist must constantly be aware of who they are' for the client, and who the client is for them.
Change occurs through insight and working through.
Techniques:
Listening
Empathy
Interpretation and maintaining neutrality with respect to what or how things change


Big Picture (how families operate/develop):
He uses attachment theory as a base. Early attachment relationships create 'working models' of how relationships are supposed to be, they create 'scripts.' as people interact with each other to become a family, they create their own 'family script' based on these early 'working models.' families have attachment patterns that are full of meanings about abandonment, engulfment, intrusion, etc. (i.e., distance regulation)
These scripts provide routines for family life which can be followed automatically. They are shared expectations of how family roles are to be performed within various contexts.
These scripts may be carried out from generation to generation in one form or another. Some use replicative scripts (repeat what has happened in the past), while others use corrective scripts (trying not to repeat scripts from the family of origin). There is a constant tension between these two.
Healthy vs. Dysfunctional families
Healthy families have scripts that provide a set of roles with which each member can identify and which provides room for improvisation when facing new situations. These scripts promote interactional awareness:
Consequences of interaction
Self-awareness (why you are acting in a particular way)
Empathic awareness (why others are acting in particular ways)
Understanding the meaning of the interaction
Shared coherent perception of what is happening


Symptoms occur when there is difficulty updating scripts. They may occur because the script necessary remains someone or something too painful to relive. Intolerable information is blocked or edited both intraphysically and interpersonally (secrets)\
Symptoms may also occur when a family script is used to prevent what members may fear to be an even worse disaster. Even though the current script is painful, it is rigidly clung to (the solution has become to problem)


Major goal is improvisation (flexibility). In order to create an environment safe enough to explore options however, the therapist must provide a secure base from which to explore. Paradoxically, scripts, although repetitive, provide the background against which change can occur.
Attachment notions
Secure
Curious
Improvisation
Uncertainty
Insecure
Avoid strangeness
Stick with the familiar


Instead of conflict in the family arising out of one person's pathology which extends to influence another's behavior, family scripts are encoded in all family members' minds, but each family member plays a particular role. Therefore, each member of the family can be taught to see how their role contributes to the problem, rather than asking the 'sick one' to reown the bad object and working through these issues.


Reduce strategies that undermine problem-solving abilities (i.e., triangulating, scapegoating, etc.)
Reduce strategies that undermine security (threats about leaving, control, etc.)
Move toward collaboration rather than coercion and blame.
Re-edit scripts so the roles are fillable by the individuals in the family.
Move closer to an ideal script in which a wide scope of improvising is possible.
Develop a hopeful script.
Promote ownership of family's success, attributable to them not you as the therapist.


This is still important for the therapist to attend to. The therapist needs to contain the family's emotions in a way so as not to become another player in their script. Therapists own scripts can also be replayed, thus it is essential that the therapist understand their own family script. Byng-Hall outlines methods for staying out of the script and for containing emotional impact:
Staying out:
Use teams, get supervision, have a clear plan, use circular questioning
Containing:
Reflecting on the process, seeing emotions as valuable information, differentiating your script from the family's, share your emotional experience with the family.


Absolves people of responsibility for their behavior (it is my mother's fault)
Lack of empirical testing
Tautological thinking:
Make an interpretation, it is rejected, patient is resistant, you must be onto something.
Perspective is individualist or dyadic without revision.
Deterministic, linear thinking (it is my mother's fault)
Blaming the victim (you put yourself in this situation, because of what your mother did)
Mother blaming
Long process

item.title: 5. Bowen Family Systems Theory
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/HDFS Classes/Family Theory II (HDFS 8875)/Lecture/5. Bowen Family Systems Theory/5. Bowen Family Systems Theory.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 6. Contextual Family Therapy
item.description:
Ivan Boszormenyi-Nagy




Biological and historical context variables (i.e., sex at birth, national origin, race/ethnicity, etc.)
Also, events that you had no control over (parents divorce, illnesses)
Anything that would impact how families function.


Cognitions, affect, perceptions, experience, individual coping mechanisms.
Could include attachment styles here or other psychodynamic constructs


Patterns of interaction between family members.
Concepts of family systems theory (Boundaries, Family Rules, Triangles, Differentiation of Self, etc.) could be included here.


This is the cornerstone construct for Nagy's work.
Trust
Loyalty (split, invisible)
Entitlement (destructive)
All of these influence justice and fairness in relationships and are transmitted through generations.


Ontic: 'I-Thou' relationship, or dialogue


Revolving Slate, justice and fairness
All humans have worth and should be provided with 'due care.'
When we don't get the care we deserve we develop symptoms
We develop destructive entitlement which continues the cycle.


Multidirected partiality
Acknowledgement/accountability/crediting
Exoneration
Therapist use of self: you need to believe/live the theory and examine your own entitlements.


Family Transaction & Power
Relational Fairness/Ethical Dimension
Ontic
Facts
Psychology


Dimension II:
Strong emotional reactions (anger, shame)
Behaviors (control-seeking or chaotic/risky)
Nay point to a destructive entitlement. As humans, we are born with value and are entitled to do care. When we do not get that, we develop a destructive entitlement. We seek others to meet our needs. We treat our partner as an object rather than a person in a relationship.
Dimension III (Transactions):
Rigid or chaotic structures
Power struggles
High conflicts
Conflicts over 'nothing'


Violation of trust

Destructive entitlement

Parentification
Parent using the child to get the parents do care needs met.
Overgiving
Over functioning, one of the partners decides what is wrong and how to fix it. They decide what is wrong with the other person and how they need to fix it. Getting into someone else's lane.
Not making 'claims'
People not claiming self. People not holding themselves accountable.
Loyalty conflicts or its 'invisibility'



Restoring trust and balance of fairness in relationships
Opening relational resources
Opening a dialogue about fairness
Direct address
Presenting options
Enhancing an individual's capacity to consider the needs of others and acknowledgement of their acts
Enhancing an individual's capacity to stand up for his/her own needs and to do self-validation through acts
Earned merit and due consideration = balance


Not neutral
Multidirected Partiality
Not being neutral, being multidirectedly partial that you acknowledge each person's perspective and saying 'I get it. I understand why you may think that way.' You want the couples to learn how to validate someone else's perspective. Not agreeing with it, but just expanding the ability for a person to have compassion for others. Getting couples to ask for what
You have been with me long enough you should know. Opening up of relational issues.
People cannot be in a relationship and give nothing. Keep looking for their contribution. Want couples to validate each other and themselves.
As people acknowledge that other people make contributions (due consideration), we feel that we are getting the due consideration.
For couples therapy - considering
Transitional
Nonjudgmental
Facilitating - 'sowing seeds and opening doors' and giving moratorium
But - therapy still can be 'short-term'
Avoids becoming parentified
Therapists' own relational histories may resonate with those of their clients
'Self-of-the-therapist' issues may prevent clinicians from keeping a balanced stance towards members of the family
Therapist does not need to be liked by their clients. Why is it so important that your clients like you? Should your clients get better for you to be a good therapist?


Child maltreatment
Blended families
Adoption and foster care
Couple relationships
Anger issues
Depression
Self-esteem
Self-destrucitve behaviors and substance abuse


Multirectional Partiality
Acknowledgement
Crediting
Anticipatory Listening
Direct Address of Fairness Issues
Suggestions
Summary/Interpretations
Making Accountable
Exoneration


Beginning
Safety and trust
Middle
Dialogue and relational ethics
End
Integration/solidifying constructive entitlement


Establish safety and trust
Alliance building
Assess on 4 dimensions
Facts, individual psychology, family transactions, relational ethics
Acknowledge past - identify transgenerational revolving slates
Screen for risk factors and ethical/legal issues
Emphasize strengths rather than pathology


Relational Ethics and Dialogue
Behavioral changes
Mutual listening and validation skills
Develop effective dialogue skills
Make explicit relational ethics, i.e., power imbalances, broken trust
Make explicit issues involving family-of-origin
Destructive entitlement
Split loyalties
Deparentification
Exoneration


Integration:
Solidify constructive entitlement
Reinforce in calm environent
Balance give and take
Enhanced trust
Continue work with exoneration
Highlight new strengths and resources
plan for the future


De-escalation and soothing
Acknowledgement of the other:
Of reality, points of view
Deeds
Good starting point: "Do you see any truth in her/his words"
Acknowledgement of the self (instead of 'why')
Claiming considerations
Repairing past unfairness
Exploring family of origin model of fairness
Creating a couple's new fairness:
Repair and negotiation


How did your childhood experiences shape your model of what you owe and deserve and your beliefs about love and fairness?
Does love in your family permit you to question what's unfair? (p. 108)
How does your unfinished business play out in your expectations of yourself and your partner? (pg. 112)
What did your parents appreciate about you? (pg. 127)
What happened when you protested unfairness (pg. 133)


Parental accountability and responsibility
Restoration of fairness between generations of adults (parents and grandparents) benefits children
Assessing and addressing:
Loyalty issues
Fairness
Parentification
Checking and restoring age-appropriate balance of 'give and take'
It is desireable to restore relationships with parents even who abused their children because it is a way to self-freedom


Who was there for you? When you needed someone, who did you turn to?
Who did your parent (s) turn to during times of need?
Who did your parent (s) confide in most?
Whom were you able to rely on in times of need?
Whom were your parents able to rely on in times of need?
Whom could you trust in your family to see your best interests?
Whom could your parents trust in the family/their parents to seek their best interests?
Have you ever felt betrayed by any of your family members?
Have you heard from your parents or other family members that they felt betrayed or unsupported by the family?
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/HDFS Classes/Family Theory II (HDFS 8875)/Lecture/6. Contextual Family Therapy/6. Contextual Family Therapy.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 8. Experiential Family Therapy
item.description:
Myth of Fusion:
Human's must come to grips with 'aloneness.' Once we accept our aloneness then we have to make meaning for our lives.
"We believe people who love us should 'just know' what we need."
We have to accept we are a self. Once we accept our aloneness, we must make meaning of our lives.
Freedom and Responsibility
Humanistic Psychology:
Humans are good and move toward growth if unhindered.


Whitaker and others claim to be a-theoretical. However, Whitaker was a systems theorist and used ideas from humanistic psychology and psychoanalytic theory to guide his therapy.
Jay Haley thought he could change a family behind a mirror by telling a therapist what to do. Experiential therapists did not believe this is true. They want the family to be open to their emotional experience and thoughts they are having.
Anti-Technician:
Rather than a-theoretical, Whitaker and other experiential therapists are anti-technician. Manipulation does not encourage open experiencing.


Through feeling expression, families are able to balance separateness and connectedness.


Always 'becoming' or moving forward, toward growth.
Emotions/affect are validated and nurtured. Rules create balance: respect for affect and getting along.
Permeable boundaries which encourage expression of intimacy needs, differentiation, bonding, conflict expression/resolution, problem solving, and playfulness.


Symptoms develop when affect is blocked, impulses are denied and feelings are suppressed.
Boundaries and processes are rigid: holding themselves together is more important than experiencing life.
Superficial experience of emotion, self-denial, lack of empathy, lack of commitment, inability to handle conflict
Little awareness, little sense of choice, flow of behavior is blocked because of unexpressed emotion.
Carl Whitaker suggested that there were 3 contexts to our symptoms:
'Driven Crazy' in an interpersonal context in which person is belittled or disqualified.
'Going Crazy' a state of temporary disorganization.
'Acting Crazy' an adaptation to the context.


Increased personal integrity, greater freedom of choice, less dependence, expanded experiencing.
Strengthening the family as a system by increasing connectedness within the nuclear family and across generations. Enhance ability to support the completion of developmental tasks.


Battle for Structure
Battle for Initiative
Working Phase
Termination
Use of non-rational, symbol, and metaphor.
Use of self is paramount: any technique comes from the therapist's creativity.
Create a new therapeutic environment to alter the family's interaction in hopes of producing a different affective experience.
Interrupt rigid, repetitive cycles
Activate and allow for constructive anxiety or confusion.
Expand the presenting problem
Encourage and support any new decision (freedom to choose).
Create trans-generational boundaries.
Create a therapeutic supra-system in which the therapist and family are aligned, and the therapist still has the ability to differentiate (get in and get out).




Self-Worth:
How people learn to be people
Communication:
The ways people use to work out meaning with one another (Placating, Blaming, Computing, Distracting, Leveling/Congruence)
Placating (peacekeeper)
Blamer (im not happy its your fault)
Computing (have to have a rational explanation, ultra rationale)
Distracting (acts out when there is stress, someone who uses humor)
Leveling/Congruence
Rules:
The rules people use for how they should feel and act, which eventually develop into the family system.
Freedom to comment:
What can you say
To whom can you say it
How do you go about it if you disagree or disapprove of someone or something
How do you question when you do not understand
Taboo subjects
Taboo feelings
Expressing affection
Secrets
Overarching goal may be to loosen up the system so there is freedom to comment. Maybe you say it yourself, maybe use family sculpting,
Link to Society:
How the family interacts with the outside world


When communication patterns are rigid (other than congruence) and continual, and you can't comment on that.
Symptoms are symptoms of the system
Symptoms are created through the process of interaction


Low self-worth
Communication is indirect, vague, not honest
Rules are rigid and non-negotiable
Link to society is fearful, placating, and blaming


Congruence (you the therapist must be congruent) (as a therapist, when you have a sense of what is going on in the room, you say it
“Recording 20240412103404.webm” could not be found.
)
- Only with congruence can we know each other fully and we can use our differences creatively.
Focus of intervention
Helping people change and grow in:
Communication
Beliefs about being able to grow
Restoring the use of all the senses
Therapist use of self is key (as with all experiential models)
To alleviate symptoms you have to intervene in the process in a way that won't replicate their process.
Conditions for Chage
Trust
Development of awareness
Development of understanding
Development of awareness of options
Practice
Universal goal for all families
Development of self-worth
Freedom to comment


Techniques should emerge from the therapist/client interaction.
Techniques are only useful in a context of trust.
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/HDFS Classes/Family Theory II (HDFS 8875)/Lecture/8. Experiential Family Therapy/8. Experiential Family Therapy.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 1. Philosophy of Change Framework
item.description:
Parts in interaction such that the whole is greater than the sum of its parts.
University Resources/Couple and Family Therapy/Keywords/Open System (i.e. human systems) exchange matter/energy with the environment (for Family Systems and our purposes this in information)
University Resources/Couple and Family Therapy/Keywords/Open System s have to have monitoring functions that allow them to pay attention to what is important in their environments (i.e. feedback)
If they have monitoring functions then there needs to be increasing complexity of rules about how to handle the feedback, and when to change in order to continue to grow and adapt to both internal and external sources of information (Rule about interaction, rules about changing the rule of interaction, and rules about change rules about changing the rules of interaction, etc.)
All interaction is fed into the system and becomes both input and output, with a constant flow of information to these monitoring functions, with decisions made to either assimilate or accommodate.
Systems are goal directed, and purposeful using both negative (deviation dampening) and positive (deviation amplifying) feedback.


System Complexity:
An increase in the autonomy of the component parts and an increase in the extent to which the system or its parts determines system behavior (parts of not simply reactive to input from the environment).
Requisite Variety:
A wide range and quantity of varied information, experience and input into the system that is somehow stored for future use.
Morphostasis:
As the system assesses information from internal and external interactions it may 'choose' to maintain itself in the same way, however because of the new information it has to change in some way to stay the same (assimilation).
University Resources/Couple and Family Therapy/Keywords/Morphogenesis:
As the system assesses information from internal and external interactions it may 'choose' to change in order to accommodate to the new information.
These processes are simultaneous and constant as the system adapts and also maintains its integrity.


When continuity and the need to accommodate to change become integrated in the system then the system is flexible and stable at the same time.
When that is happening we would say the system is 'effectively' functioning and capable of growth and change.


Behaviors and interaction patterns will not be repeated unless they serve the system in some way.
If a pattern of interaction is repeated it is serving the system in some way (symptoms serve a function).



How do families operate?
How do families develop?


Symptoms:
What is different about families that are 'healthy' and families that develop symptoms?
How do symptoms develop?
They would not be repeated if it was not supported by the system.


How can we intervene to change the way the family operates given the theory?
What is the focus of the intervention?
Is it having them act in a certain way? What is the focus?
We don't teach them about theory specifically, we are wanting to change behavior

item.title: 2. Families as Systems
item.description:
Parts in interaction such that the whole is greater than the sum of its parts.
Open system (i.e., human systems) exchange matter/energy with the environment (for Family Systems and our purposes this in information)
Open systems have to have monitoring functions that allow them to pay attention to what is important in their environment (i.e., feedback)
If they have monitoring functions then there needs to be increasing complexity of rules about how to handle the feedback, and when to change in order to continue to grow and adapt to both internal and external sources of information. (Rule about interaction, rules about changing the rule of interaction, and rules about change rules about changing the rules of interaction, etc)
All interaction is fed into the system and becomes both input and output, with a constant flow of information to these monitoring functions, with decisions made to either assimilate or accommodate.
Systems are goal-directed, and purposeful using both negative (deviation dampening) and positive (deviation amplifying) feedback.


System Complexity: System Complexity


An increase in the autonomy of the component parts and an increase in the extent to which the system or its parts determines system behavior (parts of not simply reactive to input from the environment)
Requisite Variety: Requisite Variety


A wide range and quantity of varied information, experience and input into the system that is somehow stored for future use.
Morphostasis: Morphostasis


As the system assesses information from internal and external interactions it may 'choose' to maintain itself in the same way, however because of the new information it has to change in some way to stay the same (assimilation).

These processes are simultaneous and constant as the system adapts and also maintains it integrity.

item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 5. The Publication Process
item.description:
Read FGGS Chapter 7: Writing about Your Research
Read 'Publishing in Graduate School: Tips for New Graduate Students'
Read OSU Authorship Guidelines
Read 'Writing and Procrastination' by Kerry Ann Roquemore
Writing is a skill that you exercise and develop over time.
Work towards peer review papers rather than chapters. Books in HDFS are not written often.
Publishing may get denied. The paper may not fit. Journals show their desk rejections online. HDFS journals is minimal (10%-20%). Usually rejected for fit, editor may not like your topic,
3 reviewers if paper has potential, reviewers are people in my field who give extensive paragraph, 3 primary options (accepted (very rare), revise and resubmit (common, substantial changes need to be made, may need to do a couple times for it to be accepted), rejections (happens frequently, still getting feedback, feedback is always something you can improve))
Time you submit to when you get it back (3-5 months usually to get paper back)
How much time you take on a paper will vary
Average time is about a year to a year and a half (if paper is accepted by place you submitted) (publishing early matters)
Revise and resubmit
Institute of Medicine, standards of authorship,
Are your consultations based on this person teaching you how to do it and you do it on your own, or it is them just doing it for you. That could change authorship.
You want your work to serve multiple purposes and how can I make a paper out of it?
Talk to faculty when ideas are flowing to understand if your idea is something that you can actually make happen
Be broad on what you are choosing to work with others. Be thoughtful if project will be a drag on my time or be something that excites me.
Saying yes to something means you are saying no to something else.

item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 7. Professional Organization
item.description:
Go to research conference website and look at travel awards for grad students and how to apply.
Read FGGS Chapter 9: Talking about Your Research
Read FGGS Chapter 10: Going to Conferences
Read 'Why Join a Professional Association' by Kelly A. Cherwin
Read 'Getting Ready for Conferences' by Mark Sample
Read 'Presenting Your Research' by Lindsey L. Cohen, Laurie Greco, and Sarah Martin
Read 'How to get the Most Out of a Conference' by Jennifer Thrope and Todd Ward
Read 'How to Make the Most Out of an Academic Conference' by Thomas J. Tobin
Assignment: (a. What conferences do you think you may want to attend in the next year or two? b. List 3-5 strategies you want to remember to help you develop and deliver a good presentation in the future.)
Some travel support
Advisor can give $250, School can get $250 and grad student org $250 (University level, travel award for

Beyond presenting
Go to conference if being paid to go.
Conference program, look at what is closely related to what you do, methods that you are interested in, go to keynote speakers (Good way to get important sense of what is going on in field, even if not directly related)
You should be going to the majority of sessions every day.
Networking
Conference is great place to meet people
Reach out to professor in advance
Best thing you can do at conference is network with other fellow students.

item.title: Micro-Aggressions, Micro-Resistance, and Ally Development in the Academy
item.description:
Micro-resistances: incremental daily efforts that help targeted people cope with microaggressions. offensive and defensive.
Examples that help increase personal and psychic strength:
Reminding oneself about what you value
Practicing self-care
Caring for myself is not self-indulgence, it is self-preservation, and that is an act of political warefare.
Taking power poses, especially before potentiallys tressful situations
Thinking about the 'bigger fish you have to fry'
Examples that increase your social resources:
Participating in mentoring programs
Building your network of mentors
practicing gratitude
Speak up!
Use OTFD (Open the Front Door to Communication
What can allies do?
Become more informed and empathetic
Give micro-affirmations
Tiny acts of opening doors to opportunity, gestures of inclusion and caring, and graceful acts of listening. 
Support colleagues
Open the Front Door to Communication (OTFD):
Observe:
Concrete, objective, factual observations
Both be able to agree on observations stated
Think:
Thoughts based on observations
DO NOT put other person on defense
Feel:
Actual feelings/emotions you have as a result of the conflict/observation
Desire:
A statement of desired outcome
