item.title: Availability Sampling
item.description: Sampling in which elements are selected on the basis of convenience. (@chamblissMakingSenseSocial2019, pg. 132)
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/HDFS Classes/Research Methods/Key Terms and Concepts/Availability Sampling.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Census
item.description: Research in which information is obtained through responses from or information about all available members of an entire population. (@chamblissMakingSenseSocial2019, pg. 122)
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/HDFS Classes/Research Methods/Key Terms and Concepts/Census.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Cluster
item.description: A naturally occurring, mixed aggregate of elements of the population. (@chamblissMakingSenseSocial2019, pg. 129)
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/HDFS Classes/Research Methods/Key Terms and Concepts/Cluster.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Cluster Sampling
item.description:
Sampling in which elements are selected in two or more stages, with the first stage being the random selection of naturally occurring clusters and the last stage being the random selection of elements within clusters. (@chamblissMakingSenseSocial2019, pg. 129)
There are 'naturally occurring' groups in population, usually geographical or organizational.
Randomly selected clusters. Then sample all units within each cluster, or random sample with each chosen cluster.
Error is smaller if the clusters are similar to each other.
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/HDFS Classes/Research Methods/Key Terms and Concepts/Cluster Sampling.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Disproportionate Stratified Sampling
item.description: Sampling in which elements are selected from strata in proportions different from those that appear in the population. (@chamblissMakingSenseSocial2019, pg. 130)
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/HDFS Classes/Research Methods/Key Terms and Concepts/Disproportionate Stratified Sampling.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Elements
item.description: The individual members of the population whose characteristics are to be measured. (@chamblissMakingSenseSocial2019, pg. 120)
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/HDFS Classes/Research Methods/Key Terms and Concepts/Elements.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Nonprobability Sampling
item.description: Sampling methods in which the probability of selection of population elements is unknown. (@chamblissMakingSenseSocial2019, pg. 122)
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/HDFS Classes/Research Methods/Key Terms and Concepts/Nonprobability Sampling.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Periodicity
item.description: A sequence of elements (in a list to be sampled) that varies in some regular, periodic pattern. (@chamblissMakingSenseSocial2019, pg. 127)
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/HDFS Classes/Research Methods/Key Terms and Concepts/Periodicity.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Population
item.description: The entire set of individuals or other entities to which study findings are to be generalized. (pg. 118, @chamblissMakingSenseSocial2019)
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/HDFS Classes/Research Methods/Key Terms and Concepts/Population.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Predictor
item.description: Independent variable (x)
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/HDFS Classes/Research Methods/Key Terms and Concepts/Predictor.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Probability of Selection
item.description: The likelihood that an element will be selected from the population for inclusion in the sample. In a census of all the elements of a population, the probability that any particular element will be selected is 1.0. If half the elements in the population are sampled on the basis of chance (say, by tossing a coin), the probability of selection for each element is one half, or 0.5. As the size of the sample as a proportion of the population decreases, so does the probability of selection. (@chamblissMakingSenseSocial2019, pg. 122)
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/HDFS Classes/Research Methods/Key Terms and Concepts/Probability of Selection.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Probability Sampling
item.description: Sampling methods that rely on a random, or chance, selection method so that the probability of selection of population elements is known. (@chamblissMakingSenseSocial2019, pg. 122)
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/HDFS Classes/Research Methods/Key Terms and Concepts/Probability Sampling.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Proportionate Stratified Sampling
item.description: Sampling method in which elements are selected from strata in exact proportion to their representation in the population. (@chamblissMakingSenseSocial2019, pg. 130)
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/HDFS Classes/Research Methods/Key Terms and Concepts/Proportionate Stratified Sampling.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Purposive Sampling
item.description: A nonprobability sampling method in which elements are selected for a purpose, usually because of their unique position. (@chamblissMakingSenseSocial2019, pg. 134)
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/HDFS Classes/Research Methods/Key Terms and Concepts/Purposive Sampling.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Quota Sampling
item.description: A nonprobability sampling method in which elements are selected to ensure that the sample represents certain characteristics in proportion to their prevalence in the population. (@chamblissMakingSenseSocial2019, pg. 133)
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/HDFS Classes/Research Methods/Key Terms and Concepts/Quota Sampling.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Random Digit Dialing (RDD)
item.description: The random dialing, by a machine, of numbers within designated phone prefixes, which creates a random sample for phone surveys. (@chamblissMakingSenseSocial2019, pg. 128)
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/HDFS Classes/Research Methods/Key Terms and Concepts/Random Digit Dialing (RDD).md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Random Number Table
item.description: A table containing lists of numbers that are ordered solely on the basis of chance; it is used for drawing a random sample. (@chamblissMakingSenseSocial2019, pg. 127)
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/HDFS Classes/Research Methods/Key Terms and Concepts/Random Number Table.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Random Sampling
item.description: A method of sampling that relies on a random, or chance, selection method so that every element of the sampling frame has a known probability of being selected. (@chamblissMakingSenseSocial2019, pg. 122)
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/HDFS Classes/Research Methods/Key Terms and Concepts/Random Sampling.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Representative Sample
item.description: A sample that “looks like” the population from which it was selected in all respects that are potentially relevant to the study. The distribution of characteristics among the elements of a representative sample is the same as the distribution of those characteristics among the total population. In an unrepresentative sample, some characteristics are overrepresented or underrepresented. (@chamblissMakingSenseSocial2019, pg. 122)
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/HDFS Classes/Research Methods/Key Terms and Concepts/Representative Sample.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Sample
item.description: A subset of a population used to study the population as a whole. (pg. 120, @chamblissMakingSenseSocial2019)
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/HDFS Classes/Research Methods/Key Terms and Concepts/Sample.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Sampling Frame
item.description: A list of all elements or other units containing the elements in a population. (@chamblissMakingSenseSocial2019, pg. 120)
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/HDFS Classes/Research Methods/Key Terms and Concepts/Sampling Frame.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Sampling Interval
item.description: The number of cases between one sampled case and another in a systematic random sample. (@chamblissMakingSenseSocial2019, pg. 127)
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/HDFS Classes/Research Methods/Key Terms and Concepts/Sampling Interval.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Sampling Units
item.description: Units listed at each stage of a multistage sampling design. (@chamblissMakingSenseSocial2019, pg. 120)
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/HDFS Classes/Research Methods/Key Terms and Concepts/Sampling Units.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Simple Random Sampling
item.description: A method of sampling in which every sample element is selected purely on the basis of chance through a random process. (@chamblissMakingSenseSocial2019, pg. 127)
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/HDFS Classes/Research Methods/Key Terms and Concepts/Simple Random Sampling.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Snowball Sampling
item.description: A method of sampling in which sample elements are selected as successive informants or interviewees identify them. (@chamblissMakingSenseSocial2019, pg. 134)
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/HDFS Classes/Research Methods/Key Terms and Concepts/Snowball Sampling.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Stratified Random Sampling
item.description:
A method of sampling in which sample elements are selected separately from population strata that the researcher identifies in advance. (@chamblissMakingSenseSocial2019, pg. 130)
Use if one or more characteristics are focal research interest.
The goal is to compare groupds (strata). The purpose is to make sure each group is represented in the sample.
First divide population into groups (strata). Then a random sample is taken from each group.
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/HDFS Classes/Research Methods/Key Terms and Concepts/Stratified Random Sampling.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Systematic Random Sampling
item.description: A method of sampling in which sample elements are selected from a list or from sequential files, with every nth element being selected after the first element is selected randomly. (@chamblissMakingSenseSocial2019, pg. 127)
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/HDFS Classes/Research Methods/Key Terms and Concepts/Systematic Random Sampling.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Target Population
item.description: A set of elements larger than or different from the population sampled and to which the researcher would like to generalize study findings. (@chamblissMakingSenseSocial2019, pg. 121)
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/HDFS Classes/Research Methods/Key Terms and Concepts/Target Population.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 2. Developing Research Questions and Pre-Registration
item.description:
Go through peer review at a journal.
A place for you to lay out your methodological approach prior to collecting and analyzing data (quantitative or qualitative).
Your methods may be changed (and strengthened through the first stage of review). But this also ensures acceptance as long as the project is completed as described, regardless of results.


Uploaded and stored (typically publicly), but not typically reviewed.
A place for you to lay out your methodological approach prior to collecting and analyzing data (quantitative or qualitative).
When submitting to a journal after getting results, being able to cite your own pre-registration is useful and looked upon positively.


Research Questions
Justification for Questions (Including a Literature Review)
Detailed Methods and Analysis Plans


Look at journals
Look at registries for pre-registrations:
Https://osf.io/registries


Essentially the introduction and methods section of a journal article
Lots of details
Deciding these things up front leads to better science (reduces the temptation to make decisions that are easy, like stopping data collection early, or likely to give significant findings).




Allows outsiders to see your intentions
Guides the design of your methods
Specificity is key.
Without it, your intentions remain unknown and you cannot design a quality study.
Don't jump to methods too quickly.


Proof
Originality
Relevance
Ethical
Personal (Not necessary)


Aims (broad)
Research Questions (specific)
Hypotheses (not always)
Outcomes (expected contribution to knowledge)


Contributes to existing knowledge
Contribution doesn't have to be huge
Replication is a contribution
Being able to express relevance clearly and in non-exaggerated terms is a critical research skill.
Use the current literature (and the real world) to demonstrate relevance.
Literature review is an analysis, not a summary.
Use it to:
Show what you are building off of
Show what you are adding
Filling a gap is not enough justification


Can you do it? Can you do it well? Can you do it in a timely manner?
Money
Time
Your time is your most important resource.
Do not take on a project that you will lead if it only leads to one paper (except for in very rare circumstances).
Try to commit to doing 3 papers on a topic
More efficient time use (e.g., read similar literature)
Looks good when others are evaluating your CV



This is a key writing skill that you will need to do for every paper you write.
And for your Registered Reports/Pre-Registrations
Hook the reader in.
2-3 paragraph formula



Explain the larger context that this study will inform.
Start big and then work down to the end of the paragraph to set up something more specific that is important to know.


Flows directly from the earlier points. If studying X is important, then here is what I am doing.
State the basic aims/hypotheses/questions and give the briefest overview of the data and methods (focusing on strengths).


Explain the potential impact of the specific things you lay out in the prior paragraph. That could be theoretically, it could be in terms of policy, it could be in terms of filling holes, etc.
This is hard.
It can be combined with paragraph 2



Your questions for your Registered Report have to have purpose, relevance, and feasibility.
If qualitative, consider these your 'initial questions.'
Either way, they need enough specificity to guide your research plan.
We often have an overarching aim/question or two and then questions that build on them.
2-4 research questions are most common.

Either edit the questions you have already prepared or developed new questions for your registered report.
Discuss your questions (and their purpose, relevance, and feasibility) with your partner.
As a partner, think about the logic and organization of the outline.
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/HDFS Classes/Research Methods/Lecture/2. Developing Research Questions and Pre-Registration.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 3. Research Ethics and IRB
item.description:
Two course principles that come through today:
Think deeply and early about all decisions you make in your research.
Be transparent about decisions you make and practices you use.
What is ethical?
What approvals do I need to get?
Avoiding harm:
Stress and mental health risk is a key potential harm in HDFS research.
But other things too - job performance, etc.
Avoid undue intrusion
Only ask what is necessary
(Example: immigration status)
Harm threshold: only amount of stress the participant would experience in day to day life.
Informed consent for minors (under 18):
Parents consent, minors assent
Parents provide written consent
Minors can choose not to participate even if their parents consent (e.g., babies in a lab)
Has to actually inform (thorough, readable, understandable)
Has to be voluntary
Power issues
Student research?
Voluntary throughout the study
Only applies to activities covered in the signed consent form
Consent should be in writing unless you have a waiver.
Online surveys; phone surveys
Exceptions to informed consent for active research are rare.
Misrepresentation or deception
Avoid as much as possible
Examples of acceptable or unacceptable deception
When is it acceptable?
Justified (necessary to get valid answers)
Low risk
Provides debriefing
Maintaining confidentiality
Changing more than names
Who is around when data is being collected
Just participating can breach confidentiality depending on study inclusion criteria
Securing data
Always stay up-to-date on current procedures
Always immediately de-identify and sexurely store key
Buck-IRB
Ohio State's Institutional Review Board
Training
CITI CITI Training (2023)
Conflict of interest forms
Submit all research studies for review
Exempt
Expedited
Full review
Amending your study
Knowing what to submit (transparency):
Look at other examples
Use their templates (e.g., informed consent forms)
Ask them questions (but ask your colleagues first)
Describe all study activities (including recruitment and consent)
How are you reducing harm? How are you maintaining confidentiality?
Risks and benefits


Discussed less frequently
Ethics of conducting research that actually leads us towards truths about the world.
Being good stewards of resources we are given (grants, fellowships, time to do research, etc.)
Requires careful thought in our research design and our presentation of our results
What are the costs of HARKing?
Type 1 Error
Narrow Theory
Distorted Science
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/HDFS Classes/Research Methods/Lecture/3. Research Ethics and IRB.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 4. Measurement and Capturing the World Accurately
item.description:
What are the biggest challenges social scientists face when trying capture meaning in the real world? What strategies are helpful to overcoming these strategies?
What is one construct that you are interested in capturing in your research? Thoroughly describe 3 different ways you could capture it in a study (Be creative!!!). How will you determine if your measurement strategy is 1) valid and 2) appropriate for the population you are studying?



Why do researchers HARK and/or use their flexibility in their publications?
Significant findings get published
Desire to tell a good story
Hindsight bias
Need for speed
How do we as a field reduce HARKing and problematic use of flexible decisions?
Demand transparency
Change incentive structures
Use of pre-registration to:
Force less flexibility after the data is collected
Allow reviewers to see a priori decisions
Encourage replication
Encourage/mandate data sharing
Ensuring appropriate use of your findings
How can researchers ensure that there is appropriate use of their findings?
Discussion sections
Engaging with media
Not overstating relevance of findings to practice and policy - especially if exploratory work (e.g., not pre-registered, no replications)


Our desire to advocate can cause ethical challenges.
Harm to particpants (e.g., zone of privacy)
Ways that we present findings and interpret findings
Something to always be aware of and thinking about when making decisions.


Discuss early and often
Follow professional guidelines (and journal guidelines)
OSU Authorship Guidelines
ICMJE Authorship Guidelines
Authorship and contributorship | COPE: Committee on Publication Ethics


Goal of understanding the world accurately (truth-seeking etc.)
Want valid results
Validity is how we think through likely accuracy of our research
Measurement validity=closeness to the truth; are we capturing the concepts we seek to capture?


How do you decide what measures to capture in a study?
Start with your research question.
Conceptualization:
What are the concepts we are interested in?
How do we define them?
How do we define them in ways that are measurable?
Specific
Able to be captured
Need to do for both objective (e.g., income) and abstract (e.g. happiness)


Operationalization:
The process of developing valid measurement of the variables in a study
E.g., choosing measures for survey developing observation protocols, developing experimental manipulations
Independent Variable
Predictor
Dependent Variable
Outcome
Control Variable (Covariate)
We think they matter for both the predictor and outcome. We want to make sure the associations we are looking at are not just
Moderating Variable (Changes the association you are looking at)
Mediating Variable (Process)
Need to conceptualize and operationalize all of these variables in advance.


Goal is to use measures that are reliable and valid
Look to theory for help with conceptualization
Look to prior empirical research for help with measure selection
When possible, choose measures for which reliability and validity has already been established.
However, you will still need to demonstrate this within the sample you collect/use.


Measures cannot be valid if they are not reliable.
Reliability:
Degree to which a measure produces a consistent answer when the phenomenon being studied is not changing
Test-Retest
Internal Consistency
Interrater Reliability
You should be prepared to report on internal consistency and interrater reliability within your own research.
Reliability lets you know if you are capturing something meaningful, but not if it is what you are intending to capture.


Are we capturing what we want to be capturing?
Glossary/Face Validity
Content Validity
Criterion Validity
Discriminant Validity
Capturing psychological constructs is really hard.
Harder than a lot of constructs in physical sciences.
How can we capture constructs better?
Use multiple measures (Kagan)
Natural Observations
Self-Reports
Physiological
Other Reporters
Lab Tasks
Challenges of multiple measures
Lack of correlation
Multiple reasons:
Role of context
Individual perceptions
Brings complications, but can brings us closer to truth
Lorenz and the multitrait model
Think about Venn dyagrams and where shared and unique variance comes from



Just because a measure works for one group of people does not mean it will work for another.
Huge problem in our field.
Choose measures that have been shown to be valid in populations you are studying.
Use measurement invariance testing to make sure the measures are working for subgroups in your population.
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/HDFS Classes/Research Methods/Lecture/4. Measurement and Capturing the World Accurately.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 5. Generalizability, Sampling, and Power
item.description:
Ground Rules for Social Research (pgs. 181-196)
Chambliss et al. (2003)
Henrich et al. (2010)
Duncan (2008)
Roy et al. (243-260)


Measures cannot be valid if they are not reliable
Reliability
Degree to which a measure produces a consistent answer when the phenomenon being studied is not changing
Test-Retest
Internal Consistency
Interrater Reliability
You should be prepared to report on internal consistency and interrater reliability within your own research.
Reliability lets you know if you are capturing something meaningful, but not if it is what you are intending to capture.


Face Validity
Does a test measure what it's supposed to measure?
Content Validity
Assess whether a test is representative of all aspects of the construct
Criterion Validity
Evaluates how accurately a test measures the outcome it was designed to measure
Discriminant Validity
Measures whether constructs that theoretically should not be related to each other are, in fact, unrelated.


The measures we choose will eventually become the variables in our statistical analyses
Continuous
Variable can assume an infinite number of real values within a given interval (e.g., income)
Count
Individual piece of count data (e.g., number of kids)
Ordinal
Categorical variables with ordered possible values; ratings about opinions or perceptions, or demographic factors that are categorized into levels or brackets
Categorical
Dichotomous - only 2 categories (e.g., employed or not)
Characteristic that can't be quantifiable
Always measure things with as much precision as possible
If possible, measure things continuously
You can always collapse things into categories later. (e.g., age [use birthday and day of assessment], hours worked per week [can make part-time/full-time later])
Descriptive Statistics
Want to understand your data
Check for variability
Check for normality
Check for unusual data (e.g., bots)
Check for outliers
Have plan ready in advance
Look at reliability statistics
Look at associations among independent variables
Is a latent variable warranted? (unmeasured variables that is believes to influence responses to a number of survey items)
Do not look at associations (even correlations) among independent variables and dependent variables (HARKing)


Qualitative research also needs to demonstrate rigor.
Looks very different
Validity is about ensuring appropriate conclusions are drawn - based on what informants provide and theoretical lens being used
Rigor occurs throughout the research process, not just at the beginning or the end (also true for quantitative work)
Role of verification


Role of verification
Iterative process between the data and the literature
Responsiveness
Requires knowing your data, knowing how to listen, and knowing how to synthesize
Flexible in way of processing data
Sampling
Saturation
Seeking negative cases
Audit trails
Member checks


You need to demonstrate how your data or data collection plan is valid.
Quantitative studies: reliability and validity; prior studies; how does this measure capture the constructs you are talking about in your literature review and research questions?
Qualitative studies: What steps are you taking to ensure rigor?



The literature review/introduction will direction follow your opening 2-3 paragraphs.
Goal is to explain the rationale for the work you are doing.
Not to comprehensively summarize every related study ever
Show your work builds off of prior theory and empirical work
Highlight the unique contributions of your work


Although you may not review every related study, you need to do a thorough literature review to understand how your study relates to others and how your study fits.
Focus on peer-reviewed journal articles
Try to get a sense of paper by looking at abstract and skimming before committing to fully reading
To do this more effectively, you should plan out the sections of your literature review in advance


Based on your questions
Provide an organization/headings for your literature review
Your questions may be a series of questions (each will become a header in your literature review/introduction)
Or your questions may build upon each other


Your sequential logic becomes the headers for your introduction
And it ensures that you know the 'argument' for each section (because you have the arrows drawn and connections made already)
Note: your argument does not mean you ignore findings that don't support your hypothesis - you use them as arguments as to why your research is needed.
Ultimately, should match your first 2/3 paragraphs, methods, results, and discussion.


Keep your headings general and big picture
Consider ending with a, 'The present study...' section
May have to include a conceptual or theoretical paragraph somewhere
Often easier to discuss theory within your aims-based headings
Try not to use jargon, simple words instead
Do not repeat yourself even if it is written in a different way (e.g., put another way)
Do not provide laundry list of extant literature; instead, synthesize


What is it? Is it attainable?
Think about research you have read recently? Do you think they have adequately discussed generalizability?
Big takeaways:
Being as thoughtful as possible about our sampling plan before collecting data is going to help us create higher quality research.
Be transparent about the ways in which your research is or is not generalizable.
Getting good samples is really hard. Your research doesn't have to be perfect (remember no study is).
Sample Generalizability:
Can findings based on a sample be applied to the larger population from which the sample was drawn?
Need for 'thick description'
Cross-Population Generalizability
Can findings from a study of one population be applied ot other populations?
Usually infers in universality (although doesn't have to)


Sampling is unnecessary if all the units in the population are identical (e.g., blood)
But what about people?
Are fundamental psychological processes the same across all people (universal)?


When random sampling is not possible
Availability (Convenience) Sampling:
Take who you can get
Exploratory or qualitative research
Intro to psych!
It is okay to use convenience sampling but you need to be aware of and acknowledging your limitations.
Quota Sampling:
Make sure sample represents certain characteristics in the population (but can't know all characteristics, and not random)
This is not as good as random/probability sampling but is still a much improved strategy over convenience sampling.
Purposive Sampling:
Studying a subset of limited group
Studying 'key informants'
High on internal validity


Population:
The entire set of individuals or other entities (e.g., families, schools) to which study findings are to be generalized
Census = study the whole population
Sampling Frame
A list of all the elements in a population
Sample
A subset of a population used to study the population as a whole
Two factors that make it easier to get a representative sample:
Larger samples are more likely to be representative
Sample size does matter in quantitative research
Both for generalizability and power
However, unthoughtful sampling doesn't improve much with larger samples.
It is easier to derive a representative sample from a homogenous population (i.e., can have a smaller sample)


Allows us to know in advance how likely it is that any element of a population will be selected.
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/HDFS Classes/Research Methods/Lecture/5. Generalizability, Sampling, and Power.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 6. Studying Diverse Populations
item.description:
Cases (individuals, families, etc.) are only selected on the basis of chance
Keep in mind:
You must know the population (your sample frame)
Poor response rates makes your sample nonrandom and thus nonrepresentative


Cluster Sampling:
Random sample of clusters is drawn
Random sample of elements within each selected cluster is draw
At least to stages of sampling
Really helpful for studying populations with large geographic area OR when it is easier to sample from groups (e.g., within classes instead of randomly at OSU)
When cluster sampling is used, sampling weights are also used to make sure the descriptive information of the sample will match that of the population.
Stratified Random Sampling:
To ensure that various groups are included in your sample
Proportionate:
Random sampling in direct proportion to groups in population
Disproportionate:
Proportion of each group does not match population
Pros of Disproportionate Sampling
Facilitate group comparisons
Enable the study of within group processes
They still allow for population-level generalizability


Why should we strive for population representative sampling
Importance for policy or practice (We don't want to recommend changes that aren't based on research that is representative of the full population those changes would impact.)
How?
Narrow our populations of interest (e.g., Columbus instead of the US)
Work on large teams
Use secondary data


How do you get a full list of your population
Phone numbers
Addresses
What is your population is subjective? (e.g., likely voterts, experienced trauma) - need to operationalize wel
Really hard to do for large populations with individual-level units
Easier with something like hospitals or schools
Easier to do with more targeted populations (e.g., OSU) but still confidentiality issues


How do you actually reach the individuals that were randomly selected to be sampled?
Who actually is willing to participate?
If participation rates are incredibly low, are our samples still representative?


Who stays in our sample?
Another way that our sample can end up biased in longitudinal work
Generalizability concerns (e.g., what if families experiencing poverty dropout at much higher rates)
Causal validity concerns (e.g., what is the individuals experiencing the most acute depressive symptoms are more likely to leave our study of a new therapy model?)
Are design and statistical ways to reduce the impact of this problem but still needs to be avoided as much as possible.


You will likely work a lot with quota or convenience sampling in your quantitative work. That's okay but:
Recognize the limits of your works generalizability
Think about the balance across types of validity
See if there are representative samples available to use to answer your questions
Pair multiple datasets (e.g., a representative secondary dataset with less great measurement with a datasetr you collect with great measurement)
What do we learn across studies?
Again, the goal is to do valid, high quality research and to be transparent about how the strengths and limitations of our work shape its contributions to our knowledge and understanding of the world.
Aim for the best sampling plan, but recognize it may not happen immediately.
Putting your sampling plan into a pre-registration that details your target population (even if not random sampling), planned sample size, and strategies for recruitment helps you establish a solid plan.
Talk to others who do similar research. How do they find participants?


WEIRD
Diversifying our samples is not enough; we need to think critically about how our work (and our methods) acknowledge/incorporate/ignore systems of power and oppression in the world


Placing onus on individuals or groups rather than structures and environment
Moving beyond disparities to what creates these disparities
Thinking about strengths-based approaches


Should we control for things like race, gender identity, immigration status?
Within-group analyses ideal
Using moderation to understand key processes also ideal
When not available, controlling for these things is another option, but need to think through and justify why or why not


What is structural racism?
Moving beyond the individual
Policies, lived environments, etc.


Individuals hold multiple identities
Commonly examined in qualitative work, but important for quantitative research as well
Key principle:
Cannot simply add up the experiences of multiple marginalized identities - need to understand the complex ways in which multiple identities shape experiences


Between Group
Default comparison group
Inability to look at how processes vary across groups
Assume homogeneity
Within Group
Highlight unique processes within groups
Allow for examination of heterogeneity within a population


Measurement invariance
Do measures operate in the same way for different groups of people?
Easy to test statistically in a latent framework
Do items hang together the same way? (reliability)
Does the measure have the same construct and discriminant validity?
If we don't ensure our measures are appropriate for the participants we are studying, we are not going to get closer to truths about the world.


Understand that your own bias shapes the question
How would answering that question enhance children's lives?
The potential solution (s)



Problem focused
What is missing that we must go find?
Leads to depression, dysfunction, and learned helplessness


Opportunity focused
What is present that can be leveraged and build on?
Leads to innovation and meeting the needs of the community.


Acknowledign your positionality
Researcher
Other identities
Building relationships with organizations, community laders, and community members
Identifying your sample
Based on the literature about that sample
With deedback from community members
Attending to any comparisons within your sample and how you will provide context for them
Ensuring sample is not confounded by race/income
If it is, generalize your findings specifically to the sample study is drawn from
Ensuring sample is representative of the communities being studies
Ensuring that pan-ethic and racial groups effect the heterogeneity
If they do not, address this when discussing your work.


Research measures should accurately and truthfully capture your data of interest
Use of inappropriate measures can lead to biased findings
Leading to deficit framing of your population
Do not be race 'mute' or 'blind' when choosing measures
Interrogate race when identifying what to measure and how to measure it
Measures should yield equitable data for BIPOC participants
Do your measures allow for your sample's BIPOC, strengths to be highlighted?
If no, you need to re-assess your measurement choice
Reliable and valid for your population
Culturally relevant
What do you do when the measures for your variables of interest do not have reliability or validity estimates for your population?
Identify multiple forms of measure
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/HDFS Classes/Research Methods/Lecture/6. Studying Diverse Populations.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 7. Casual Validity
item.description:
Correlation does not equal causation.


Rule out other explanations.
Make sure timing works (cause happens before effect).
Is there a plausible mechanism?


Causality can only be inferred from research design.
Statistical significance does not mean causality.
No statistical analysis alone can lead to causal findings.
Needs to be in combination with appropriate research design.


Self-selection
Endogeneity
Third variables
Common cause
Omitted variables


Randomized Experiments/Randomized Control Trials
Best causal validity (when done right)
Still have to work about equivalence and artifacts
Natural Experiments/Quasi-Experiments
Have exogeneity which provides some causal validity
But still have to rule out alternate explanations
Observational Designs
Observational = no external agent causing change like in an experiment or quasi-experiment
Are NOT causal!
But we can take steps to rule out alternative explanations, which brings us closer to causal validity


How do RCTs get around 3 rd variable problem?
Random assignment
Ensures that charactertistics of the individuals (or families, schools, etc.) are not related to your independent variable (treatment)
So, the relationship between your treatment and your outcome (dependent variable) is not influence by 3 rd variables
Randomized is the method to get causal estimates


Randomization ensures that your treatment is independent from characteristics of your sample/3 rd variables but not that the treatment group and control group are equivalent
In large numbers, they usually are.
Need to check for statistical equivalence - also known as baseline equivalence


Artifacts are issues that can arise in RCTs that may bias your results and reduce your ability to make causal statements
Hawthorn Effect
Individuals modify an aspect of their behavior in response to their awareness of being observed
Placebo Effect
A substance that has no therapeutic effect, used as a control
Contamination
When the members of one group in a trial receive the treatment or are exposed to the intervention that is meant for the other group. The result is a minimization of any real difference that exists between the groups.
Demoralization
Issue in which those in the control group become resentful of not receiving the experimental treatment.
Non-Compliance
Any failure to adhere to requirements for conducting research that may reasonably be regarded as presenting a genuine risk of substantive harm to the safety, rights, or welfare of human research participants.
Attrition
Loss of study units from a sample; the selective dropout of some participants who systematically differ from those who remain in the study
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/HDFS Classes/Research Methods/Lecture/7. Casual Validity.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 8. Longitudinal Design (NEED TO UPDATE)
item.description:
Something occurs outside of researcher control that leads to pseudo-randomization
Casino opening
Laws changing
Airports closing
Provide plausible exogeneity (the change is unrelated to characteristics of those treated or untreated)
Need to check for artifacts as in random controlled trials
Plus other potential biases
Other things changing, hidden 3rd variable problems.


Are similar to natural experiments but often involve more researcher intervention. (Quantify what determines how to give treatment)
Regression discontinuity
Does going to kindergarten shape behavioral and brain development?
Key is that the assignment variable (e.g., cutoff) is quantifiable.
Instrumental variables
Matching techniques
Choosing an appropriate comparison group
These are not fully causal but provide better approximations than most.


Most common quantitative approach in HDFS
Some things are hard/unethical to randomly assignment and not likely to occur in natural experiment design.
But they are always suspect to 3rd variables (hence not causal)
How do we improve causal validity in observational designed
Establish time ordering
Have a plausible mechanism
Rule out 3rd variables using covariates
How do we choose 3 rd variables to rule out?
The influence of attending a private school (as compared to public) on reading achievement
The influence of financial security on relationship quality
Control variables need to be carefully planned out based on your research question and plausible 3rd variables.
Need to be planned out in advance so that:
You actually collect them
You don't fall suspect to p-hacking
Use of proxies as covariates
Don't use mechanisms as covariates


Statistical significance helps us rule out chance as a reason for any associations we find in our studies (random controlled trials or observational)
But doesn't establish causality
Confidence intervals provide more information
Remember, causality does not mean certainty
Probabilistic nature of social science


Randomized Experiments/Randomized


Length of overall study
Frequency of follow-ups
How intense are follow-ups?
Phone, lab?
Long, short?
Emotional draining?
Match to theory and your conceptualization
But recognize practical limitations and tradeoffs.

item.title: 14. Practical Skills
item.description:
Three reasons you should care about data management:
Federal funders are moving to requiring a data management plan
You need to share your data when the grant is over
You'll need a plan that will have your data ready to share publicly by the time you're done.
Science is more interesting when it's true:
Data management makes your data and your conclusions more accurate.
Some researchers are very uncomfortable with data sharing.
They make 3 basic arguments:
It was my idea to collect these data.
I did all the work
It's against the ethos of science
This will be required for federal grants:
Data should be owned by the public that funded it
Allows data to have a wider reach
Makes sharing with other authors easier
Keeps data archived and accessible long-term


The Inter-University consortium for Political and Social Research (ICPSR)
Lots of resouirces on how to share
Good confidentiality and maintenance policies
OSU already pays for a site license so it is free



Where you're going is dependent on collecting good information.
Important to have analyses in mind when choosing what to collect
Be thoughtful of how you present and word questions to your participants.
Make sure your instructions are clear.
One of the first things you have to do is select measures.
You can't answer a question you haven't measured on your participants.
It is important to select ones that reliably and validly measure what you want to know.
Document everything.
It is hard to remember what you measured, when you measured it, or why you measured it. Your best defense is well documented protocols, a good codebook, documentation of what all of your variable names mean.


Key to success with any project is writing things down.
Future you won't remember what current you decides to do today, or why you decided to do it.
Protocols are written documentation of the decisions you make when designing your data collection.
They are living documents that should be continuously updated.
They have two important points:
The decision made
Document who made the decision and when
The decision is a rule to be implemented across the project
A rationale for why the decision was made.


Think about someone else using your data later, and what they will need to know.
Every project has at least two investigators:
You
Future you


Inclusionary criteria for participants
Recruitment procedures
Assessment administration
Training of project staff
Communication with participants
ID schemes
Protocol Example:



Can convey lots of information (but doesn't have to)
Most important thing is that you make a rule and don't change
Once a participant has an ID don't change
Don't change it
We always have a protocol for:
What an ID looks like
When an ID gets assigned



The shortened digital representation of each variable in your dataset
Column names
Important that all variable names are unique
Variable names follow a rule:
Develop a naming convention for yourself
Be consistent across datasets (and projects if possible)
For item level data, always put the number of the item LAST.
Global variable naming protocol:
XXXX#YYY or PPVT1001
X: Short Survey / Scale
#: Timepoint
Y: Unique Identifier
You can make your own rule, but make sure you document them.
Don't change them.


A codebook is a key translating what you give participants into the data you store.
Necessary to link between the items given and the variables in your database.
Makes interpretation and analysis easier later.


Variable values follow similar rules
Keep them consistent across your project
Document them in the codebook
Think about someone else using your data later, and what they will need to know.
Hack:
If you have a dichotomous variables, don't name it after the construct.
Name it after a category, such that 1 = yes or has that attribute.
For the question: Is your house green or red? (Bad: 'HouseColor'; Good: 'HouseGreen')
With multiple response questions, make sure the order of options makes sense. (Bad: '-20k, 10k, <10k, >20k'; Better: -<10k, 10k, 20k, >20k)


Tracking your participants (master list, consort, change form)
Tracking data collection (on the fly messiness, scheduled and completing data)


A master list is a list of every person the project touches.
You may have a sub-master-list, which contains only those participants who you have assigned an ID.
How do you determine who gets an ID?
You make a decision and you write it down and you don't change it.
The master list is a living document from which nothing should ever be deleted
Contains basic demographic and contact information
This is the lifeblood of the project - how you determine who needs to be assessed and when
All information in the master file needs to be stored as letters or numbers


Consolidated Standards of Reporting Trials
Primarily concerned with RCTs
Consort's diagram is a useful framework for documenting your study.
“14. Practical Skills-20240416182721764.webp” could not be found.
“14. Practical Skills-20240416182823221.webp” could not be found.- Consolidated Standards of Reporting Trials
Primarily concerned with RCTs
Consort's diagram is a useful framework for documenting your study.

Longitudinal Options:



Participants in studies are transient.
Keeping track of movement of participants is important.
You can keep track of this in multiple ways:
The Master List
A separate excel log
A form or digital form



Backing up your data is one of the most essential steps in data processing.
This may mean scanning or copying paper data or a more sophisticated digital system.
Try to make sure that your department/university has a file server.
Shared drive
Allow for multiple computers to access the same datafiles.
Easier to set back-ups.


Every data set has some problems. If you don't think you have data problem, then you haven't looked at it yet.
Data needs to be cleaned to be used meaningfully. Be flexible because data cleaning is hard.
Avoid manually-entered questions.


Create an organizational system for the data files.
Create a system for tracking issues and resolutions (codebook/protocol)
Ensure variables and values match those in the codebook
Run descriptives on key variables/calculated scores
Do the means make sense across ages/grades/timepoints?
Eyeball the data
Compare actual data capture to data in database





Final inclusion of SSRS in Released Publishable Database:
- Total scores and standards scores
- For each of the two subscales
- At each of the three time-points
- For each of the two raters (parents and teachers)



After final dataset is made, never touch it again.
Make a copy of the final, clean dataset. Store it somewhere separate as backup.
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/HDFS Classes/Research Methods/Lecture/14. Practical Skills.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Ground rules for social research: guidelines for good practice
item.description:
Bibliography: Denscombe, M. (2010). Ground rules for social research: Guidelines for good practice.
Type: Book
Title: Ground rules for social research: guidelines for good practice,
Author: Denscombe, Martyn;
Publisher: Open Univ. Press, McGraw-Hill,
Location: Maidenhead,
Series: Open Up study skills
Year: 2010
ISBN: 978-0-335-23381-6



Keywords: In Progress


(Denscombe, 2010, p. 17)
“the purpose of the research is something that needs to be understood concisely, precisely and right from the beginning.” (Denscombe, 2010, p. 22)
“a clear vision of the purpose of research provides a crucial basis for evaluating the research” (Denscombe, 2010, p. 22)
“This allows readers to evaluate the research by providing benchmarks against which to judge the extent to which the research has been successful.” (Denscombe, 2010, p. 22)
“a clear vision of the purpose of research provides a good platform from which to conduct the investigation. This applies whether the research uses a quantitative, a qualitative, or a mixed methods approach” (Denscombe, 2010, p. 22)
“Clarity of purpose also calls on the researcher to identify a relatively narrow and precise area for investigation rather than setting out to investigate some general area of interest. It requires the researcher to focus attention on specific aspects, specific questions, specific issues within the broader area of interest.” (Denscombe, 2010, p. 22)
“unless some quite specific topic is pinpointed, there is the very real danger that: • researchers will ‘bite off more than they can chew’; • researchers will flounder in a sea of vast quantities of issues and data; • time will be wasted on the collection of unnecessary information; • time will be wasted on meanderings up blind alleys before a clear direction becomes evident; • vague questions might lead to vague answers.” (Denscombe, 2010, p. 22)
“Social research questions must be, in principle, testable. Explanations and theories must be open to proof or disproof” (Denscombe, 2010, p. 23)
“The research should also offer something new.” (Denscombe, 2010, p. 23)
“The literature review is particularly important” (Denscombe, 2010, p. 23)
“To offer something new or different, the research needs to build on existing knowledge and link to what is already known on a particular topic or issue.” (Denscombe, 2010, p. 23)
“Good research avoids the pitfall of being over-ambitious in terms of its scale and its scope.” (Denscombe, 2010, p. 24)
“it is essential that the research does not set out to do something that is illegal or immoral.” (Denscombe, 2010, p. 24)
“the project researcher should ensure that his/her activities accord with ethical standards and codes of conduct that operate for the discipline, the profession and the country in which the research is located.” (Denscombe, 2010, p. 24)
“descriptive research, which provides detailed accounts of events or situations in order to gain a clearer picture of what is going on.” (Denscombe, 2010, p. 24)
“explanatory research, which is mainly concerned with cause–effect relationships. It builds on well-established theories with a view to developing them and using them to make predictions that can be tested. It aims to explain why things happen.” (Denscombe, 2010, p. 24)
“exploratory research, which investigates new areas and which seeks to generate new theories and concepts.” (Denscombe, 2010, p. 24)
“The rights and interests of participants and others directly affected by the research will be taken into consideration. The research will be conducted in accord with an appropriate code of research ethics. Approval will be sought from a relevant ethics committee or institutional review board. The research will be conducted in an honest, open and transparent manner – as far as it is possible.” (Denscombe, 2010, p. 73)
“Ethics refers to the system of moral principles by which individuals can judge their actions as right or wrong, good or bad” (Denscombe, 2010, p. 73)
“researchers need to introduce a moral perspective to the way they design and conduct their investigations.” (Denscombe, 2010, p. 73)
“need to consider what will be acceptable in the context of the values of the wider society in which the research is conducted” (Denscombe, 2010, p. 73)
“The motivation for researchers to operate ethically should be a matter of professional integrity” (Denscombe, 2010, p. 74)
“‘The acceptability of social research depends increasingly on the willingness of social researchers to accord respect to their subjects and to treat them with consideration.” (Denscombe, 2010, p. 74)
“Research that does not do this will damage the reputation of social research” (Denscombe, 2010, p. 74)
“without the good will and trust of the public large parts of social research will become starved of information.” (Denscombe, 2010, p. 74)
“Research” (Denscombe, 2010, p. 74)
“must take account of the moral and legal climate of the time and the boundaries this places on the topics of investigation that are deemed acceptable and the nature of the methods of investigation it tolerates.” (Denscombe, 2010, p. 74)


Ground rule: Research should produce findings from which generalizations can be made.
Either the research is based on a sample of people, events, or data that are representative of the wider population (generalizability).
Or sufficient information is given about the characteristics of the sample or the cases used in the research for judgements to be made about the extend to which findings can be expected to apply more widely (transferability).
Or the people, events, or data included in the research have been chosen because of their particular characteristics and the belief that these characteristics will be helpful for generating and developing theories (theory relevance).
“A generalization involves drawing some conclusion about a whole group or category of things on the basis of information drawn from particular instances or examples. On the basis of what is found to exist in a relatively few instances or examples, propositions are made about the nature and qualities of the whole class.” (Denscombe, 2010, p. 195)
“Researchers usually wish to feel confident that their findings have been based on samples that are either representative of, or have particular characteristics that are significant for the analysis of, the broader class of thing being investigated. Another reason centers on the researcher's wish to produce generalized knowledge in the form of theories.” (Denscombe, 2010, p. 195-196)
“The concern with generalizations relates to the way findings from specific pieces of research lend themselves to the development of propositions that work very widely – possibly universally – and that contribute to establishing rules or theories about the workings of social phenomena.” (Denscombe, 2010, p. 196)
Generalizations
Continue to be a crucial aspect of good research for all but a small minority of those operating under the umbrella of ‘social research’
Can be justified in different ways depending on the nature of the particular research and its underlying assumptions
Need to be incorporated into the rationale for the research.” (Denscombe, 2010, p. 196)


“the criteria for selection are the crucial starting point when it comes to generalizations.” (Denscombe, 2010, p. 196)
“the selection of the items to be included in the study needs to be done on a logical basis – a basis that allows generalizations from the data to be defended as reasonable and justifiable – and within social research there are broadly two approaches to this matter. One way is to go for a representative sample. This tends to be favored by relatively large-scale survey research using quantitative data and a positivistic approach. The alternative is to select the items for study on the basis of their particular characteristics. Smaller-scale research involving case studies, qualitative data and an interpretivist approach tend to rely on this.” (Denscombe, 2010, p. 196)
Do the findings from the research apply elsewhere?
Have the criteria for selection of the people, events, or data been described and justified?
Reflecting the criteria for selection, have an adequate number and appropriate diversity of people, events, or data been included in the research?
Does the description of the sample or cases used in the research allow comparisons with others of their type?


Research tends to focus on a reduced number of instances of the thing under investigation. It investigates a sample or it investigates specific cases.
To what extend do the findings from the sample or case apply to other instances that were not included in the study?
To be representative, samples need to:
Cover all relevant types
Have these types in proportion to the volumes found in the whole population
A representative sample includes a balanced cross-section of all of the relevant instances. This justifies generalizing from the findings of the sample.
To achieve representativeness:
Use of random samples.
Provided that the units included (people, observations, etc.) in the research are sufficiently large and are chosen on a genuinely random basis, the end result ought to be representative of the total population from which they were drawn.
There is the selection of samples by quotas. On the basis of attributes of the population which are already known, the researcher can select samples deliberately to include all the relevant types and to cover these types in proportion to their profile in the total population.
It is not always easy for researchers to obtain a sample that qualifies as 'representative' according to these strict criteria. It demands that we know relevant details about the whole population.
Social researchers frequently rely on a less stringent version of representativeness in which the principle remains the same but the rigor of selection of the sample is relaxed somewhat. The principle is still that the instances used for the research allow for the findings of the research to be extrapolated to other instances not included in the research.
The researcher does not claim that the sample necessarily meets all the criteria of representativeness. The claim is that the instances used for research are 'typical'.
The word 'typical' carries with it some notion of being standard, of being normal, of being usual. It suggests that any findings from the sample will apply elsewhere because the instances included in the sample have no particularly unusual characteristics that mark them out from the rest.
While claims to conducting research on 'typical' instances certainly retain the need to identify key features relevant to the investigation, the sample might not include all of the relevant categories.
The claim to generalizability, however, persists through the emphasis on:
Including the main type
Achieving some balance of the numbers in each category


A case study approach is used when a researcher's focus is on a limited number of instances.
Researchers can make the strategic decision to concentrate their investigation on one or a few cases in order to allow greater depth to their research, more attention to the dynamics of the situation, better insights that come from a detailed knowledge and understanding of a specific example. (Qualitative researchers favor this strategy)
Example:
There is almost no chance of getting a sample that is large enough and widespread enough to satisfy the criteria for being representative, in a statistical sense, of the whole 'population.'
The selection tends to rely on a more purposeful process in which examples are chosen for their particular qualities, as opposed to being chosen with no regard for their individual traits (random) or being chosen with respect to some general category (quota).
There are 4 grounds on which cases might be chosen to reflect their particular qualities:
Researchers can justify generalizations from their case study (or small sample) if they can establish that the instance included in the research was typical of other instances.
The basis for the generalization is that whatever was found in the one instance actually studies was likely to appear in other instances because there was nothing unusual, nothing special, about the case that was investigated.
Social researchers can opt to focus on instances that are anything but representative or typical. 'Extreme' instances may be selected deliberately because they have certain qualities that exaggerate the influence of a particular factor that is of interest to the researchers.
Things might be visible in these circumstances simply because the situation is extreme or special, and that these might be impossible to detect in more 'watered down' instances. Things become visible here that would remain hidden under typical circumstances. (It can suggest the way things might develop if typical instances start to shift towards the special or extreme. The special/extreme example might act to alert is to factors that would otherwise have remained hidden under the typical circumstances. What was detected in the extreme instance should be looked for in the typical.)
Researchers might decide to focus on instances which would appear to present a least likely scenario in terms of the theory or proposition they are investigating.
Following the commitment to testing theories to destruction and challenging existing theories or suppositions through attempting to 'falsify' them, there is clear logic to choosing instances that might be expected to 'go against the grain' and prove the theory wrong.
The selection of a case might reflect the fact that it constitutes an event or situation that is a special case - a one-off or extremely rare occurrence.
It is almost certain that such events or situations are beyond the control of the researcher in the sense that he or she could not organize for them to happen, as in an experiment. The timing and the location of the event will be something to which the researcher responds rather than initiates.


The degree to which the findings from the small number of events or cases being studies might be expected to apply elsewhere can be addressed by comparing and contrasting the nature of the specific units of study with the broader population of such units that exist.
The selection of instances for research can be based on their usefulness in terms of the contrast they offer with other instances chosen to be included in the research. The researcher can deliberately set out to select examples that provide a stark contrast with one another and that represent the widest variation possible within the thing being studied.
Choosing them to achieve a maximum variation allows the research to use the comparative method, controlling for key variables such as size and location, to see what other factors might appear to be linked with these.
Selection on the basis of comparison can be useful:
It can allow an element of 'triangulation' between alternatives. The researcher is able to see how a certain thing works in two or more very different settings.
It is useful where the research design is emergent. Where the researcher selects cases as part of an unfolding path of discovery, then the idea that has emerged from the one example can be compared with the next sample, which might be consciously chosen as one that is different.
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/HDFS Classes/Research Methods/@denscombeGroundRulesSocial2010.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Weekly Reaction Papers
item.description:
To develop your writing and critical thinking skills, both of which are essential for success in graduate school and beyond, you will be turning in weekly reaction papers. These papers will be written in response to the readings for that week. What should you talk about in your reaction papers?
The papers should be a comment on the theory and research for that week. It can be an idea for further research or theory, a new way of applying one of the articles, a criticism, or an integration or comparison between two or more articles.
Do not summarize. I have read the articles already. In these papers I am expecting you to come up with an original idea that in some way extends our understanding of the topic. At the end of each reaction paper, you should pose at least one discussion question. Some considerations when posing your questions:
Your question should be related to the thought/reflection that you develop (i.e., provide a rationale for asking the question)—I am as interested in your thought processes as I am in the question itself. If you question the methodology of a particular study, be sure you are clear as to why there may be a methodological problem.
Possible answers the question; (i.e., Don’t ask rhetorical questions and try to ask questions that go beyond the material); 3.)
Avoid asking the same questions every week; 4.) Be sure the question is discussable.
Papers should be about 2 pages, double-spaced.
You are required to turn in 11 reaction papers, but you will have opportunity to write one for 13 weeks. I will take the 11 highest grades.
You will upload your paper to Carmen by 11:59pm the Tuesday before class—this will allow time for me and your classmates (see below) to integrate your questions into the presentation and discussion for a give article.
Please make sure you proofread your writing for grammar and spelling errors. One strategy that may be helpful is reading the paper out loud prior to turning a paper in.
Your reaction papers will be graded on the criteria show in the following rubric:

item.title: Abduction
item.description:
Theory is a creative process of moving from observation to theory.
Use imagination, experience, literature, or intuition to generate theory
Use justification to provide logical account connecting observation to theory
Interplay between all three—starts with abduction to generate and develop theory, then deduction to develop/test theory – induction helps make sense of testing theory.

item.title: Demographic Transition
item.description:
Based on observed changes across countries throughout the world that are experiencing different paces of industrialization (things like the industrial revolutions, advances in germ theory, access to clean water, hygiene, food availability, and wars)
Good summary:
This is a state of high birth and death rates culminating in low population growth overall.
With a consistently high birth rate and decreasing death rate, population growth surges.
As the birth rate falls and the death rate remains low, the population continues to increase.
Traditionally considered to be the final stage, this is one of demographic stabilization, in which both birth and death rates are low. This means that the overall population stays fairly low.
This final, contested stage may predict higher or lower fertility levels depending on which theorist you ask.
item.guid: University Resources/HDFS/HDFS Classes/Theoretical Perspectives on the Family (HDFS 8820)/Key Terms and Concepts/Demographic Transition.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Demography
item.description:
The Institute for Population Research & Census are examples of what demographers do.
May sound familiar as you often need to include “demographics” in your research projects.
Traditionally defined as studying three population processes, fertility, mortality, and migrations.
More modern conceptualizations are social demography that seek to study population processes that may not fully align with these big three (e.g., Family Demography is a big field).
Family Demography typically two types of studies:
Careful tracking and measurement of families at either a given time point or trends over time.
Focus on the social, cultural, and economic correlates, precursors, and consequences of family structure and transitions.

item.title: Descriptive Statement
item.description:
A theoretical concept like family cohesion in a contextual theory might appear in a hypothesis as a set of survey questions about how close people in a family feel to one another, in a narrative description as an informant’s story about family celebrations, or in an empirical generalization as the frequency of family meals.
Descriptive statements are more about observable/measurable concepts.

item.title: Diverging Destinies
item.description:
“Diverging Destinies” framework, articulated by McLanahan (2004), indicates that families are increasingly dissimilar across social class lines, often proxied by educational attainment.
A theme you will notice about a lot of demographic and sociological explanations is that they take an economic or structural approach to understanding families, marriage, child-birth, and development.
